review_title: Best People + Most Fun Place to Work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in North York, ON
pros:
I joined Capital One out of university, and I haven't second guessed that decision since. It's been such an awesome place to start off my career, and when I look at my friends who graduated around the same time, most have since left their first employer or aren't nearly as satisfied with them as I am with Capital One.

A few things contribute to this satisfaction:
1) High performing culture. They hire incredibly talented and hard working people, and they foster a collaborative environment where people are incented to coach and develop others. I've always been fortunate enough to have managers who are passionate about people leadership, which is really exciting as someone new out of school.
2) Job variety. Whether you're interested in building quantitative models, designing marketing strategies, working on the Mobile App or new tech products, etc., there's an area of the business that's at the forefront of the field. I've had the opportunity to move around a handful of times, each time learning a new space and working with new people.
3) Fun. Nothing beats loving coming to work every day. The people I'm surrounded with make me laugh multiple times per day, and the formal committees within the company do an awesome job planning activities like Blue Jays games, Paint Nights, Holiday Parties, etc. Because the culture is close knit, there's also a lot of informal fun, like after work drinks, etc.

All in all, this place is pretty awesome.
cons: My biggest dissatisfier about working at Capital One is the North York office location. While it's on the subway and super convenient to get to on a daily basis, it's not as exciting as being downtown. Luckily, the office is moving downtown in 2018... and I can't wait!

review_title: Mostly awesome company, can be difficult to get things done
job_title: Master Software Engineer in Richmond, VA
pros: Pay and benefits are great.  Lots of opportunities to work in many different areas and job roles.  Typically able to move to a new role without too much trouble (can be manager dependent though).  Some teams are more flexible with working remote.  There are a lot of internally accessible training courses and Capital One has partnered with a number of external training companies to provide associates access to online training.
cons: Capital One is a large company, so it is easy to get lost in the crowd.  Performance management seems to be based more on who knows you versus what you have done.  It can be difficult to get things done because there are so many processes, reviews, approvals, and rules that you have to jump through in order to do actual work.  Some of the automation seems to cause more headaches than it has helped to make the job easier.  Things change constantly and it can be difficult to keep track of the latest method to do something is.  Attending conventions can be difficult or impossible due to limited numbers of individuals being approved to attend.   Mandatory CBTs are required on a quarterly basis for compliance reasons, but CBTs are not always appropriately targeted based on job roles, so you will most likely have to complete one or more CBTs that have nothing to do with your job.  A lot of groups/teams are meeting dependent, so you may spend an abundant amount of time each day in meetings which may not add much value to your daily work.

pros: Benefits are great. Campus amenities are superior. Overall organization's mission towards the customer being the #1 priority is honorable and inspiring, and the perspective lives throughout the company. Bonuses are very generous. Compensation is average.
cons: Advancement is extremely difficult, as it requires a heavy amount of politics and a to have a particular personality type. If you make it to the next level, you are placed into a stretch role, which means you aren't promoted technically for a year. There are 3 levels for every one compared with most companies in the industry, so these are baby steps. You must have a very high energy level and communicate a certain way to be successful. Lots of buzz words.  Highly competitive. Lots of hype, not as much is actually accomplished compared with the intensity. There is an overly zealous focus on several different forms of documentation. Several groups work on the same solutions at once and may the first to deliver a mediocre presentation win. Culture caters to 20 somethings, and not many are older than 40. If you are over 40, and like to get things accomplished and be recognized in anyway for your work, the environment will be tough coming in from other organizations.

review_title: Good work-life balance, inconsistent opportunities for career progression
pros:
- Great work-life balance (can be busy at times but schedule is very flexible)
- Good pay and benefits
- Leadership is accessible and approachable
- Some smart and fun people to work with
- Can be exposed to different areas of the business
- Great place for those who are highly analytical and willing/able to completely cater to your surroundings (see below)
cons:
- Very hierarchical official reporting levels
- Experience outside of Capital One largely doesn't matter, in terms of its value to the company (i.e., none) and how you've been used to getting work done
- Some managers are no good at managing people, but by definition they have to. No option to progress with hard skills.
- Direct manager plays too important a role in a person's career. All your eggs are in one basket. No avenue to get around it unless you want to officially complain about your manager.
- Promotions are very political, despite efforts to make it transparent. It all comes down to how much the aforementioned managers are willing/able to fight to get you promoted, and your ability to suck up, for lack of better word. No consideration whatsoever for experience/tenure (they pride themselves on this).
- Re-orgs are way too frequent. While they don't as frequently let people go, there's a good chance you or your manager have no control over drastic changes to your actual role.

cons: competitive, low work life balance

pros:
Capital One is a brand that many future employers will recognize and carries some clout in this area.

Contractors are well-compensated for work.

Working from home and flexible scheduling allows for a nice work-life balance.

Fast moving.

Nice co-workers.
cons:
Contracting feels like being a stranger in a strange land. There is a certain hierarchy that is built into the way things are done there, and contractors are at the bottom of the rung. It is reinforced not only by differently colored badges (Yellow vs. Blue) and CONT after one's name on email and IM, but also by involvement and perks, such as not being able to use the gym, health center, or Career Development Center. Also contractors are excluded from other events with the exception of department potlucks. 

Space is at a premium at West Creek, so don't expect a cubicle or an office to work in. The PODS can be very noisy, thus headphones are a necessity.

I have personally found that several managers dangle the conversion carrot to increase productivity from contractors only to renege at a later date. The decisions on who to make an associate are not always clear.

Do not expect much in the way of training or assistance after the first week or so in the job. This is SPARTA.

All that being said, a good manager can negate many of those issues. Managers who view contractors as team members rather than as resources make all the difference.

Culturally, Capital One moves very fast. Reorgs and change management are very common. However, these decisions are not always well- considered or fully funded. Capital One loves processes and data, but doesn't always know what to do with it. 
 
Too many meetings, acronyms, and as other posters described, empty words.

review_title: It All Depends on Manager and Work Unit
job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: Very bright people to work with and very interesting work - if you are in the right place, and that seems to be getting harder to do according to my friends who still work at Cap One.
cons:
Career advancement highly dependent on your manager - they can make or break your career.  You will probably change managers frequently.  The 360 review process and dreaded "cross calibrations" make the review process more like getting into a college fraternity than properly assessing your performance.  You can easily get "blackballed" by a manager other than you own.  You will have to spend time on political tasks that advance your "brand identity" to as many managers as possible.  This, however, is a fact of life in the modern corporate environment at Cap One if you want to advance.

Cap One is now so top heavy in risk management and process management that it really is becoming "just like any other bank."  Additionally the work environment, at least at the West Creek campus, is like being in kindergarten where everyone sits around a big table to work.  Great if everyone is polite and considerate, but not so great for those who talk on their cell phones or hold conference calls on speakerphone.  Invest in a good pair of in the ear, noise cancelling headphones and bring your favorite play list with you to work.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: You are exposed to some of the most intelligent, dedicated professionals on the planet. Hours can be flexible depending on what department you are in and working from home is an accepted practice in most professional roles. The company is very active in the community and sponsors volunteer events regularly for associates to participate in. The salary and benefits package is competitive. Taking on new challenges is encouraged and once you have been in your role for a year you can post for any available roles at your level.
cons: There are reorgs frequently. There is no rhyme or reason to the cadence with which they will shake up your work life, job or reporting relationship. In some cases these reorgs result in folks losing their jobs. Also, coming to work every day and doing your assigned job is not enough to be successful. Going above and beyond is the minimum standard. Be prepared to take on more and work outside of your role if you expect to keep your career with this company. The performance management process is the most convoluted I have ever seen. You are pitted against people at your same level within your department and your manager has to go into a cage match twice a year to fight for your ranking. I have never had a problem navigating the process. It is just something to be aware of before you sign on.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: Information Based Strategy in every aspect of running the business. Usually there are a lot going on at the same time that you get to always learn new skills and areas of the business. The commute to work is just 15 mins for most folks. You can work from home if you are Mobile. The work life balance is amazing. In the current economic environment, capital one seems to be in a sweet spot as the company has very low mortgage exposure and has a good mix of card and banking products. The deposits at the acquired banks seems to provide cheap capital for card portfolio to run its business. The unemployment rate seems to the biggest challenge for the company out there but the exposure reduction programs and loss mitigation efforts seems to be taking the company aggressively in the right direction. The job involves a lot of analysis and get to learn how to use data of all kinds in creating good strategy decks. Credit Risk Management practices and decision processes gives a very good grounding for any credit risk analysis roles later in the career.
cons: Pay isnt too great. Being at the right places where there are the next higehr roles available determines to a great extend your chances for getting promoted. TARP has affected green card filings and hirings of h1b visas lately. Government activism in recent times is scary and any kind of new constraints leads to sub optimal solutions and the whole card industry would be impacted by the regulatory changes that govt is introducing soon.

pros: This company is focused on the future. Very tech-savvy, and doing so much more than credit cards. Excellent work-life balance and a CEO that is a founder and has a ton of passion for the business.
cons: Employment is treated like a 24/7 competition. You're competing with every coworker every day to earn the right to keep your job, and maybe get promoted. Performance management takes up considerable time and causes considerable anxiety. You're considered an athlete competing to stay on the team. This idea is taken to extremes, causing a highly passive-aggressive environment. If you're "in", you're set. If you're not, it's an uphill battle to ever get the chance to break in. Too much time wasted on doing things "beyond your job", selling the idea that "being great at your job isn't enough". Nobody is in charge and everybody has a say. This is great in theory, but when it's time to make a decision, nobody is clearly empowered to make the call so compromise is key. As a result, moving forward means watering down projects to make lots of people feel ok about agreeing to move forward. Decision by committee takes the bite out of innovative efforts.

review_title: If you are talented, be careful
pros:
Great people, great learning, great experience getting to your goals with a catch.  Has helped me wonderfully achieve many personal goals.  Great chance to “lead” others without authority. 

Great first company for anyone coming out of college. 

The people have great attitude and are kind.  The culture shock will be very positive after arrival. 

Workspaces are innovative and well designed.  Whiteboards galore depending on what building your at.
cons:
Managers are honest to the fault of being petty and the performance management system will weed out super performers and those with diversity (yes, me).  The funny thing is for the poor performance management system and poor bonuses (you most likely will not get what they tell you), it suffocates talent and we leave daily to better opportunities.  Yes, people grow, but for a company I love and would rather stay with, the bell-curved talent distribution doesn’t work.  Pay could also be about 20-30% higher for mid-career folks.  

Leadership is split between directors and above who play politics and make decisions slowly to senior managers and below who feel like they are on a ship without a captain.  

Promotions tend to go to like-minded people as disruption or a different way of working is frowned upon.  

Benefits have reduced over the last few months.  Not sure why when the company is handsomely profitable. 

Would I return?  Neutral, and I would consider based on updates made to manage talent and some of the items above.

pros:
Great mission "changing banking for good" - company is truly putting action to this and it has greatly excited our workforce.  The customer focus is truly awesome and is really inspiring.
CEO continues to be the charismatic driving force behind the mission and the declared corporate strategy and spends significant time getting in front of associates annually to present on it
Awesome benefits
Company is doing very well overall
cons:
Company continues to be heavily skewed with most senior leaders having come in as Business Analysts in Marketing and Analysis (M&A in Capital One).
Lately Digital Product Managers and Data Scientists are the hot jobs - coming in as anything else is definitely less appreciated and long term outlook for some roles is questionable at best (Project Manager, Data Analysts, etc).  Of course it is still good to be a BA also (although some are starting to question that, and attrition is going up).
Performance management, while a 360 process, continues to be questionable at best.  Promotions don't always make sense and clearly are not always results based (no different than many other companies, but good to go in with eyes open that it is far from perfect here despite our 360 process)
Continued hiring swings.  Record # of hires in some areas while redeployments (layoffs) in others.  Senior leadership does not manage this well.

review_title: So far so good; Fraud Intake Coordinator job review
job_title: Fraud Intake Coordinator in Tampa, FL
pros:
I just finished classroom training so my review will be based on that and updated later on. Classroom training is eight hours a day for four weeks long. It is A LOT of information, but the trainer is really good at her job.Also, being in the classroom with people who had experience and with people who didn't made it easier to learn things. There's a lot of managers, and each one came in multiple times throughout training to meet us. So far, management looks laid back and personable. 

BENEFITS BROKEN DOWN:
All benefits including 401k matching,health,dental,vision,education assistance,adoption assistance, start on DAY ONE!
The benefits cant be matched elsewhere. Yes, hourly isn't anything to write home about, but you're offered a "differential" to work a later shift of about 10%, over time is given if wanted and theres monthly bonuses that add up to $1250 that agents can get. From what I have heard from current agents, they aren't too hard to get.
Health care: This is the best health care I have seen for hourly employees. Again, it starts on day one, and their most expensive plan for one person is about $30/month, which includes no copay and free walk-in clinic visits. Add dental and vision on for about 2 extra a month.
I didn't get insurance, but purchased life insurance. My $138,000 policy is about 3 dollars a month.
Education assistance is $5500 for Bachelors and Masters degrees


Capital One as a company is really cool. They pride themselves on having personal relationships with their customers.
cons: It seems to be very difficult to get promoted

review_title: Great benefits and good flexibility for work life balance if you can survive the culture.
job_title: Director, Human Resources in Wilmington, DE
pros: Benefits, flexibility with work hours (for non-front line jobs), good comp plans, amazing CEO and vision. Amazing community involvement.  Some of the most talented people work there.
cons: Leadership (VP + levels) - it's a good ole boys world and Richmond runs the show so if you are not in Richmond or follow suit and comply with old school methods and practices you will struggle in the environment. There is a culture of fear -(regardless of what is preached) and you are always needing to "show well" or "concede to egos" or you will be calibrated down in performance reviews (or out) and will not move up or around in your career there.  It's all about who you know and who likes you versus the impact you have on the organization. I have seen some of the worst leaders get promoted.

review_title: Best job I have had so far
job_title: Associate Principal Engineer in Nottingham, England
pros:
- Great bunch of people who are motivated to achieve and very friendly.

- Lots of paid for social occasions (food and drinks provided), at least one / month since I have worked here.

- Nice working environment (clean, tidy, good quality equipment, nicely decorated, plenty of natural light).

- Breakout areas to get away from desk Games room (pool table, table football, table tennis), Music room (drum kit, many guitars, piano, guitar hero on xBox), Gym.

- Free tea, coffee (instant and freshly ground 200 degrees coffee) and milk provided with taps dispensing boiling water so you don't have to wait for the kettle.

- Excellent facilities to run / cycle to work (huge bike shed, changing rooms with many showers, lockers and a drying room for towels / wet kit).

- Subsidised Canteen with restaurant quality food.

- Only have to ask management team once to remove blockers / perform tasks and there are absolutely no worries that it will happen.

- Half an hour / week meeting with manager to discuss absolutely anything that is happening at work. These have never been put off or cancelled to make way for anything, it's very important to the management to keep the communication lines open and stamp on any issues as soon as they arise.

- Excellent communication downwards from the top about what is happening in the business and what direction we are moving in strategically.

- Trusted to manage own workload and time. No micro-management.

- Possibility of company mobile phone if required.
cons:
- Workload not always as technically challenging as I would like it to be.

- Quite a lot of admin / process to follow (to be expected in a heavily regulated financial institution).

review_title: Excellent work life balance for those who need it!
pros: The best reasons to work for Capital One are the work life balance and flexibility to perform your job.  No set hours and you aren't tied to your desk.  As long as you are performing your job well, you have the flexibility to set your own schedule and work location flexibility.  This is a huge advantage compared to other companies I've worked for in the past.
cons: The performance management system is a bit frustrating primarily because you don't really have any set performance goals that would give you a guaranteed rating.  You are judged in a pool with your peers on a bell curve.  If a peer gets a high profile project to work on and you don't, they will likely get a higher rating even if you produced more results of equal quality.  Likely similar to a consultant environment minus an up or out philosophy due to it taking longer for promotions on average.  Just recently modified job levels to increase opportunities and shorter times for promotions, so they are trying to improve the system.  However, they need to work on helping to adjust management's mindset to align with the new system as many of them still have the same mindset based on the prior longer promotion process.

review_title: Excellent work/life balance, overly focused on empirics, too much middle management
pros:
Laid back culture; management and oversight is extremely lax, the most junior associates are trusted and empowered to get their deliverables compelted on their own schedule.  I work in the Northern Virginia office and my entire management heirarchy is in the Richmond office, so I basically come and go as I please so long as I get my work done when it's needed and the results are good.  I can basically work from home whenever I like.  
Going back to trust and empowerment of junior associates, this is true also in terms of the work assigned; management does very little hand-holding, leans on these associates to perform most of the work on their own.
cons:
Traveling to Richmond on a weekly basis is a pain the rear.  At this point I basically go on my own schedule, nobody absolutely mandates I make the trip, but to effectively get results and exposure to management I don't really have a choice.
Most of the analyst teams have too much middle management; anaylsts report to managers report to directors report to VP, when in reality it seems VP always sets the strategy, analysts perform the work, and everyone in between just refines the powerpoint.  
The "Information Based Strategy" environment at times is too analytic; too much time and manpower is spent in overly detailed valuations frameworks that provide little if any value.

review_title: The rare bank on the rise
pros:
Though recently trimmed back, it still offers a relatively competitive benefits package, including healthcare, dental, child-care reimbursement, and even adoption assistance.  It is also one of the few financial corporations that is staying strong in the current climate, providing job security and plenty of room for gowth within the company.  THus, I would highly recommend getting in on the stock plan, which is available to even part-time associates, along with many of the other benefits.  
Company values actually feel genuine and are followed, breeding a loyalty among employees, which is important for stability.  Generally there is a strong team work feel at the branch and even district level, which helps morale.  And starbucks coffee...
cons: There is sometimes a problem with information trickeling down from the top and frustrating lack of uniformity regarding operations. Lack of full-time opportunities in the banking sector contributes to a brain drain as the most talented seek to make a living elsewhere.  There is the usual struggle between sales and operations as the company tries to grow, sometimes creating conflict as number-driven sales people try to push through things that are in violation of policy and even law.  There is also the professional conflict that arises when the sales side is unofficialy regarded as being above the operations side.  In some markets the perfect balance has not been achieved.

review_title: Great Benefits, Great Vision, Though I feel my role will be eliminated by tech in 8 years
pros: I'm so thankful to be working here. Top sellers: Great Benefits, Awesome Vision, and a  Really Open Forward Thinking Company. It's always featured as a Best Place to Work. I'm confident Capital One will win out and become the best in the Finance industry... barring some outsider tech disruption or economic downturn.
cons:
I am not personally challenged by the work. Though the company's pay, benefits, and general atmosphere are great in the short term I am not as fulfilled working here.

Given that the company's current vision is geared toward capitalizing on advances in tech to be the future of the company, I don't believe they will have much use for many front-line associates in 5-7 years. I'd define front line associates as the many lower paid positions within the company who handle tasks like talking to customers and handling account info.  

The one thing that causes discomfort is when you realize how much resources this company can use to keep you entertained and happy with extra peripheral stuff. This definitely isn't bad perse, but many of us associates don't like the feeling of being bought when the sentiment sinks in.

Overall though this company is doing 1000% better than others, so in comparison to any other employee who is working a somewhat unfulfilling job, Capital One will have you beat 99/100.

pros:
- Pay & benefits are good. 401k is one of the best around.
- Smart and talented coworkers
- Free snacks and coffee
- Opportunity to work on some really cool AWS cloud projects.
- Lots of holidays and PTO
cons:
Capital One is very hierarchical and is a culture of management and meetings. As a developer, I've had 4 managers in my two years here. I've had quite a few engineering jobs, and this was by far the worst managed tech culture I've ever seen. Lots of managers who can't deal with challenge and would rather remove the people with big ideas and replace them with sycophants. 

This opportunity is best for managers and junior developers because they give juniors tasks that are way above their experience level, much to the frustration of senior engineers. They are having problems keeping senior developers around because promotions are very hard to come by and the opinions of senior talent is not respected. Chest puffing is more valued than actual work.

Ultimately, you have to enjoy working in a corporate environment. By that I mean, you have to know when to open and close your mouth and know what words to say. If you are competent and can play the political game, you will do very well here. If you are here to actually care about your work, then I would look elsewhere.

pros: They have really good benefits
cons:
I chose Capital One as the HR reps who visited my school touted it as a really healthy, progressive environment that differentiated itself from the old school finance way. I was a part of the rotational program so I got to experience several parts of the bank. 

The most major issue I experienced was sexual harassment. My first week on one of my rotations, there was a work happy hour and a senior male commented that I “was going to be his second wife.” Then, in the office, another senior male made a sexually charged comment. I told my manager about it and a sexual harassment case was filed but there was no real resolution other than he had to stay away from me. For the rest of the rotation, he bad mouthed me (even to the interns that were there for the summer). I heard quite a few racist and sexist remarks that he either announced publicly or someone else would tell me how uncomfortable they were by something he said to them as well. Yet, nothing was done. After I left, I received a request to pay back some of my compensation for leaving early. I called HR to see if we could come to some sort of agreement as I had left early to get out of a toxic work environment but they “had no record of the sexual harassment case.” Ultimately I ended up just paying it in full so I could move on and not have to worry about fighting with Capital One anymore. Overall, I was disappointed by how they handled this incident.

Also, they market Capital One as a place motivated people come to build something great. Most of the people I encountered were people who came from big banks who were now ready to take it easy in a less intense environment. It didn’t really feel like a place to start your career and learn from the best. 

Last thing, performance reviews are very subjective and not transparent. If you don’t have a manager who has your back, you’ll struggle to feel fully valued. I tried to communicate with my manager early on and was constantly told that my work product was timely and of great quality and that I would likely receive the highest ranking, though it wasn’t set in stone. At the end of the rotation, I suddenly got a lower ranking because “I asked too many questions when I should be trying to problem solve on my own” when my male counterpart (who several times turned in projects late and spent most of his time on linkedin looking for other jobs or facebook) got a higher ranking than me. All the other feedback was the same as throughout the rotation but I was downgraded for that reason (even though it was never communicated to me when I asked). Looking back, it just seems like a weird process to me as I ask more questions than ever in my new job (and my manager has commented on it) yet I still get the highest rating because of my timely, solid work product. 

I now work at one of those “old school” financial institutions and it’s a much more meritocratic and supportive environment than either of my teams at Capital One (plus to be blunt, the pay is better). Looking back, I learned a good lesson and found my way but I think I could have saved myself a lot of trouble if I just started off in a big bank.

job_title: Senior Unit Manager in Plano, TX
pros:
Initiatives and strategic vision is industry leading - you truly feel like you are working for a technology company instead of a bank. They are innovating, instead of reacting (like many other institutions).

Many talented, smart colleagues - you work with motivated individuals who are trying to do more with their careers can just cash a check. 

Committed to employee satisfaction - employee satisfaction surveys are taken very seriously and management is expected to have action plans to address areas of opportunity. The company invests in facilities, benefits and other perks to make associates experience as enjoyable as possible. 

Tremendous quality internal training - particularly useful for exempt level employees. If you take advantage, you can learn things you will use your entire career. 

Endless opportunities - many associates can make career changes within the company and/or generally find jobs in whatever geographic area they want to live.
cons:
Performance management - associates in the same job level are ranked against each other by management. The perception is politics can have a significant influence on your rating. It can be particularly difficult for higher performing associates, who are not skilled at corporate politics, to receive higher ratings. 

Promotional process - in operations, promotions are often "stretch roles." This translates to you performing the role (including all responsibilities) without having the title or pay increase. "Stretch roles" can vary from six to as along as 15 months. This can be frustrating.

pros: When I worked there, I loved the culture and my co-workers.  There are also great opportunies to give back and serve the community. There are many days I miss working there, and even though it was a cutback in my department that led to me losing my position there I am forever thankful for the wonderful opportunities I had while working at Capital One.

I lost my position due to cutbacks and even though I had tons of internal people trying to help me get a new position, and had excellent performance reviews, I wasn't able to find other work within.  So, even though they talk about retaining quality talent, they don't mean it when it comes to the bottom line.  However, you find that at every company.

Capital One is an incredible place to work! Every day I am surrounded by incredibly bright, innovative people that genuinely care about one another, our customers and our community.  I believe that our values, mission and heart are the primary drivers for the company and they put people over profits. The company is an exciting and fast paced place to work, as we are on a journey to become a technology company that offers exceptional Financial Services to people. Money is so integral to our day to day lives-- from buying groceries to saving for college-- and it's important to be part of a company that wants to make managing money a positive and simple experience for people. 

In addition, Capital One has awesome work/life flexibility, paid leave, and career advancement. I have had unlimited opportunities for growth since I started with the company-- development through classes and trainings, new roles and promotions, and intentional mentorship. I genuinely believe that Capital One has set me up to do some of the most fun, most valuable work of my career.
cons: It is certainly a competitive environment, so you have to be thoughtful about making sure you manage your priorities well. Capital One supports work/life flexibility, but if you arent careful-- working from home and other options can cause you to work too much. Additionally, we are working on becoming more Agile as a company, but I still think it can be hard to get things done. As a federally regulated bank, there are a lot of hoops to jump through that you dont have to deal with at other companies.

review_title: Hire and Fire, the Capital One Way
job_title: Human Resources and Training Specialist in Richmond, VA
pros: Great benefits.  Great work-life balance once you have attained length of time.
cons:
This company offers great career roles but they do not scope them as permanent despite how they are advertised.
This company HIRES and FIRES (which they call redeployment for laying off numerous roles in bunches).
It is a part of Rich Fairbank's strategy: New and different business initiatives and practices each year.  When roles no longer fit in those new initiatives, they place you on 'redeployment'.  The company does not have a viable solution (Career Development Center) for retaining talent that may face redeployment.
Companies and roles change most certainly, but this is cut-throat.  In my 8 years at Capital One I have seen countless individuals placed on redeployment.  Great people, individuals with outstanding backgrounds, performances and skillsets.

The company does not make an initiative to retain this talent other than to say you are free to look for other roles within the company.

pros:
Satisfaction: The study showed that satisfaction is one of the most immediate benefits of an employee who fits well culturally at a company. If an employee finds their environment to be satisfactory, they are going to be happier working in that environment.
Increased Performance: That happiness is likely to lead to several motivators for the employee. Because they fit well, they’re likely to be more confident in their work and strive to work harder and achieve more. Because of a good fit, the employee will have an increase in his or her work performance, benefiting the company and the employee.
Reduced Stress: A big problem with a poor cultural fit at work is stress, affecting a number of areas in the employees life – from work performance to socializing with other employees. A good cultural fit means the employee will be less stressed at work, likely to reduce poor performance and turnover.
Reduced Attrition: If an employee is happy and fits where he or she is, they’re going to be less likely to want to change that. Finding candidates who will fit the culture of the workforce isn’t just ensuring that the candidate will just work hard – it likely means they’ll continue working hard and remaining committed to the company, with less motivation to leave.
Commitment to Company: Above all else, if an employee fits culturally to the company, he or she will identify that as part of their company experience. Therefore, they are more likely to remain committed to a company because they fit so well.
cons:

pros:
(1) Interesting work: Capital One satisfies all three rules of the "advice to data scientist on where to work", as provided by Stitchfix. We leverages data Science for its strategic differentiation; we already have great data to work with (as opposed to aspiration to great data); and we are applying big data technologies to many green field opportunities for the first time. 

(2) Great team and great learning opportunities: since data scientist is still a relatively new profession, one of the most important criteria in my mind is whether you can still learn new things on the job. Capital One as a company is strategically embracing open-source technologies such as Hadoop, python/R, Spark, AWS... etc, and there are many open-minded and experienced data scientists on the team, so that we can still continue to improve our capabilities.

(3) Competitive compensation and great work-life balance. The work life balance is definitely encouraged here. Some people have long commute, but if their job nature allows them to work from home, there is no cultural stigma associated with that. In fact, several members in our extended team work from home on a regular basis (a few days a week).

(4) Company culture: we really are changing banking for good, and the actions we take as company reflect this core value.
cons: Financial industry is heavily regulated as a whole, so if you are used to software-industry speeds, you may feel that things don't move as quickly (especially on things that concerns financial regulations)

review_title: A great place to learn and grow
pros:
The cloud journey is new to a lot of people within Capital One which gives everyone a real opportunity to influence the direction of the company and the services being developed.  This also leads into an environment in which personal learning and growth are positively encouraged, meaning there is a constant expectation that not only should you be growing as a Capital One employee, but as a individual as well.

The offices are great, London especially is a brand new custom designed office, though the diagonal desk move in Nottingham take a bit of getting used to.  Nottingham also provides a free gym and subsidised cafeteria and the food isn't half bad!

There is a real diversity of people within the office, some of who are experts in cloud technologies, some are experts in platform specific development etc. which leads to a good collection of people working towards a common goal without a prescribed approach.
cons:
There does seems to be a clash between the Capital One culture in (old) Nottingham and the culture developing in (new) London.  This does seem to be seeping into Nottingham slightly, which is showing itself in how things like performance reviews and progression are being managed.

The vast majority of the Software Engineering senior management team (Director level) are in London where-as the majority of the Software Engineers are in Nottingham, again leading to a split in how some teams are managed and developed.

review_title: Great place if you don't mind work for the sake of work
pros:
work/life balance
ability to work remotely when you need to
no one is waiting to see if you get in right at 9 a.m.
Friendly people 
Opportunities to move--to different departments--all you have to do is ask
cons:
"It's not about actually reaching the end goal, it's about showing me the process with how you are thinking through getting there"

If that makes sense to you, then you will have a very long and successful career at Capital One. If you are left wondering how you can show your process when there is no end goal and why you wouldn't want to have an end goal in the first place--then you should proceed with caution.

It's an endless cycle of creating decks and having meetings to prove that you are "thinking" and "producing" but little to no actual work ever gets completed. Long-termers seem perfectly content with this set up. However, it can be maddening to goal oriented people.

It's also a very political environment. Bonus are based on what essentially are gossip sessions between everyone who is at a level above you. Losing out on $10K in a bonus can often occur because you didn't say hi to someone when you passed them in the parking garage at the end of the day. This creates an every man for himself situation in many of the departments.

review_title: Pays well, but not worth the backstabbing
pros:
Capital One pays very well in many of its departments. Especially if you're looking to work in one of their digital departments, expect to get a pretty competitive salary.

The company's got a pretty strong strategy and seems positioned to do really well in the industry.
cons:
Maybe it's because the headquarters is so close to D.C., but I never thought a corporate job could be so similar to an episode of House of Cards. Expect each and every one of your coworkers to play the political game extremely well. Capital One structures its performance reviews around a process that pits you directly against others in your job family to determine who gets the few coveted high ratings. So it behooves everyone to spend 99% of their time making themselves look good and making their coworkers look bad. 

Unfortunately, because of this, little to no actual work gets done, as everyone is more concerned with making a friend or two that will help them advance and backstabbing everyone else in the process. With such frequent reorgs, there is ample opportunity for ambitious people to try to wrest control of teams or entire departments from anyone who tries to focus on getting work done rather than playing the game.

If it weren't for the paycheck, there's no doubt that I'd call Capital One the worst decision I ever made.

review_title: One of the best places I have worked at!
job_title: Tech Lead/IT Manager in Plano, TX
pros:
Great benefits - 7.5% match on 401K (on base and bonus), 1K match on FSA, Discounted stock purchase program.
Flexibility, open work space, Wi-Fi at work lets you work from anywhere you want in and around the building. 
Really smart intelligent colleagues who make it a great place to work. You are always challenged and motivated for that reason. 
The company is always doing the right thing for the employees/associates. (eg: they pay bonuses even when they didn't make much money or had layoffs and doesn't make that an excuse for cutting down on benefits). 
With the acquisitions of ING Direct and HSBC Cards, growing even more and unlike most other financial companies is well managed and growing, but very carefully with a bright future ahead. 
One of the rare places where I have seen things work the way they are supposed to and if not, you could find a way to work to get that changed.
cons:

review_title: It all depends on your direct manager....
job_title: Small Business Account Manager in Tampa, FL
pros:
Gift Cards & Surprise Rewards Are Frequent
Great PTO & Holiday Package
Work At Home Options In Florida, Virginia, & Deleware
cons:
There is an "in-crowd" within management. If your manager is part of that "in-crowd" AND they love you -- you are set for a fast moving career! However, if you manager is part of that "in-crowd" AND they do not like you -- your time will be short lived. If your manager is not part of that "in-crowd" then feel very lucky. 

Employee experiences vary greatly based on who your unit manager is. 

Limited opportunities for growth. 

Training seems very good and thorough while you are in it. However, once out of training, you realize it is not relevant. 

If you are hired July or later, you will not receive a raise (of any sort) for 18 months minimum. 

Each manager perceives the QA requirements very differently. So based on your team, you could have very high QAs when really your QAs should be average. Of course the opposite is true too. You could end up with very low QAs when your QAs should be very high. Bonus is based on what your QA is compared to everyone else in your department. So this issue often leads to stress in some departments.

review_title: Overall excellent until massive disruption of work life balance
pros: Great benefits health & education. Great work at home opportunities.  Nice pay increase due to meeting industry standards.
cons: A week after the "you deserve this" increase and submitting required vacation submissions for first half 2015, they announced we would be forfeiting our schedules and would be required to bid on new ones that would not be disclosed until mid January.  Required days of Monday, Friday, And one weekend day would ensure no opportunity of consecutive days off that included weekend without using vacation hours. Shifts also for later in the day.  Therefore rendering just completed vacation bid useless and upending work life balance for the majority involved.  Disrupting class schedules for college students who've been registered and paid for and with results not being available til mid January, unable to make timely adjustments in class schedule. Happy holidays.  As an employee, the need for weekend coverage is understood and would be easily implemented.  The complete upending of our personal/family lives at short notice does not coincide with their mission statement "do what's right" but is an unfortunate reminder of our place in the organization.  When questioned as to why the added measure of no concurrent day off that would include one weekend day beyond the new work hours and weekend the answer was that most companies would not even warn us.  I think most LARGE companies would and may have taken, possibly, a more measured approach.

review_title: Great starter job, if you're willing to risk your mental health
pros:
- Good starting salary
- Strong in analytics
- Nice junior coworkers, who share the pain
cons:
- Management: A culture of consistently promoting self-serving, political climbing managers who are generally willing to trade-off their associates well-being for business results and a personal promotion.

- Associates: A culture of being afraid to leave despite being depressed, because of tight-knit friendship circles at work, above-industry pay, and the impression that they are working with "the smartest people in Toronto"

- Symptoms of depression I've seen in myself and many others:
Emotional numbness, insomnia, hopelessness, overwhelming dread, zero self-worth, and a total inability to believe that things can be better. All of which feel normal in the moment, and insane in hindsight.

Also being afraid to express these feelings, partially because I've experienced and seen other managers tell their associates off for “being negative”. This is despite all the mental health training for managers. 

There are also some truly great managers, but they are the minority and won't get promoted as quickly compared to the ones who optimize for self-gain.

review_title: Traveled a long way to find out it was just like everywhere else
pros: At first, Capital One seemed to be an ideal place where customer service and associate engagement were not contradictions in terms.  Certainly the site management, with a few legacy HSBC exceptions, did their part to ensure the culture was maintained.  The front line incentive has been generous and based only on QA scores, no sales.  The company seemed to be dedicated to bringing customer service work back in-house and on-shore in spite of the expense, and made multiple investments in the site and associates to underscore it.
cons: The punch line is that Capital One hired a new Sr VP of Card Channels, and her vision was to outsource more service work under the guise that it was needed to be "scalable" in a more digital world.  Also blamed was the city for not making it easy to recruit or retain employees.  All of that seems like a ruse.  The truth is that the folks in Richmond and McLean want to control everything and don't want in-house leaders making them look bad.  If you are seriously looking at a Capital One job outside of HQ, recommend you pass because they are likely to up and move at any time.

review_title: LOVE WHAT THE COMPANY OFFERS BUT HATE THE LIFERS!
job_title: Senior Data Analyst in North York, ON
pros: Capital One Canada is an interesting company; being a foreign branch of a top american bank, it has access to great associate development programs and training resources. They also compensate their associates above well industry standard to compete for talent in the financial services space and technology space. This company is a great stepping stone for new graduates.
cons:
There are quite a bit of lifers in middle management at Capital One Canada. These lifers are pretty much stuck and content or even happy. They get paid at less 100k base salary for delivering the quality of work of a junior consultant. Sweet Deal, Right? The chance of transitioning to a big 5 bank probably means a pay cut or running the risk of being the underperformer of a big bank. As these are lifers could only perform in a junior consultant level, the top tech firms like apple, google, amazon, etc, probably won't take them and tech startups mean getting a pay cut and doing REAL work, so NO… Staying put is probably in their best interest. They make it incredibly difficult for new hires to settle in. The turnover is pretty high, on average associates stay for least than 2 years.

P.S. A lot of the 4-5 stars are fake posts from HR. If you filter the rating from highest to lowest, you would notice that there are not a lot people find the posts "helpful" but you filter the rating from lowest to highest, you would notice a lot more people find the post "helpful".

review_title: Can be a good place to start a career, if you're lucky.
pros: Can be a great place for those with an analytical bent depending on team placement.  Business issues are addressed with analytical rigor and people are interested in finding the best answers.  Some of the teams have a friendly and fun atmosphere - lots of young people who often hang out together when they are not at work.  There is some focus on developing general business skills so people are able to take some of what they learn at Capital One and leverage that in other positions at other firms.  There is certainly a good bit of talent - lots of smart people at all levels of the organization
cons: There are significant downsides to starting a career in such a large organization - one that sometimes feels stagnant.  Opportunities for advancement are often based on matters of luck / building visibility rather than in delivering strong results.  There are significant organizational hurdles to getting sometimes simple things done - detailed prioritization processes and so on.  Success in navigating those channels can play too large a role in overall success.  It's hard to get aware from the fact that much of the business feels dirty - or at least ethically questionable... getting people who aren't smart about credit to pay all kinds of fees doesn't give you that warm feeling at night.

review_title: Working with smart people can keep you on your toes
job_title: Business Analyst in West McLean, VA
pros: Capital One might not be the biggest name in financial services, but that only makes it somewhat more willing to try new things and step out of the box a little more often than some of its competitors. Most decisions are made with a good deal of analysis and information about the market, which makes shots in the dark few and far between. You're surrounded by smart people. Not only are other analysts capable, but so is most of management, having risen through the ranks themselves. This helps give the impression that there is upward mobility within the company and gives associates something to strive for.
cons: Capital One has re-orgs on a fairly regular basis. It takes a while to fully understand what your new role is inside the company, and sometimes by the time you get settled and understand the different aspects of your new job, you've changed roles again. Rapid changes to your managers might also prove to be a hindrance to getting promoted - if your new manager hasn't worked with you in the past, it feels fairly hard to get recognized - I have had very competent coworkers who have been in this situation. Lastly, you are surrounded by smart people, and you are often second guessed by your management - but that serves to keep you on your toes and to produce airtight arguments.

job_title: Capital One Risk Associate in Tampa, FL
pros:
Cubical environment (shared) environment, super fun sometimes, and relaxed managers. (purely dependent on manager)

The bathrooms are clean, nice break areas (building management is the reason for this).
cons:
It's a collections job, you have to meet monthly quotas or else your on PIP. Once your PIP is over and you aren't improving, you'll be let go. I've seen it happens many times, sometimes it can become stressful with the monthly quota necessary and the stress they put on collecting money. Most of the time it's luck, some people will get out of the ditch they are in and be able to pay, where as others are living with their parents, homeless, jobless, and simply cannot pay even if they want to.

The supervisors and managers look for kissing ups, otherwise you have no success of moving up. If your daddy has a high position there, expect promotion fast. Otherwise, you're a sitting duck waiting for a promotion. No growth and advancements. 

Previous employees will tell you that they do not like the job they are doing and the job is beyond stressful after 3-4 months working there. You will learn real fast after all the positive talking in training, they don't tell you the real things that awaits you. 

Oh did I mention pay is horrible?

review_title: I have worked for other financial institutions and Capital One is by far the best. They truely practice what they preach
pros: Levels do not matter when it comes to adding input or suggestions/comments/concerns. I have worked in several dept's at Capital One and you truely are treated like an equal no matter if you are entry level, or a Senior level. Capital One gives all its associates the opportunity to learn and grow from those at a higher level and is very patient and encouraging when it comes to personal growth and development.
cons: The performance management cycle is bittersweet. If you perform well, you are rewarded highly. But, if you work in a large department that means you can get lost in the mix of other associates you are calibrated with at the end of the year. Its hard to stand out and shine if you work within a large group of people at the same level.

review_title: Lots of perks, lots of layoffs and turnover
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros:
Perks:  West Creek gym, best cafeterias I have seen in the corporate world, good insurance, ESSP, etc.
Campus setting is pretty to look at.
Intelligent people (for the most part) to work with.
Generous severance package
cons:
Cutthroat environment.  They are in massive "redeployment" (layoff) mode.  The good news is that the severance is so good and the morale is so bad that many people like me took the money and ran.  Meanwhile, there is a constant stream of new college hires walking in.

Richmond associates are being asked, then begged, then forced (or get redeployed) to move to Willmington, DE.

Cross calibrations/Performance reviews are a year round process.  It is all based on comparisons to your peers throughout the company who are all working on different types of projects.  This means it is a back room process with your manager fighting (or not) with the other managers to see who gets what raises & promotions.  Read up on your Machiavelli if you want to survive here.

review_title: Don't work here if you aren't of a certain background . . .
job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: They pay you money I guess
cons: I was a data analyst for about a year, but left as soon as I possibly could.  I'll just be upfront here - I'm a white woman, and this was a place for Indian men.  Almost my entire department was Indian.  Really set the culture of the place - I was supposed to be a super meek little woman, without opinions.  Racist (against white people) and sexist place - at least in the data analyst sphere.  Yikes - stay away!  This was such a shock - this was my second job and my previous company had been wonderfully supportive of women, so this was just so weird to me.   I was specifically told to hang back, not speak in meetings, not take initiative, etc.   When I had the experience, creativity, and intelligence to really make a difference.  Such a weird place, the data analyst environment.  A real blip on my resume - haven't had any other issues in my career, so I do think it's them, not me.

review_title: It's mind boggling how inept upper management is
pros: Made a lot of friends there, and the culture was trying to adapt to a more "open-door, open mindedness" atmosphere....schedules were flexible for the most part, and benefits were decent.
cons: Upper management operates off the stereotypes that the company was desperately trying to avoid...hiring managers with zero interpersonal skills. They may have been decent at their jobs at the time that they were an associate, but that doesn't mean they're capable of connecting & leading a team of 20 agents. What you got was immaturity, politics, power-hungry type-A's.....and it created the most toxic atmosphere.  My last manager was a work-horse with the personality of a T800...he fostered unethical behavior to ramp up stats...was called out for it, but since the stats made him look good they promoted him to a PA overseeing an entire department. Execs came down once or twice a year and were given the red-carpet treatment by management who spent a  considerable amount of time covering up the truth and having them ONLY speak with agents who were glorified cheerleaders.

review_title: Do not work here - especially not in tech
pros: The negatives out-weigh the positives in every way. They waste time while talking about "not wasting time". They applaud time at the company with complete disregard for ability to manage and Capital One dips itself consistently into technology that they have no idea what to do with. They do have a great work from home policy on occasion depending on who your manager is but they re-org so often that it's hard to have consistency.
cons:
Pay is not good, normally they try to sell you on a yearly bonus that is a range that they make impossible to attain the top dollar of.Capital One is a true example of management styles that are stuck in the past. They have weak people in management positions taught by the bureaucratic environment that sticking up for their employees is not worth it. They have lost numerous people (who are great employees) simply due to policy and weak management not willing to stand up to precedence for team members. 

Capital One presents itself as a technology savvy bank. However I can only attribute this presentation to the marketing department because within the technology departments I worked in the people in charge had no understanding of their products or the technology necessary to produce quality. They would fully staff teams before they even procured new software that these teams were planned to work on. The amount of waste is really overwhelming. I would advise going to another company if you want to be challenged. If you prefer to coast then this place is perfect.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Plano, TX
pros:
- The work/life balance at Capital One is unbeatable. Excluding software engineers, I don't think you could make the same $/hour anywhere else early in your career.
- You drive how much responsibility you're given. If you want to take on extra projects and expand the scope of your role, you're generally given the freedom to do so - just ask! The time and effort dedicated to your professional development is incredible.
- You're surrounded by very smart and very friendly folks at Capital One. HR does a great job of hiring personable people who have the raw brain power to get up to speed fast.
- While it's a bank, Capital One really does focus on maintaining a high standard of ethical behavior. They do everything possible to help customers pay their bills on time and to make the customers' lives easier.
- Leadership takes the time to explain our strategic priorities regularly and thoroughly.
- While the promotion system requires a little bit of politicking at higher levels, it's overall well-done and fairly executed.
cons: - The biggest con applies to the entire industry: it's hard to get excited about financial services. Staying motivated can be hard when you're not passionate about what you do, and many people find it difficult to be passionate about banking.

job_title: Senior Risk Representative (Collections) in Tulsa, OK
pros:
Great vacation benefits.
Good 401k 
Decent office setting
Lots of holiday meals provided
Decent bonuses
Lots of paid bank holidays
cons:
Training is completely subpar. My trainer was gone in meetings 90% of the time and had an employee from the floor babysit the class, but we were hardly trained at any point in time. 

The dialer is a disaster and crashes half the time. 

My manager was atrociously bad. If questioned, she would put her own team members off onto another manager because she didn't know the answers to problems. She yelled at staff and encouraged them to quit if they fell below 100% because they would make her look bad. She had the "best" Mini Miranda team in the location because she would bully and humiliate employees until they quit. 


The system and phones were slow and often crashed or hung up on customers. It was not uncommon for the computer to freeze and crash once a day or more. The entire system would crash for the entire site and we would have irate customers screaming at us while we couldn't use the system to take payments.


The QA team is extremely meticulous, which is fine, except agents are not trained on what counts against them. There is varying answers among teams. You will almost never get a legitimate answer because every single manager believes QA does something differently. These passings/failings mean you don't get bonuses depending on how bad you did.

review_title: A good place to start your career
job_title: Senior Business Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Extremely well balanced work life arrangement. It is relatively a young organization with most associates below 40, which makes the environment energetic and challenging. Highly analytical approach to work with big reliance on data and less so on qualitative factors.There is an open culture of soliciting opinions and feedback. Their is also a culture of encouraging or supporting associate decisions to change groups or role type.
cons:
Growth beyond junior/entry level positions is very limited. The competition is high, so if you are looking for fast growth this is not the company for you. Also the company culture is very data driven, with certain groups like Business Analyst community highly respected while others are not given adequate value.
Leadership and management skills at mid to senior level leaves much to be desired. The growth of the company has put some relatively young people at senior levels who were rewarded with promotions for their analytical skills and the not the ability to lead or manage people. This is especially true for roles on the business side.
Constant re-organization and moving of groups will leave you confused as to who is doing what.

pros: Given five promotions in six years for work above and beyond. Found anyone wanting promotion had to press the flesh with the right people and work the politics. Hard work and awards alone weren't enough. Leadership was sometimes lacking. I went four months on one team and we did not have a manager in that time. Team was eventually absorbed into other groups. Corporate perks that can be used in the community are great, if you can afford them.
cons:
Not family friendly, despite what you hear. I was written up and nearly fired for missing one day to bury a family member. Missed one day of work and immediately let my manager know and returned with an obituary. Nearly fired again when child hospitalized for serious illness. Shared news immediately with my then boss and he threatened to fire me, as my child was struggling for life in the PICU. 
Company values performance more than anything else and nobody in leadership wants to hear about problems or issues. Many colleagues came to me almost daily for answers that should've come from managers.

pros: On your first few days of training, your class will be flooded by speakers , mainly bosses , from the GM, UM's TL's down to the maintenance workers and janitors. You will be awed. The speakers speak so casually making one feel at home. A sense of "family" creeps in. And especially when the facilities, benefits and perks are discussed you will thank God for putting you there. The company, it's vision, mission and principles , nothing but admirable..
cons: If only the americans Mr. Richard Fairbank assigns here know how the filipino employees whom they designate to head the teams really operate. How they practice favoritism. How they favor those who go on drinking sprees with them more over those who are serious and dedicated to their work and seldom has the time to hang out.  The BPO industry , supposedly doesn't have any sort of discrimination, and Capital One sort of adheres to that and one would think, if he / she is above 40 years old, that the company doesn't practice discrimination in age. Maybe the company, the leaders, managers, they clearly do. This is a good company put up and raised from the ground up by one good and exemplary man. Too bad the people they choose to lead are swell-headed, arrogant, power tripping filipinos who terminates their fellow filipinos if they find them too serious or too boring.

cons:
- Boy's Club: finance is still a very conservative industry and particularly in the Risk/AML spheres, a lot of the focus is on hiring former Law Enforcement, which means that it becomes a fairly misogynistic environment pretty quickly
- HR is basically completely centralized. Unless you're in Richmond, expect to be ignored.

review_title: Inspiring leader who keeps Capital One ahead of the competition!
pros: Capital One has allowed me the opportunity to work a very flexible schedule.  I have not missed one event for my child or family.  I do need to work longer hours at tmes to accomodate this, but it is worth it to me to take time with my family.  The people at Capital One are great to work with.  It is a very collaborative environment where people want to help one another and it is just one of many reason Capital One is the successful company it is today.
cons: Compared to other employers, there are limited downsides to working at Capital One.  One downside now is that the entire Financial Industry is not ideal to work in, but Capital One is leading their peers in terms of weathering the storm.  There are times when you work a lot of hours, but the flexibility that is offered and provided equals that out.  There is a competitive environment at Capital One, but in a good way.  Everyone is always striving to be the best and be on the A Team.  It's still very team oriented and the competitiveness is not intended to be a negative thing, but for those that are not into that environment, this may not be the place for them.

pros:
Good benefits - salary, 401K, medical
Flexible work schedules - allow work from home, flex hours to accommodate your life
Growing company - increased focus on technology, striving to be a market leader in finance and tech with focus on moving everything to the cloud
cons: Very little role clarity, constant re-orgs and forced ranking system contribute to a working environment that is constantly in flux and puts people on edge.  Was hired for one role and, shortly after one month of my arrival, the role morphed into something that I was way overqualified for.  Instead of the "team" attitude, because people are forced ranked against each other, it was less "I'll help you do this" and more "that's so and so's job." That attitude leads to a lot of backstabbing and politics across the culture.  Told to just "keep my head down" and not "rock the boat."  At this point in my career (I've been working for 10 years in corporate America), I don't have time to just skate by and hope that I don't ruffle any feathers by sharing an unpopular opinion or offering a new way of doing things.

review_title: Great benefits, minimal opportunities for advancement
pros: Competitive salary, nice bonuses, big 401K match, great benefits overall. Smart people.
cons:
Incredibly hard to get promoted. Certain job families are valued (mainly product owners and business analysts) and others are not. If you find yourself in a category that is not valued, you will likely never be promoted. Don't let them convince you otherwise.

If you are being hired in as a professional - not college - hire, make sure you are at the correct level. HR/hiring managers are notorious for interviewing at one level and then offering the role at the level down, saying they want to "set you up for success" and you can get promoted in 6 months. It is not true and you will never catch up to the right level.

"Reorgs" happen at least every 6 months. Usually these involve layoffs and massive organizational challenges. I had managers in the double digits by 3 years in. Very disruptive both for getting work done and also for career trajectories.

Super hierarchical; no one owns anything, so it's hard to get decisions made, and when they're made, they can be undone by one person questioning the decision or thinking something else; highly regulated environment; lots of bureaucracy, so it's hard to get anything done.

pros: Great benefits, generous vacation time, employee discounts, opportunity to meet executive leaders

review_title: Flexible, Open Culture with Challenging Work Environment
pros:
- The people! Really smart people with humility and openness. 
- Challenging work. The credit card business area is infinitely complex with macro- and micro-economic factors, human behavior, and risk that all needs to be under consideration in decision-making
- Flexibility. Although with colocation and agile becoming an ever-present trend in how the teams work, there is flexibility in work hours and remote work depending on the role and team. Leadership is also very supportive of personal growth (within reason) so moving to new functions or business lines is commonplace and promoted.
- Parental leave. Capital One recently extended it's PTO for both maternity and paternity leave and is an industry leader in the US private company space
- Extra benefits. Team fun events, occasional dinner/lunches at the office, and onsite gyms with optional PT sessions in Richmond, Plano, and Mclean were nice extras to have.
cons:
- Office locations. While some more tech/digital roles are moving to city center locations (e.g. Clarendon - closer to DC, San Francisco, and New York), it is a long commute if you work in McLean HQ and want to live in DC proper.
- Varying hours, without varying pay. Teams, work style, and hours differ depending on where you sit in the business and how time critical or significant work is. However, there isn't pay differentiation between a senior analyst in one role working 40 hours per week or one working 60 hours per week. Performance/bonus/promotions are more dependent on competencies and results.

pros: As my first job out of undergrad, I've found COF to be an excellent place to start a career.  As soon as you're able to show some ability, you're given a sizable area of ownership and influence.  Its not uncommon to folks six-months with the company to regularly be presenting to Sr Manager +.  Another benefit it lack of heavy-handed top-down management.  I have the feeling that leadership sets the direction and the associates are free to determine the most effective way to reach our goals.
cons: Really this is driven by the macro-environment, but I question the long-term sustainability of our company.  As a result of what looks to be a mid-term peak in credit & credit cards, increased regulation, and a looming recession, we will be forced to cut back on some of the things that have made the company great; total compensation, innovations, and fast growth

review_title: Great place to start a career
job_title: Principal Data Analyst in McLean, VA
pros:
- Good work-life balance. Depends on your team, but I have 35-45 hour weeks and work at home whenever I feel like it.
- Decent pay. Perhaps not the highest around, but you're well compensated for the amount of effort you put in. Richmond-based people can live like kings. Excellent 401k match.
- Smart and friendly people. The culture is pretty open - but see cons.
- Good cafeteria in McLean. Richmond's is worse.
- Very focused on development. Tech/finance skills are weighted equally with presentation/influence skills and you are strongly encouraged to work on these through practice and classes.
cons:
- Capital One is trying hard to become a tech company but not much is changing. Buzzwords abound but few understand what they mean (and they keep leaving). Some people work on innovative side projects, but the core work stays the same.
- Too many highly qualified people are stuck doing monotonous work.
- People can be too nice. Reluctance to openly criticize or flat-out reject a doomed project results in wasted time.
- Promotion/rating process is very secretive and results are sometimes surprising.

pros: Great benefits - ample paid time off, medical/dental, 401K. Work-life balance was better than other companies. The company values are admirable.
cons: The company culture is inconsistent and depends on which business unit you work in. I've had a positive experience working in some departments compared to others. The performance management process needs a complete overhaul and do not match the company's values. 360 feedback reviews are a political tick the box exercise and are a complete waste of time. Cross calibrations in some business units unfairly penalize certain positions if they do not fit into a standardized job description. Middle management is poorly trained in people skills and does not encourage career development, despite the encouragement from senior management (VP+). As a result, advancement is nearly impossible, based on favoritism, and is definitely not merit-based. Process change management requires multiple levels of red tape, is poorly executed, is extremely slow to implement. Pay was competitive up until about two years ago. It's now easier to advance and earn greater pay if you leave the company, which may explain why longtime employees are now leaving in droves.

job_title: Product Manager in Midtown Toronto, ON
pros:
I've been at Capital for a few years now and my three favorite things about it are:

1. The culture -  it's a work hard play hard, informal environment that centers around pushing associates to take full ownership of their space to drive value; there's also a big emphasis on career development, I've already played three different roles in my time here and I've always had the support and space to ramp up and learn.

2. The people - tied closely to the culture, this a big team who really rallies together for the sake of our customers; I've learned so much from my peers, team, managers, and leaders over the years: everything from tactical skills, to being an effective leader

3. The resiliency: the company has been growing a lot and with that comes a lot of change; the leadership team is not afraid to make bold transformations to meet the needs of the market and keep up with the industry; it's been a great experience being part of such big changes and watching them unfold over the years.
cons:
Of course, no place is perfect. 

At the end of the day, this is a big organization and with that comes  a little bit of difficulty in getting things done. It's definitely not as bad as other big organizations - specially in the financial industry - and it's something we are working to resolve. It does get better the more we try!
