review_title: Great place to enter corporate world and learn, but move on...
pros: Capital One has great Work Life Balance. You work long hours only if you wish to, or don't know how to manage work, or have a really bad manager, or a stupid single person who just graduated and does not have a sense of work-life balance.  One gets to learn new things at Capital One. Capital One really focuses on associates learning new skills (both hard and soft).  Some of the projects are really cool to work on.  Capital One also has good 401(k) package. Additionally, Richmond is a small city, cheap, affordable and trafiic is not bad.  If you have kids, Henrico county schools are one of the best in the nation.
cons: Lately, promotions have disappeared - its become more cut-throat and ploitical.  if you can't please your manager, simply move on to a new team or be prepared to suffer all along.  When I started, salaries were competitive, but in last few years raises don't even match inflation. To get a better raise and bonus, one needs better rating and due to forced curve, it has becoem difficult to get them.  Bonus for mid-level jobs have shrunk as they canceled Long Term Incentives.  Except for 401(k), other benefits are really bad, especially the health plans (person with a family pays close to $300/month with $3,000 deductible.)

pros: When I left Capital One, I was sure my new position would offer all the fulfillment I felt I was not getting.  It only took 6 months to realize what I had left behind.  Capital One genuinely allows employees to grow and become whatever they have the desire to be.  Its provides training and makes a concerted effort to help every associate be successful.  I miss the flexibility and growth potential I had.  I really miss the work-life balance!!  Capital One treats you like an adult, allows you to make decisions and be responsible for your team.  Management understands when you need to go to a school play or take an afternoon for a doctors appointment.  Moreover, they pay really well compared to the market.  It was after losing all the various benefits, did I realize how much they were truly worth.
cons: As with every company, there is politics and inept managers.  Unfortunately Capital One's performance process allows a lot more of that than there should be within such a dynamic organization.  I ended up leaving because of inept management and felt that I had no way to be successful in an organization I truly enjoyed being a part of.

review_title: Highly political, not a career, says one thing and does another
job_title: Director, Risk Management in Plano, TX
pros:
- Says the right things, right values
- Concerned about costs
- Lots of new,  young people are always around, and therefore it continues to feel entrepenurial and energetic. 
- No "old" folks.
cons:
- Everything they say and value does not matter.  The only thing that matters is your manager's rating of you which is only their perception of your results and you better hope that you know where you sit at all times and that your expectations are aligned at all times!  He/she can spin "performance management" and 360 feedback anyway they want.

- Don't stay here a day over the age of 40 unless you're a VP and you're staying put in your role that you've been in for at least 10 years.

- My manager was entirely unprofessional, made comments about my weight, my religion, and regularly threatened and bullied me.

- Antiquated performance management that is no longer practiced by Microsoft or GE.  They've both matured and moved on a few years ago, yet, sadly, Capital One holds onto this terrible practice.    It gives way to politics, backstabbing, insincerity, and to ultimately 'just a job'  instead of a career.  I can promise that sooner or later  this game of "spin the bottle"  will  land on you!

cons: Change in short term disability 3rd party--Fast forward 2016 I got sick again and the new company "Sedgwick" who deals with disability claims has been a nightmare causing additional strain by denying my claim and not paying. Currently I am out of work going on two months and without a paycheck to sustain my family. Needless to say this has caused additional stress and my doctor will not release me.

review_title: Frustrated by deeply ingrained financial institution culture; despite a lot of rhetoric to the contrary.
job_title: Senior Software Engineering Manager in McLean, VA
pros:
Plenty of capital resources. Lateral mobility. Upscale office designs. Flexible office schedules. Solid benefits.  Offices in several locations. 

You shouldn't have to worry if your paycheck will keep coming.
cons:
Very difficult to get ahead. Antiquated year end review process is designed to contain costs, not reward and retain performance and talent. Good people forced into lower bracket performance bands so target distributions are met. 

Way too much focus on perceptions.  Not enough focus on real business value. 

Very competitive environment results in people willing to submarine others for their own ambitions. Self imposed schedule pressure creates stress and diminishes quality. 

Organizational infighting. 

Way too much energy spent on recruiting instead of retention and training. 

Poor IT support often gets in the way of productivity. 

Too often, "more people" is the answer. When really, fewer, but better people would lead to superior results.  

Numerous facilities and space management issues.  You will likely move your desk at least once a year.

review_title: An alright place to be--but there are plenty of opportunities for improvement
pros:
-Pay is reasonable
-401k match is decent
-Management has generally been not overbearing/easy to work for and with
-Decent corporate culture
cons:
-Tuition reimbursement plan is pretty poor--seriously, Taco Bell pays up front and more per calendar year. Taco Bell.
-Management plays musical chairs every year leaving employees without a lot of direction until new management establishes goals and plans.
-Very evident that they take much advantage of the H1B Visa program to hire/underpay many foreign workers.
-Performance review process is poor, making managers fight for why their employee is better, and when added with musical management, I've had years where I've been reviewed by a manager I had for only two months of the previous year. Or have been reviewed by a manager who is no longer my manager--why would he fight for me?
-Benefits aren't anything special. 
-Raises are tiny when you are anywhere near the salary cap for your position. Salary cap isn't floated with cost of living.
-Social events (eg employee appreciate parties) are pretty poor. Related perks (eg they sponsor lots of stadiums) are pretty non-existent.
-Not lots of opportunities for promotion within.

pros:
- Great pay
- Great benefits
- Love the Richmond campus and the new M2 building
- Some really smart people
cons:
- Management doesn't understand basic Product techniques 

- Performance Management is forced distribution and is based on your manager's opinion (not your work or success or anything else you have done) of you. Your goals and performance are not usually even mentioned in calibrations. Your reviews are political and only people who play politics really well get promoted.

- Product at Capital One CC basically consists of people who are trained as Business Analysts being Product Managers without any training in most cases. In some cases, the people who "train" the analysts on Product are themselves former Business Analysts who also don't fully understand product. 

- Tech teams are evaluated on points completed

- While agile, design thinking, etc are talked about, those techniques are not followed. Agile is only used for tech teams (not the full process).

Commitment to improvement.

Can be a bit hit and miss dependant on the department you work for.  Those departments which can deliver revenue growth are seen as sexy, whereas as those areas tasked with loss mitigation can be a far tougher environment and have lower employee engagement.

In some areas it is still target driven, which is positive in terms of focus, but the mindset in some areas is not necessarily about doing right just getting an outcome and can be highly competitive. This does lead in some cases to games at associate level to try the teflon approach to divert blame which can be counter productive to good teamwork.

Whilst it is evident that there has been investment in systems to assist employees these are not necessarily optimised.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in McLean, VA
pros: As a Business Analyst Capital One was a fun place to work. Typically, people are quite approachable and talkative. You are quite flexible in your own schedule as long as you get the work done. I liked being able to work from home when I didn't have any meetings. Capital One has a good reputation for being analytically advanced especially for credit risk management.
cons: The senior management is mostly experienced analysts and not the best strategic thinkers so you may often find yourself being pulled into working on some detail which may have no value for the business. Similarly, there may happen large organizational changes which may not make any sense but you just follow it because you are told so. Finally, especially during the past few years due to worsening credit environment there has been a number of budget cuts so a lot of the free perks disappeared.

pros:
I like the people I work with and people are willing and help and support each other.  The vision of  moving to new/open source technologies, Cloud and MicroServices makes sense.

The work life balance if great and I think it's one of the reasons much of the tech staff has been patient but that's waining
cons:
The re-org that took place in order to move teams onto new technology platforms was needed but with the change getting drug out over 6 months it was the most poorly executed change I've seen.  

The company is using the stack ranking approach that Microsoft abandoned after much churn last year.  The end result is you could be doing stellar work but 

* if your manager isn't politically connected your chance of getting a good bonus is slim
* If your manager is shy or lays back you won't get the bonus you should
* Your manager can only hold up a limited number of names so if they have too many they won't be holding you up for a good bonus


And my favorite (encountered this year)
* If you changed managers once or twice during the year the manager at the end doesn't need to incorporate feedback or scoring from previous managers so you don't get the bonus you should.

I went to talk with someone who has been here a long time.  Her response was that yes, this isn't uncommon and you just have to find a different manager.

pros: COF is populated with very smart people who are driven to create leading edge results. Total cash compensation is excellent, although base is a bit lower than average.  Leadership is very understanding of employees who need time off for family reasons or other personal reasons.  Benefits are fairly good with a broad range of educational assistance, adoption benefits and even a two-week paid paternity leave. There is a high acceptance of people of color and LGBT staff. People are thoroughly screened before hiring to ensure as much as possible that they will be successful in this fast-paced, demanding culture. Women occupy many key leadership positions. The Richmond West Creek campus is beautiful.
cons: Culture is quite unforgiving...very PC.   Long hours and stress to create quickly with no mistakes can take their toll--this is not a company for those lacking confidence. In the current climate for financials, middle and upper middle managers are interested in showing their worth by cutting headcount while driving remaining staff to do more with less.  As a whole the company is obsessed with speed and a six-sigma type approach to creation. Insofar as performance measurement goes, many times a person's "behaviors" as listed in in process counts far more than their results. In the past five years, the company has become far less nurturing.

review_title: Very depressing place to work regardless of the benefits!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tampa, FL
pros: Benefits, schedule flexibility, paid training at regular salary.
cons: The type of work is beyond depressing, its a call center no matter how the company tries to tell you that its totally different than any other call center. Being monitored constantly especially when dealing with angry or upset customers most of the time is just not worth the decent pay and benefits. The software used to handle customer accounts is very flawed and so is the process used to carry out certain customers requests such as credit limit increases. Employees are not given any information to explain everything needed to customers, making them angry most of the time. Just sitting in the chair all day taking calls is too depressing, definitely the worst job I have had and I understand why they try to pay decent and offer benefits because the job is so depressing! Also it seems like advancement to manager or CAT is based heavily on social factors instead of merits. The company claims to have customers service on par with Discover and Amex, but the in-call requirements and structure required to receive high quality scores completely prevents an agent from having any shot at replicated the magnificent customer service received with Discover and Amex. I have both cards so I know first hand.

review_title: Great pay, good benefits, no security and competitive culture
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Capital One facilities are great places to work with many ammenities.  The pay is high for the Richmond area and the benefits are better/as good as any other company around.
cons: The culture is now of a BIG bank and they now have lost the culture that originally drove folks to apply.  The performance management system is rigid, political and competitive to a fault (I am a high-performing associate, but don't like how it works - good people get screwed over).  There are continual cuts every year, and it seemingly is targeting long-time/older folks in the workforce.  A ton of experience has been redeployed from the company over the years.  There is a move to Mclean, DL, and Chicago for jobs, so Richmond has the most limited hiring, which limits your options for growth.  You WILL work REALLY hard for that salary and more and more folks are logging in to work more hours late at night and on the weekends to keep up.

Since they were all once VP and Senior Directors and now were demoted to Managers as a part of acquisition, they think no one should be promoted or raised. They are actually fighting for lower pay for their people (yes-fighting) when HQ is raising you pay. They are blocking everyone from promotion or internal transfer as they are now severely demoted and feel it's unfair to have similar job level as them. 
Interviewing for former HSBC management?  Move on...

review_title: CapitalOne is an awesome company to work for. They care so much about their customers.
pros: They are customer service oriented, they care a lot about their employees and they treat us well. Their training is the best because the first two days you get to travel to the corporate office and train there and meet upper management. Lunch was on them for those days, they treated us well and gave us very good information on the history of the company. Then we train at a training center for 9 days and we learn the whole system and policies and procedures. We practice a lot so we can get it by the time we get to our branch. After this week then we will shadow at another branch to see how they do it. The life balance is great 9-5 job and on Saturdays 9-1 and no Sundays, so it is great. The time off is awesome, we get 4 weeks per year for the first four years and we also get 10 paid holidays off in the year. So much opportunities to grow within the company, just be great at your job and they will provide you with everything you need to transfer to another department or promotion.
cons: There is absolutely nothing that is bad about this company, they are just awesome in every way they continue deliver on their promises to their employees.

job_title: Financial Advisor in New York, NY
pros: Not too many...401(k) match is nice.  National Capital One Investing program is striving to make it a formal program with focus on holistic financial planning.
cons: Local management in New York City region.  Local managers treat program like a boiler room.  Name recognition is not a plus.  Prospects and bank customers accustomed to Capital One as a credit card company.  Very difficult to get clients to take you seriously enough to get all their assets.  Heavy favoritism on the part of local management whose cronies/favorites are inexperienced advisors.  Favorites who are grandfathered into company get and keep all clients except those with little to no opportunity (i.e. don’t live in area).  Constant churning and wrong recommendations from less-experienced advisors who only focus on assets they see at the bank (as opposed to considering/profiling for outside assets and full financial planning) and happen to be the favorites so they can pad their numbers.  Clients mysteriously move from your book to theirs.  Exact opposite of what National Investment program is saying/trying to do in a fiduciary capacity.  New advisors in program are treated like they are in a wirehouse program.  If so, why work at Capital One?  Work at a real wirehouse with some name recognition.

review_title: Great advancement opportunities, but competitive culture can cause headaches.
pros: Flexible work arrangements provide flexibility for parents.  Other than health care (expensive) the benefits package is pretty good.  Has nice plusses like paid maternity/paternity leave and generous 401k matching.  There is generally a lot of focus on associate development and training.  Great place to be if you are still fairly early into your career as advancement opportunities seem to be concentrated at the lower levels (below director).
cons: Competitive culture, and in some cases fragile egos.  Depending on job level, performance bonuses may comprise a good portion of the employees total yearly compensation.  Some (but certainly not all) departments measure individual performance in such a way as to create resistance to any change in the status quo.  In these scenarios, employees become more obsessed with protecting their compensation rather than advancing the business.  These types will do anything to avoid being associated with weaknesses in the business, which prevents weaknesses from being improved.   Compensation follows preset distributions, so performance ratings and promotions may or may not be reflective of an individual’s actual contributions depending upon how many people the department has.

review_title: Used to be better - now mostly awful
pros: Decent benefits, good pay for Richmond, subsidized food on campus
cons: Capital one used to be a great place to work - most old timers can agree on that. In more recent years they seem to have lost their way. Coherent, integrated strategy is lacking. Performance management focuses only on results and bright shiny objects. Managers have a cursory knowledge of how to effectively manage people, and leadership is lacking all around. Some departments are hiring only externally and ignoring internal candidates in favor of fresh blood. Ironically, this hasn't done much to improve the quality or speed of products coming out, nor has it helped overall morale. Most people I know here are smart, capable and deeply unhappy - they see it as a means to an end. A lot are trapped as this is one of the top employers in Richmond. This will change over the years as new companies start to move to town, but evolution here is slow. The people who are the most successful here are the ones most willing to play the game and play at the expense of others in many cases. A lot of senior management has been here since the beginning of time, and this is all they know.

review_title: Good Company but losing Strategic Vision
pros: The company is very laid back generally speaking and strives on trying to keep you happy.  Great PTO ( 5 weeks after 5 years non-exempt/ 4 weeks exempt)  Salary is good if you negotiate correctly coming in.
cons: The whole strategy with Mortgage Banking has been a complete failure due to not hiring the best and most experienced talent. Also not listening to experienced professionals and overspending from the reincarnation in 2009 caused this as well.  Capital One's claim is they are a digital company but this does not translate to many lines of business i.e.,  mortgage banking and even Small Business for that matter. Many processes are still very paper driven and disorganized even after spending millions of dollars on systems that didn't work. Unfortunately,  President of Financial Services Sanjiv Yajnik has a lot of blame for this mortgage division collapse. Leadership changes and remapping of strategic goals should have occurred years before.  A one fits all approach doesn't work in every business.  I do hope with a possible liquidation and  selloff of certain lines of business to a forward thinking company will help Capital One refocus on the markets it strives in.

review_title: Changing Banking For Good? I think not!
job_title: Technical Support Coordinator in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Decent starting base pay and good bonus/incentive structure. Good Aetna benefits. Direct management seems to be caring but never seems to have opportunities to help as much as they would like.
cons: Training doesn't adequately equip phone reps for things they will actually encounter on a daily basis. There are a lot of questions the training staff cannot answer. Team/unit managers are rarely able to give actual tips and guidance. The bank itself seems to do more harm than good regarding essential aspects for its customers (i.e. giving customers beneficial and accurate information at the branch level). The website and mobile app have constant issues but there seems to be no qualified employees in place to make timely fixes. Certain departments are expected to go above and beyond and do the job of other departments quite frequently, without compensation. The company takes more stock in "metrics" and telephone software numbers than the actual performance and contributions of the employee.

review_title: Great company to grow you career
pros: It is extremely difficult to get into Capital One but when you do there are few barriers to entry across different job families.  If you are smart, can problem solve and deliver results you can be successful across multiple job families.  They are not afraid to give you big opportunities and projects just be prepared that you need to then step up and deliver.  While not a ton of formal training you will be exposed to a variety of tools and techniques in everyday work that will be beneficial to you both at Capital One and at any company you work for in the future.
cons: Org changes and leadership changes are frequent and while lower levels are insulated from the changes the higher you are the more disruptive the changes.  The company is full of talented individuals who inherently think they have a better way which leads to big changes from leader to leader most of the time.  Perception of promotions is that they are slow unless you are on the big project with the highly influential leader and then things tend to move much quicker.  I do think the company does a good job of identifying top talent for promotions but that leaves those not in the top 5-10% frustrated with the process.  Leverage your top talents and find a senior advocate and you will do great.

review_title: Wonderful company with very talented people, leadership, and great culture
job_title: Technology Development Program in McLean, VA
pros:
- Incredibly mature internship program.  I had a great experience as a TDP intern and that only continued in full time.
- In Technology at least, really talented staff.  In my current role, I get to see a lot of other Fortune 500 tech departments - Capital One's is heads and shoulders above every other one with regards to culture, unified vision, and abilities.  Very youthful energy.
- Super benefits, 401k match is great, above average vacation, employee stock purchase program
- No babysitting in my experience (YMMV) and not a tech sweat shop - I clocked out at or just under 40 hours nearly every week.
- Invested in your growth - whatever you need from certifications to video lessons is provided.
- I found it to be an inclusive environment.  I have a disability and never felt like I would be punished for my bad days.
cons:
- No office in the city I wanted to move back to :(
- Promotion system is too much about how many people will stick up for you in cross calibrations from past interactions rather than your actual delivery.  Had talented coworkers get absolutely screwed because their roles weren't as customer-facing.

pros:
1. Good Work life balance
2. Good Pay
3. Benefits
4. Perks
5. Good Teams
6. Good learning opportunities -  sometimes you will be without any work for few months altogether, that gives you ample time to skill up,  though there will be no opportunities to work on what you learn
cons:
1. Constant Re-Orgs
2. Lack of clear direction from leadership
3. People with technical skills are not rewarded, people with social skills skyrocket in their career
4. Lack of good technical intents, be prepared to sit idle most of the time until leadership tries to get intent (am a java dev, but last year i did manual testing for most part and 0 API or microservice work)
5. Layoffs here and there, and no clear career path direction (all API teams were converted to mobile teams in chicago downtown, by teaching android and IOS development - you have 6 years of technical experience in one area, so what??  start from 0 now)

The card division had worsened over the years. Politics had taken root in the culture. From being a fair and progressive company, the place had become a joke. 
The management selects a bunch of individuals based on perception and then gives them a free pass to success. The selection is purely based on perception rather than true results. The place was hell bent on showing how open it is to certain historically disadvantaged groups and gave favorable benefits to them inspite of work not upto the mark.  (Hint: if you are from such groups might not be a bad idea to join )
Promotions especially to the dir level make no sense, its purely driven by who "likes" you!

pros:
- The pay is generally in the top 25% for the industry.

- They usually promote from within.
cons:
- The bureaucracy is far crazier than anything I've seen in any other company.  It can be very difficult to get through the red tape and get things done.  Half of the people who work here are there to prevent the other half from doing their jobs.

- They hire smart people, but most of them don't have any other experience.  So they only know the Capital One way of doing things.  They're convinced this is always the best way.

- High Potential Program.  There is an official "high potential" program they arbitrarily choose people and treat them differently.  This creates a bit of a self fulfilling prophecy, but more importantly breeds resentment.

- There is a weak approach to expense management.  As a result.  Most of the office is traveling at any given time even though they don't need to be.  People will habitually fly from Toronto to Richmond Virginia for a single short meeting.  People go on trips simply because they are young and like to travel.

- Some members of senior management are religious fundamentalists and it shows.

review_title: Worst decision in my professional career
job_title: Senior Brand Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, 401k and vacation options.  The corporate heads have a great vision & great ideas.
cons:
No appreciation for employees, the vision gets lost the further down the chain you go.  There are way too many politics at play.  They do not value long time employees.  I've seen employees who have been with the company for 40+ years transferred to another location and then the branch closes & the employee laid off.  They lay off employees when they close a location,  employees are encouraged to apply internally, but are rarely hired.  Capital One is looking to going "digital" so they want very few branches, so that mean very few employees, so if you want a company for the long haul, avoid here!  They make big promises to get you on board and then there is no follow thru.  In my 4 years, I've seen so much turnover, everyone below the CEO to me has changed.  I've had 5 different managers in less than 4 years.  
I've seen older employees pressured and pushed out and managers advised to push older people out In favor of younger employees.  

There is very little career growth.  Every person above me who was hired the past 4 years was external and very few people promoted, the ones who have been promoted have been "in" with leadership.

pros: Capital One has great overall benefits--Flex Spending, PTO, 401 k match, etc. The company is performance based, so metrics are very important and key to you being able to earn more money through salary increases, monthly/annual bonuses,  and promotions. I could go on and on about how wonderful it was working for this company.
cons: In my case, the biggest con would be the Year End Appraisal process. Depending on the business group you work in, you are stack ranked based on your job level with people with different job functions that may not have anything to do with what you do, For example people manager vs process manager vs operations analyst. There is a rigorous calibration process across different sites/locations to determine what your Year End Appraisal will be. Which is unfair as many of the decision makers may not know you or know what you do as they are a in a different business unit. It's left up to your manager to convince them how great you are.

review_title: Good pay, horrible environment and incompetent mgt
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Glen Allen, VA
pros: They pay is very competitive, as good or better than most other IT places (at least in the central VA area), though not by a huge margin.  Their West Creek "campus" is a nice place to work, facilities-wise.
cons:
Management, mostly; it's a joke.  They swap contractors in and out in this perpetual revolving door, treating them like 2d class citizens (if even human beings at all).  Worse, they're constantly shuffling positions, cutting them short out of the blue, laying off people one minute and hiring the next.  Further, most managers and even some of the more veteran staff are very stand-offish, with their little cliques and nothing in the way of genuine friendliness to outsiders coming in - again only barely enough for CYA purposes.  To them, "team spirit" is nothing more than annoying cliche they give a little lip service to, if that.  

It is - by FAR - both the least stable and "coldest" place I have ever worked.  The little extra money one might (might) get working there is not worth the stress of working at a place you hate - and unless you get REALLY lucky, you'll hate it, trust me.

pros: Work-life balance; Facilities far above average, (with the exception of Wilmington) benefits are above average; retail bank presence is strong.  Exec management communicates frequently.
cons:
The constant  change is somewhat ridiculous. Hire, layoff, recruit for new positions, hire, layoff, recruit for new positions and change senior management - seems like this is done quarterly. Previous ING folks seem to take precedence. The merger happened over 2 years ago and they still talk "ING" language.  Newsflash - ING in the US is Capital One - get used to it.  So many duplicate positions.  Card Services remain the "golden child" and typically run separate from the rest of the organization.  Training and Talent development is awful - the worst I have ever seen.  They lack consistency and fail to build solid relationships within the organization.  

Sr (Exec Mgt) does communicate frequently - town halls, etc.  Done particularly in Richmond and McLean. Most communications will never disclose anything but positive or good news about the enterprise - very filtered so as to believe it is a perfect company.  Very "Virginia" based. Other locales are felt like outcasts. 
Technology far behind banks of their size.  Salary scale somewhat lower than banks their size as well.

review_title: Great Company With A Lacking Culture
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Working at Capital One was honestly a breath of fresh air compared to a number of other financial call centers and how they interacted with their customer base. There was more of a focus on customer satisfaction and resolution rather than sales or time spent on a phone. Supervisor roles were given great autonomy to take care of phone agents with customer concerns as well as develop needed work skills to attain new or promoted positions within the company. The people were always amazing to see and you really felt like the people you worked with were a second family.
cons: The major downside I had with Capital One is that they have an almost forced culture of doing the right thing and being encouraged to promote new ideas/concerns to company leadership. This all sounded good to the front line/customer facing associates, but rarely anything was ever done with agent feedback or ideas and simply stowed away for tracking purposes. Reasons that action was rarely taken was a lack of resources within certain departments or more often than not self serving interests of senior leadership did not feel the proposed feedback was important or necessary at that time.

Those who have inexperienced, or ineffective managers are lost in the shuffle of a major corporation. review_title: Have to take the good with the bad here.
pros: Capital One has a great benefits program and they do promote work/life balance. You get work from home days regularly in back office jobs. They also promote community service and giving back which I like a lot.
cons: Work/life balance is hard to achieve with long hours and work phones. You feel like you’re always attached to the job. The company in general doesn’t live by their own values (do the right thing). Lots of gaps and areas of improvement. Middle management is terrible (micro managers or completely incompetent) and upper management is completely out of touch with levels under them. Performance management needs to be completely revamped. Employees are rated more on defined “competencies” than actual metrics of performance. These “competencies” are things like communication or influence which are completely subjective and at your managers discretion. Basically you can be terrible at your job but if your manager likes you, you can get promoted. Also, management for the most part is a “good ol boys” club and lacks diversity - mainly women or dare I say it....women with families.

pros: Work from home.  Decent pay and vacation, but needed every day of it plus more.
cons: Seniority means nothing.  They hire outside the company instead of promoting within.  Once you are in a schedule you can not get off of it.  The new hires get a better schedule than the tenured employees.  If you want to go part time, they tell you no, but they hire new employees part time.  Sure you can post for a new job, but you have to apply like you are a new employee with resume and interview.  They will not look at prior work history.  When they do post a new opening, it is only because they have to and you are just wasting your time, they already know who they want for the opening.  Like they say...It is who you know to get off of the phone, they have favorites.  Stressful and micro management.

review_title: Great place to work and grow if you can get past the business model
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Toronto, ON
pros: Capital One was unparalleled in terms of the work-life balance: employees up to the VP level would regularly leave at 4:00 pm to pick up kids from work, leave for classes, or make an appointment. The internal coding courses offered were an incredible way to get relevant, foundational technical skills that you could practice day-to-day. The role I was in was fairly challenging although the cyclical nature of the work meant that things would get repetitive past the 1-year mark. Fortunately the rotation program allows almost anyone to switch teams and experience a new role within the company.
cons: Capital One's only real con to me was its unsavory business model. While the mission was to "Change Banking for Good", looking at the financials usually painted the picture of profiting off poor people and new immigrants off of interest and high fees. While this does not affect the genuinely great day-to-day work environment, there is a pill that should be explicitly swallowed when considering the societal value that is created at large.

You had a good thing going here but ruined it by letting petty office politics win, when true talent goes unnoticed.

pros:
Capital One showed little hesitation to hire from a temp-worker pool, and frequently offered resources for advancement, including help to get licensed in the industry. Opportunities were often open to change departments for those who wanted to leave Customer Service.

The pay for an entry-level position was strong, and systems were in place to recognize associates with merit raises annually.

Company culture was fun and engaging; we had special events every 6-8 weeks and set aside one week a year for team-building and challenges within our department.

Capital One allowed me to add a partner to my health benefits package, despite the fact that we are not married.
cons:
Some business decisions have been puzzling. The company has decided to functionally close its office where I work and move cross-country. As a result, they are letting go many people who have more than 5 years of experience.

Certain issues my department raised got little attention or exposure. Some projects seemed to be in the pipeline for years before finally being released, despite their clear benefit. Top-down decisionmaking sometimes led to poor customer experiences.

pros: Treat this place as a university . Learn new technologies to put in your resume and use this place as your stepping stone.
cons:
1. Work pressure. No work life balance. Managers tell you that you should not work after 5 PM. But on the other hand, you have unrealistic deadlines. Agile is out of picture. Work is taken in chunks and divided into sprints. PO says “we have to deliver this in this many sprints”. In office hours, we have tons of meetings and no room for actual work. This leaves no choice and you end up working from home after office hours.
2. Office politics - corruption, bias, favoritism at its peak.
3. Incompetent managers and peers who are waiting for you to finish your work and then steal it and showcase as their own piece of art. After work is done, manager will say you didn’t do anything great. You are hired to do this. Everyone else is doing the same. What are you doing extra??
4. No freedom to be yourself - just pretend you like Capital one in front of your manager. 
5. Team work vs individual performance management - all year, mobbing is enforced and people who want to take up something on their own are blamed in the retrospectives. At the end of year, no one knows who did the actual work. Only manager’s favorite guy gets the promotion. The least favorite might even end up losing their job.
6. Idiotic meetings - two hours of useless meetings to come up with some points on blah blah which is not helpful in any actual work.

pros: Good technologies, Nice office/campus, learning opportunities.
cons: Performance management is the worst part, where people recognized how much they talk and how good the relationship you have with management. You can talk like, I can create a diamond from the air, and talk it loud and talk the same, though that is not possible in real and you will be recognized.  Ineffective game-players can get a better rating than people who work hard and dedicated.  And they might put you in coaching plan, if you are in the lower bucket, learn how to make a diamond from the air. And if your manager doesn't like you, because you don't go every day and say good morning, then you are in bad luck. People may smile at you all the time, but they will not hesitate to give bad feedback for the mistake you have not done which might be interpreted as you did it. One of my friend told one day... "here snakes are everywhere", which makes perfect sense. If you want to work in a friendly environment, where people treat each other in (not fake)compassion, this is not the place. You may get some money/benefits, but not worth the quality of time you are spending with your colleague.

review_title: A good place to work but...
pros: The benefits package very good.  There is also deliberate attempt to keep the work & life balance manageable.  A very diverse company with lots of people from different backgrounds and many of women in senior positions.  A very positive company with incredibly passionate employees.
cons: I start at Capital One about 6 months before the big change last year. The move to the Branch Ambassador role has eliminated all traditional branch roles.  This makes progression opportunities difficult, as there is no clear route to take.  Formerly there were different levels of Banker, lead tellers/assistant managers etc., now we work in a sort of socialism where everyone is equal and no progression in bank .  Company is pushing towards a digitalized future with associates presently encouraging customers to DIY bank by using online apps and using ATMs over tellers etc.  This make the employee wonder where this leaves them after this transition complete.  Capital One claims to be a bank modelling itself as a tech company, but it is has many technology problems and too many software program to perform simple jobs.  Company focuses on feelings and emotions (values) more than address what customer wants.

review_title: A Bank that Doesn't Feel Like A Bank
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in McLean, VA
pros:
Capital One's forward-thinking, development-focused culture is the main selling point, in my opinion. The company is made up intelligent, driven associates who are supported by a management team that is committed to engaging them as humans, not just employees. The focus on growth is tangible, and it makes all the difference.

Another point that stands out is the willingness to take risks and learn from failure. The party line is that, if you never fail, you aren't trying hard enough, and this is taken into account when evaluating performance. 

All in all, when most people imagine what it's like to work at a bank, they imagine a scene out of "Office Space" or the beginning part of "Fight Club" before things get weird. Capital One is lightyears away from that stereotype. It feels more like a technology company than a bank, more akin to Google than Goldman.
cons: Because we're in such a heavily regulated industry, there are a ton of governance tasks and checks and balances. It can sometimes feel like you spend a large amount of your time cutting through red tape. This isn't such a big deal most days though.

pros:
Capital One is a fantastic place to work due to the environment. Managers are really flexible with where and how you work through the future of work program.

People are encouraged to apply for different positions every few years to build their respective skill set. The company has a significant amount of very smart people.

Managers are encouraged to have 10:10's meetings atleast monthly to discuss your performance. 

Benefits and the work-life balance are well above average.
cons:
Many of Capital One's pros also result in the cons. The hiring process is geared toward hiring highly ambitious and intelligent people. This results in a very competitive environment where people are backstabbing and stepping on others to get ahead. 

The highly PC environment results in a lack of honesty/integrity and a reluctance to hold people accountable. People have a high degree of academic and business intelligence, but emotional intellligence / social skills are lacking.

The performance evaluation process is highly suspect as it force ranks people in the same departments at the same level. Some groups have a high level of performance and great employees while others are worthless.

Many people do not provide any value add to the company. TOO MANY CHIEFS...

review_title: Great company with great people, need more focus on defining strategy.
pros: Great education and training opportunities. Very associate centered culture, strong desire to be a good corporate citizen and 'win' in the market. There are a lot of great people who are professional and open to collaborating.
cons:
Ivory tower syndrome in upper management who often have selective perception regarding input from lower level staff. Lots of stress in middle management; which is the result of the daily changing strategy and the expectation of knowing what the flavor of the day is without being told. Constantly changing agenda/strategy. 
 The rating is determined in management calibration sessions which rate your performance against everyone else at your same level (not job title). So if someone at your level has gone above and beyond (which always occurs), this then creates the standard for which you should've followed. This makes it impossible to set goals and be confident that if you've met them you've performed well, since you are ranked against your peers not against goals set by you and your manager. This process leads to less teamwork and knowledge sharing and more individualism. Technology is lacking and in some ways is less than the industry standard.
Lack of communication from upper-level management.

review_title: Pretty Campus, Poor Exec Leadership, Performance Mgmt system a joke
pros: Benefits are nice, campus is pretty
cons: Can't call yourself a progressive company, and retain a rank and yank performance management system from 3 decades ago.

pros: Amazing benefits and competitive pay
cons: Heavy workload at times. Nothing too hectic though.

pros: Great company to work for.
cons: Never ending transformation and changing targets

review_title: Capital One is satisfying but not outstanding....
job_title: Bank Teller in San Antonio, TX
pros: The best reasons to work for Capital One would be the benefits package offered to full and part time. The benefits package includes medical, dental, vision, and 401k. Capital One also has a tuition reimbursement plan for full time and part time staff. The starting salary of an entry level teller compared to other banks is higher and there are incentive plans for tellers as well. The attitude of the workplace and staff is easy going and because, I think, Capital One as a bank is still fairly new, it has a small town bank feel and a slower pace associated with it.
cons: Due to the current economic situation, there is little upward mobility and not many new branches being opened at this time (2nd Qtr. 2009). Because of this, there are not many positions opened at this time for entry level or upper level positions. There are little to no full time teller positions available at branches and part time is usually about 30 hours. And due to the scheduling of bank hours, this usually means that a person probably could not pick up a second job.

job_title: Manager, Project Management in Plano, TX
pros: Great employee benefits, flexible work schedules (depending on the position), bright open work environment and extensive development opportunities via Capital One's internal Capital One University.
cons: Capital One is constantly changing the organizational structure which can leave many employees either moving around ALOT, or pushed out of a job. I was lucky during many of the changes because I was valuable to the business in my role, however the constant changes leave you looking over your shoulder. The environment is also very difficult to advance in. I chose to leave after applying for a role above my "title", got offered the position, however was advised by HR that due to company policy I would have to accept the new position laterally with no pay increase or title change. I had enough so I went somewhere else to get my promotion.

review_title: Great overall culture, but not immune from some negative pockets
pros:
Development Programs
Especially the Analyst Development Program
4 weeks of 'training' (more like summer camp for business geeks) over a year allow friendships and networks to develop
Those running the program are very receptive to feedback and actively seek it out

The company in general is very good to its main office employees (not so much contractors, call center workers etc)
Quarterly fun days are great team-building and general fun
Cheap Gym
Multiple subsidized cafeterias
on-site clinic
on-site bank (which should really be expected given that they're a bank)
free career counseling
generous severance forewarning and pay
free job search services after termination
cons:
Leadership of my customer department
Would often jump to conclusions before getting data (the company is actively against that sort of thinking, but it happened)
Officially rewards the value of work produced over effort put into it, but in reality a bigger emphasis on looking like you're working hard

review_title: Great place to start your career, workload can get tough though
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Wonderful teammates, easy place to make friends in a new city
- Emphasis on data-driven decision-making, great place to pickup technical and analytical skills in a world that increasingly values these things
- Tech stack is getting better, unlocking opportunities for more product-like work
- Lots of smart and motivated people to work with, I've rarely/never felt like I had to carry the team. I always felt supported by hard workers
cons:
- Workload can be very high during deadlines due to: tech migration, regulations, contract renewals/negotiations, internal mandates
- Workload varies heavily by team
- Different leaders have very different styles, and different teams have different pressures - with some you'll learn great technical expertise but feel stressed most of the time, with others you'll learn great leadership skills but less opportunity to develop on technical skills
- There is sometimes bureaucracy - your project may not fit your development goals, or a big project may get stalled for a variety of reasons
- There can be a general sense of under-staffing, or commitment on projects, leading to high workload and stress

pros: Good pay and great work culture
cons: Working long hours can be hard

pros: Good pay and great work culture
cons: Working long hours can be hard

pros: Good company overall, nice perks
cons: A lot of layoffs and job eliminations

job_title: Home Equity Account Manager in Plano, TX
pros: Flexible staff and competitive pay
cons: There weren’t really any cons to this place!

review_title: Capital Takes good care of employees, but middle management is lacking training and support.
pros: Work life balance can be quite good at time. Also the people who work there are very smart. There is a strong focus on learning and growing within the company. If you find a good team and good work it can be fantastic
cons: In general people are not responsible for the outcomes of their work. There is a real lack of connection between what we produce and what actually happens. Additionally, your success will largely be determined by the specific projects you are assigned to. As it is a bit of an experimental business, many of these will fail. So a really good analyst can get screwed because his project doesn't work while a poor analyst may succeed beyond imagination.

review_title: Great Company, Extremely poor People management
pros: The IT Platform is great, leadership does go after most of the right things with regard to software, hardware, procedures. Work-life balance is also okay. While compensation is not as great as other companies I have been at or know of, perks such as low cost Fitness Center in basement, free parking, ability to work from home, cell phone and data plan for certain managers all combine to make a nice package.
cons: People management is where Capital One loses in a big way. Quite a few managers that I worked with do not know how to coach, provide feedback and help grow and retain resources. There is also a lack of "common culture" across managers and directors. For example, completely different messages are given by different managers/VPs/Directors about dress code or if a child can be brought in if school / day care is closed unexpectedly, Agile processes. Capital One is big on BSAs for every Agile Team and this causes significant confusion: Who owns creation of Stories, Acceptance Criteria - the BSA or team members or Product Owner.

review_title: Where Did They Find These Managers
pros: Let me think about this and get back to you
cons:
My manager soon to be X-manager they must have picked him from the bottom of the barrel. Yes, this is true and I am not kidding. I took my issues with this person to HR rep. And it went on deaf ears. This person tore apart the structure of the team and hired all new people and fired nearly everyone else just to save $. I guess the old employees were too much $.  I never saw this manager EVER work even 8 hours a day - totally unplugged could care less about anyone on the team except número uno. Even after I went to HR multiple times, they did nada. And now the loser manager is leaving cap one. And in the process has literally destroyed the team. All I have to say is I am SO glad I don't do ANY business with this company. YES I mean it!
The net result of POOR management is the customer suffers. And that frankly is why I don't do any business with this company. I really wanted this to be the company that everyone one wants to work for but frankly was so naïve. This company must have bought its way to the list of Forbes 100 best companies. Because, if it was a good place to work there would be procedures in place to protect an employee from an unethical manager.

pros:
- Co-workers and managers are all knowledgeable and friendly.
- Campus facilities are great
- Benefits are top-notch (BCBS Health, BCBS Vision, Delta Dental, 401(k), stock purchase program, training, bonuses, unlimited sick time in addition to PTO, + more)
- On-site health clinic available to employees and their immediate family
- Active community volunteering participation
- Campus is environmentally conscious with recycling bins throughout
- Fun campus amenities include ping pong tables, Foosball tables, video game console lounges, coffee shops, tree house, comfortable outdoor seating in relaxing environment, putt putt golf course, softball field, sand volleyball courts 
- Great food selections in on-campus cafeterias daily including subsidized healthy choices to encourage good health through food choices
cons:
- Computing environment is constantly changing due to acquisitions, consolidation, upgrades, and decommissions of systems, networks, and applications.
- Turnover in smaller, acquired banking locations can occasionally be sudden as management decides which locations to keep and which to shut down.
- Hiring process is long, drawn-out, and rigorous (but this helps to ensure a good team, so it's not really a con from the perspective of the inside)

review_title: Great place to work, but unstable. Be ready to jump from depart. to depart. to survive.
pros: great benefits, awesome bonuses, deluxe people, cool stock plans, honorable 401K, flexible hours, superb bonuses
cons:
Reorganizations are volatile / Unstable – Reogs are so frequent that you don’t know if you are going to come in and have a job or not.  One example: They’ve dissolved a plethora of departments that are in one state, due to upper management being located elsewhere.  These departments have been stationed at their locations well before the new management had taken over.  This is a complete disregard of their employees’ livelihood. 

Upper Management Favoritism - With some managers mainly the ones who were brought in with companies Capital One bought, its not what you know it’s who you know.

Competitiveness – Management seems to have forgotten that we are all with the same company, working on the same team. The reorganizations are having teams try to cancel each other out just to survive reorgs.

review_title: Was a good place to work until...
pros: Great benefits and flex time with option to work remote (depending on team)
cons:
End of year reviews (performance reviews)  are a joke - you're put on bell curve with a 1-5 rating against your team and extended team!  They basically compare and evaluate you with everyone on your team and in your department so a Help Desk engineer gets pitted against a senior level engineer which is completely unfair.  Thats like comparing a doctor to a garbage man in terms of skill. Really? Not only that, your bonus and career trajectory suffers because of this. Managers and senior level associates get credit for your successes which helps them , not you. 

Company is going through lay offs like crazy - be warned. Full time employment is nice but once the projects are over, you can say good bye. Capital One is automating everything.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Arlington, VA
pros: Good learning and extremely nice facilities
cons: Politics, no innovation and management sometimes is ruthless

pros: Beautiful facility, extremely nice people,
cons: Very political, Bureaucratic, A lot of make work.

pros: They care about their employees
cons: No advancement within the department

review_title: Despite some tough times in the past, a great place to work.
pros: I really believe that Capital One hires smart people.  That doesn't necessarily mean that they are enjoyable to work with but the average person there "gets it" in my opinion.  There is a lot of flexibility in terms of work style and how you perform your work.  The benefits are good as well.  In general Capital One is a laid-back place to work except when there is an important project to deliver within a certain time.  Then it is probably about the same stress levels as any corporation.
cons: I think it's the work.  Ultimately it is a financial services corporation.  You're not working on the next iPhone or consumer product that will delight the world.  You are working on fine-tuning numbers to bring in more dollars for the company.  The performance management process is a bit of a pain as it is quite a bit of work and not fully transparent.  The opportunity for advancement has declined significantly since 2001 due to outsourcing and the economy.

review_title: Ageism, No Management, and work here only if in Virginia!
pros: OK Bank to hang out at and make good money IF you work for them IN Virginia. The non-Virginia locations are so miss-managed that you can hide for years doing nothing and still make good money. I left because I am a high performer and couldn't stand all the dead weight and people, including Sr "Management", that don't know what they are doing...I think it is by design!
cons: If you like to do the right thing, this is probably not the place for you to work. If you want to be rewarded for bringing issues to light and fixing things that are broken,... go elsewhere! They hire a lot of younger folk, which is good....IF there was good management (but I feel sorry for the younger ones who get hired here). They get rid of a lot of the older (over 50) folk, so watch out if you are nearing that age! There is rampant favoritism, large cliques of people who do not carry their weight, and all the usual lip service about work/life "balance". If you are not drinking the kool aid, caution advised. The wrong word or instant message or email and you will be OUT! Many, many disgruntled people in this place! Don't take me wrong...I was not fired. I left because I have better things to do with my career than spend any more of it here!

job_title: Customer Service Coordinator in Tampa, FL
pros: The greatest benefits I have ever had, and other than moving to better shifts, the company treats employees great.
cons: Recruiting lies to you when offering you a job, and management continues to lie to you. You figure this out after about 6 months to a year.This is mostly in regard to the hours you will work. For example, my team was hired to work until 2:00 PM - 11:00 PM Tuesday - Saturday. We were told that all new hires must work evenings and one weekend day per week. After working there for a while you will find out that new hires get whatever shifts are open at the time. For example, many are hired 8:00 AM - 5:00 PM Monday - Friday, or 4 ten hour shifts, weekdays only. If you start on evenings, it is very hard to ever get a day shift, and even after 4 years, cannot get an early morning shift, or a weekend off. They also say metrics is what is used to get better shifts. That is not the case. Even if you are in the top 10 for metrics, better hours are almost impossible to get.

pros: One of the very few large banks that you actually believe is trying to keep a morally justifiable course.  All of the horrible headlines about big banks during the financial meltdown largely did not apply to Capital One.  They are constantly trying new things and expanding into new areas.  Their campuses in Richmond and Plano are top notch, and at least when I was there compensation was above average.
cons: Constant churn internally.  Director and up are constantly moved around, often times just to provide change for change's sake.  A department that is running well is almost guaranteed to be largely disbanded within a year.  Some people enjoy a new job every year, others not so much.  Constant heavy pressure to perform with overly ambitious goals set by senior leadership.

review_title: It's clear why they win "best place to work"
pros: Excellent Nottingham office. They really think of everything, from hair straighteners in the gym changing rooms to a dry cleaning service. Working in complaints there were always lots of bonuses to be had, awards to be won and socials to get involved with. Flexible working hours arrangements to fit around your life/travel. Great holiday allowance. Managers followed a process and so they couldn't go too wrong and the senior team were visible.
cons:
Rewards and bonuses within complaints team were there to create as much output as possible and I was never entirely sure that the customer was always getting the best service as the staff (myself included) were solely driven by money and reward. 
Temps and fixed term staff offered no security and generally fobbed off for as long as possible with regards to what may happen with role, particularly when nearing end of fixed term. I and all people on same contract as me were given minimum notice and I know full well that it was done intentionally to prevent productivity dropping off. (As that was the be all and end all)
Promotion generally happened to management's favourite people. It was never about what you knew...always who you knew.

pros:
- Good health insurance with three coverage options
- 50% HSA match
- The company gives a 3% base contribution on employees behalf on top of a matching percentage on the next 4% contributed.
cons:
- Poor work life balance as most departments are understaffed. 
- The pay is decent at face value, but is not in line with the amount of work and responsibility that the typical worker has. 
- Performance management system is skewed to pit employees against each other rather than assess your actual performance (this is also any easy way for the company to lower your bonus). 
- Frequent reorganizations and process changes. Most of the process changes result in increased difficulty of completing your daily job. 
- Many of the team leads are not ready or capable of being a manager. 
- Recently switched from Microsoft office to G Suite, which has been a fiasco so far. 
- Business origination and the bank's risk tolerance (credit) are not on the same page. 
- Promotion and mobility in the company is very dependent on favoritism and face time with the right managers and senior managers.

review_title: A good place to start, but not to stay.
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in McLean, VA
pros:
A great place to intern or start your career due to its great management and technology rotation programs.

Lots of great learning opportunities to pick up relevant skills. In most lines of business, the company's tech stack is pretty modern. The company is also fully invested in transitioning into the cloud, and makes plenty of learning resources available.

Competitive salary relative to other commercial banks, especially for entry-level positions.

Above average benefits: health care, life insurance, parental leave, stock purchase program, tuition reimbursement, FSA, and a FANTASTIC 401k.
cons:
There is a substantial level of politics and nepotism within the senior and executive ranks, and the effects of that are apparent. Reorganizations and departures at the VP+ level are a common occurrence, and you will find managers who possess no technical background leading engineering teams.

Stack ranking and all of the arguments and backstabbing that ensues.

Uncompetitive salary relative to technology companies recruiting for the same engineering talent. Don't expect to receive any substantial amount of equity (RSUs or options) unless you're going into mid to senior-level management.

You have to stay at the company for 2 years before that fantastic 401k vests.

pros: Great amazing fun awesome work
cons: Work lost hard lots of stuff

pros: Amazing benefits. Incredible 401(k) match, awesome bonus program and good salary. They even match your FSA and offer multiple health related programs during the year where you can get extra bonuses in the form of gift cards. Decent number of in-office perks like free breakfasts/lunches, lenient business travel policy.
cons: You just can't throw money at people and expect it to make them happy when the organization is a complete and utter mess. There is tremendous overlap across teams and departments, so you're constantly facing redundancies and duplicative work. No one has a clear role so everyone is fighting to "own" something and it creates lots of tension. I work in Brand Strategy, only there is NO strategy. We just react to everything and change our minds every 5 minutes, so it's impossible to accomplish anything. Processes are rigid and get in the way of doing work, rather than helping it along. People are fairly nice, but many are in the wrong role and don't know what they're doing, which further slows things down. Performance management is talked about every 5 seconds, but is highly political and even one weakness can hold someone back from progressing...unless they're connected to the right people and have become a favorite. Stay away!

review_title: Aspirational Tech Company, emphasis on aspirational
pros:
- work/life balance
- great benefits
- collaborative
- continuous learning encouraged including  role rotation 
- empowered to pursue new ideas at any level 
- trying to change the way things are done in banking
cons:
Gender-bias and a lack of diversity are pervasive issues (unless you are a white male), while this problem isn't specific to Capital One and a problem that plagues most of banking, don't expect to see diversity in roles higher than the Manager level.

There is no understanding of how to grow and develop Product Management talent. You're expected to make it up as you go, sounds great with lots of room to grow, until management decides what you've done isn't what they wanted and you'll find yourself seeking other opportunities. Depending who your manager and leadership chain are will determine if you were given any constructive feedback or an opportunity to take a different approach/adjust. 

Other quick thoughts:
- there are lots of great people at this company however your experience will vary greatly depending on your direct manager and leadership chain
- constant reorgs are exhausting and disorienting  
- consensus driven decision making makes it difficult to get thing done timely

pros: great and fun expectance good fun
cons: love my job and what i do

pros: PTO and vacation time nothing else
cons: Everything about this job is horrible

pros: Training ,benefits, diversity . Very good corporate culture, highly experienced training team. Customer has very good product choices. Corporate perks are really great.
cons: Not what it says in job profile and training.Job profile and training /orientation  say a particular position does not have sales goals. But regional managers and branch managers push and stress you out. They force you to turn away clients by promoting digital banking and in the evening you are asked to sit late at branch and call customers inviting them to branch to discuss product. I didn't know I signed up for an after hr call center job. Company boast about being digitally forward, may be from the client side, not internally - employees have to use more than  3 different applications which are reluctant to load ,to get customer info while customer is in front of you rushing. Break room walls are full of target and sales charts - so dont expect break in break room. You call compliance assistant or help desk  every time you are in doubt, even in front of customer which makes you look incompetent. Customer surveys are a joke. Even a tech savvy person can mistake in those stupid surveys and can put you in trouble.

review_title: Performance Mgmt process causes bad behaviors
pros:
Employees are very talented and tend to be giving of their time and information.
Benefits are excellent.
Campuses are nice and well maintained.
cons: 'Up-or-out' performance management process equates relative ranking to absolute ratings, e.g. if you are at the bottom of the curve relative to your peers, you go on a performance plan, even if you are doing on okay job.  And the 'bottom' is forced - the company demands a certain % be rated below-expectations.  Once on a plan, it is nearly impossible to get off, since you must 'climb over' someone(s) ahead of you on the curve.  Moreover, as a manager it's difficult to put someone on a plan who hasn't been there already, since they weren't properly warned of the possibility, making climbing out of a low rating even more difficult.   So people scramble to switch jobs before the performance period.   So many things can wrong with this approach, it leads to alot of wasted talent and hurts morale.  Most companies have recognized this issue and allowed managers more flexibility in how they rate their people; relative ranking (forced ranking) will always be there, but it need not automatically lead to forced meets/does not meet ratings.

job_title: Senior Risk Coordinator in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Provides benefits day 1, great pay (pay increased almost $5 an hour overtime), recieved PTO/sick days/personal days up-front to use whenever throughout the year. Great people and enviroment. Very flexible.
cons:
Looks are decieving. Even though Capital One has many great attributes, they don't care about their employees. When push comes to shove they are selfish and management chooses themselves and screws you over. They let go ALOT of hardworking people and employees were dropping like flies in the course of 2-3 months. They "cleaned house" as corporate would say. You have ZERO job security and when you think management has your back and can vouche for you, think again. They will be the ones to save their own butts and throw you under the bus. 
Capital One is glitz and glam and then they take it all away from you because they need "someone to fire" 
If you decide to work here, just know not to put all your eggs in their basket...

review_title: Was Really Great... For A While
pros: Training, their training, especially if you've never worked in the industry, is top-shelf! The work/life balance is reasonable, there's lots of emphasis on things like diversity and development, typically you get lots of face-to-face time with your manager. The benefits were really good.
cons: I worked in fraud for a while before everything changed--managers left, upper management changed, supplier sites which were severely under-trained were brought on. I was part of a focus group to discuss our concerns about the department and it was essentially a way for management to say, "Well, you don't understand xyz and here's why..." Lots of frustration stemmed from the fact that we felt like we were not being heard, especially given the fact that agents requested for the focus group were tenured. Additionally, the change left our direct managers stretched thin and during that time when I was also transitioning to a new department I had very little chance to discuss how that change would take place or who to report to, etc.

review_title: AVOID AVOID AVOID: THEY WILL FIRE YOU FOR ANY + EVERY REASON.
pros: Nothing, absolutely nothing.  Some customers are nice I guess, but that does not compare with management that will lie to your face.
cons: I will start off by saying this review is for the retail bank division. Capital One is the worst company I have ever worked for. They are eliminating positions left and right and giving more responsibility to lower level employees for no extra pay. The company currently fired all of their bankers and lead tellers (because why pay them to do 1 job at 40K when they can hire someone as a UBA for 29K and have them be a teller, banker and manager). You can work here for 30+ years, it makes no difference they will throw you out the door without any empathy. I was just fired because 'my position was eliminated' and am sick to my stomach.  They like to do mass firings on group conference calls as well; they will have you on a group of dozens of other people and fire you all at once and ask 'any questions'.  You can be a top banker, bring in over 2 million in new money, and it makes no difference, they will fire you if they want to.  How much did they save with the tax cuts? Yet they still have the urge to do more mass firings.

review_title: A Very Good Place to Work!
pros:
Working at Capital One is like a dream come true for me. 

- It feels more like working for Google or Facebook instead of a bank. A tech company that just happens to be in banking.
- They have very smart people at all levels of the company.
- The benefits are second to none.
- They provide associates with plenty of training and opportunity for growth. There's no pre-defined career path. You decide how to shape your career and they help you get there. It's a hard place to get pigeonholed if you're a go getter.
- Pay is very competitive.
- The corporate campuses are amazing places to work.
- A lot of emphasis is placed on management and culture. It's a very positive and upbeat place to work.
cons:
- This may not be the best place for someone who's just looking to put in 40 hours a week and collect a paycheck.  

- Frequent re-orgs and changes of focus. It's challenging and fun for the right people, but could be stressful for others.

review_title: Great place to start a career in financial service industry
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: It really depends where you are in your career stage. I always think COF is a great place for fresh graduate from college or even from grad school w/o working experience (including MBA's changing industry). The people you work with are very smart, with very diversied backgrounds (both academic & culture wise). The management is very open and encourages innovation/new ideas/initiatives. Knowledge-sharing is almost like an imperative and teammates are very willing to help out. Lastly, but not least, is the training provided on campus - which includes both competency (e.g., structural thinking, networking, etc) and technical (SAS, SQL, etc).
cons:
Be prepared to be aggressive - there are many international guys here (including direct hire from India). They are not here just for the job - people are willing to put in extra long hours to shine. 

Be prepared for frequent re-org that will change your reporting structure, and ultimately impact your performance review if you fail to manage it properly and closely.

review_title: Not as perfect as described in job interview
pros:
*pay is good, better than other banks
*PTO is also good
*Incentives are good
*Most of the co-workers are good people
*Capital-one in this area are not  as busy as others
cons:
*The GAIN is ridiculous, management is never satisfied
*They make you investigate customers in order to make referrals to the bankers (They call it discover hidden needs) have to ask customers where they work, and what plans they have 
(Hate that)
*When the bank gets mystery shoppers and you fail to get a 100% they make sure you feel everyone hates you
*Everyone feels they have the right to tell you what to do
*one day they tell you, you are a great  employee, and the next you are the worst
*If one day you have referrals, you're the best, but when 
 you don' t have any they throw it in you're face, and make you feel unproductive
*Co-workers are great, when you do what they want you to do, when you dont  they talk about you until they get tired, and start being great again
*Most of them say that they are professionals, but its not what you see in them

pros: Employees are given lots of responsibility, and have a voice in the decision making process.  You work with a lot of bright individuals.
cons: Lots of meetings.  Decisions are made by consensus very often, which can lead to a long decision making process.  Lots of change in the organization structure and senior leadership.  Not easy to get hired - it is a lengthy process with several interviews with different levels in the company.  Not easy to get promoted.  Standard policy is that you perform in a role for six months when promoted to prove yourself.  At the end of 6 months you're evaluated to see if you actually receive the promotion - at that time, your title and salary kick in.  So, they essentially have you busting your tail for 6 months to "earn" your new salary.

pros:
-Teams all seem pretty happy in spite of the weak salaries
-The culture is decent, compared to what I've heard about similar places
-
-Good benefits 
-Diversity networks are great
cons:
-Not all departments are created equal - half the place walks around with macbooks and works from home as they please, other teams are paper and pencil only and don't have the option to work remotely at all, even in the event of a storm or on work trips. 
-The performance management system is completely out of whack.  All departments have completely different stances on promotions and raises, so equality is basically non-existent, but you are still rated against your "peers" (aka those with the same job title as you) at year-end, regardless of what your individual jobs entail.
