The system also basically tries to eliminate any attempts at negotiation of salary by delivering the final decision to you in a tidy little package with seemingly no other options.
-The pay is much lower than the industry standard.  
-Depending on where you are, there is ZERO opportunity.

review_title: Good Benefits and Culture, but needs strong and consistent leadership
pros: The Company has a great overall culture. The top executives look to keep associates engaged. The work-life balance and laid back environment are different from most financial institutions. There is a reason it is a consistently a Top 100 place to work.  It earns the title.
cons: Certain groups within Capital One are steady (Card, Commercial, National Expansion), but the banking group is in constant flux. Leadership takes the roles to move on, never to build. There is constant shuffling as a result. It is best to take an exempt position or a role in National Expansion. Non-exempt roles are subject to too many vanishing goals. If you take a role in the contact center, fight for stability and change. There is a bevy of potential with just a little consistency and innovation.

review_title: A good place to work at
pros: I've been at Capital One for over 3 years now and have enjoyed working here. It's a pretty good place with smart people, great work life balance, good compensation, great benefits and flexibility in work location.
cons: One of the best things about capital one has always been the bottom up innovation in the strategy setting and product development. However, the recent spate of acquisitions has added a lot of beaurocracy and moat of the work being done is driven by senior management with the ground level employees simply finding ways to do what they are asked to do. Also, the performance appraisal process needs more transparency. The way it works today, its a popularity contest. If people above you like you, you get to be on the high profile projects and get promoted as a result of that. The others just get stuck in a viscious cycle of getting the same vague feedback again and again.

job_title: IT Senior Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Good pay, benefits, time off, etc.  Pockets of great leadership.  Campuses are excellent - great work spaces and amenities.  Coworkers are super bright, most committed to the success of projects, their teams, and their peers.
cons: Confused on their identity.  Want to be a "tech" company, but are a large financial institution.  This conflicts with federal regulations/controls/and risk reduction practices needed to support a financial institution.  Also has a tendency to do a full pendulum swing verses really thinking through broadscale shifts in direction.  In this new agile world, senior leadership should pilot, implement, learn in smaller pockets vs. taking an all or nothing approach to everything they do.  It's ok though because with the tendency to overcorrect, wait a year or so and it will balance back to what would have made sense in the first place...

job_title: Customer Service Associate in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Benefits ( if you are approved).
cons: Management, Work Conditions, and expectations.

pros:
Benefits are second to none
Good Tech
Parties and socials, they reward staff well and there are always things to get involved with, vouchers and thank you's at Christmas.
Non managerial colleagues
London Offices are great, Nottingham have a subsidized restaurant.
cons:
Huge diversity issue- two senior female leaders here and that's where it stops, they have big goals to achieve a better gender balance and BAME representation but no actual will or motivation to get to it.
Old fashioned interview process that makes you doubt your ability, and you will almost always be interviewed by a while male. 

Management is archaic, certain areas of the business in particular have management with 10+ years tenure and no openness to a change in ways of thinking. HR have no interest in feedback, they just want to hit their curve on their out of date performance management and creating a dog eat dog environment in order to get the rating you deserve.

Certain stars of the business are over looked in favour of people who's faces fit, very cliquey in that respect.

review_title: Smart top management, largely capable people and culture, less political than competition
job_title: Manager, Project Management in Richmond, VA
pros:
* Great values, sensible and largely competent top management
* Strong support for employees' work-life balance and flexible work options (eg: working from home)
* Support for lateral movement for employees
* Largely less political compared to competition, and quick to adapt business strategy and adjust priorities in response to broader market environment
cons:
* Still integrating the multiple Bank acquisitions, overall culture is not consistent, very hierarchical in many groups (different from the Capital One of a few years ago)
* Lack of savvy around investment in technology infrastructure, aging systems and massive inefficiencies that are finally slowly being addressed. Not too dissimilar to other banks but for a company that grew up on innovation and analysis-driven strategy, its taken a while to realize that ongoing technology investment is needed to support the quality data and analytical tools the company needs

job_title: Master Software Engineer/Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: decent salary, 7.5% 401k match, perks not that bad when compared with other traditional organizations like capital one.
cons:
capital one preaches one and practices one. you will be able to see this across all layers of management. every year when i speak to my directors they speak about promotion opportunities and expect you to make a difference in the organization etc., etc., and finally award promotion to non technical talents because there is no growth path for technical people who wants to stay technical. as you see upwards of the management hierarchy, all of them are from non technical background and hence they don't really like technical talents except for getting work done through them.

only 1/10 will be technical talent and there will be a huge crowd of people who you will deal with everyday and get frustrated. you might start feeling very dumb over a period of time because the environment is not fostering enough.

review_title: Overall it was a great company to work for. I learned a lot in my 12 years there.
job_title: Senior Associate in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: Career growth, PTO, lots of engagement and fun. Huge on diversity and community outreach programs. I also utilized the tuition reimbursement.
cons:
They have an insane rating system that affects every aspect of your career. It’s the only company I know that no matter how well you do your job, if the external customer doesn’t audibly voice their pleasure, you get rated as a neutral or worse a detractor. No matter how wonderful you did, if the customer isn’t clear with their approval, it will count against you. Even in positions with no customer involvement, you’re rated as a neutral. It’s that way across the board. 
Also it’s extremely political. 90% of all internal interviews are just formalities. They know who they want ahead of time. 
Actively seek out feedback. Otherwise, you’ll never grow with the company.

review_title: Has had its ups and downs, difficult industry environment may hamper career progression
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in McLean, VA
pros:
- A lot of flexibility and emphasis on work-life balance.  Freedom to work from home occassionally is a nice benefit, and a fair amount of vacation time out the gates as a college hire.

- High level of involvement in day-to-day work from business directors offers opportunity to learn from experienced / savvy professionals.

- Able to make lateral career changes to different departments / lines of businesses as your interests change.

- Fairly competitive salary / 401k match.

- Decent name recognition if business school is a long term goal.

- Strong alumni network if desire is there to leave.
cons:
- Arbitrary differences between some job families.

- Richmond is not the most exciting city in the world.

- Benefits seem to be trending downward over last few years compared to late 90s.

- Difficult credit environment hits credit card companies hard.

- Frequent organizational changes can make getting results difficult.

- Not all departments are equal during evaluation time.  Make sure you're in the right organization.

- Tendency to act in extremes, and then change behavior to the complete opposite in reaction to news / markets / audits.

- Significant amount of time putting slides together for hour long presentations.

pros: Training program for new hires is one of the best I've seen. The company as a whole has a great culture and great benefits. They offer tuition reimbursement, even if you are using a degree that may not be relevant to work in a banking environment. The traditional benefits (insurance, 401k, etc.) are also some of the best I've seen, at least in the area I live. The company encourages advancement and prefers to promote within.
cons: The local management is has too many cliques and doesn't like to work with those who choose not to be part of their cliques. If you don't fit in with their group, they will make work very difficult and will criticize even things you do correctly. The district manager that was hired during my time with Capital One also had unrealistic goals for branches in our area. He had never worked in the lower levels of the banking industry (teller, relationship banker, branch manager) and had only been upper level management since moving to banking, therefore he set unrealistic expectations.

job_title: Senior Advocacy Coordinator in Tampa, FL
pros: Career Development Center. I feel that a lot of my fellow associates do not take advantage of on-site Career Development Centers. These CDCs provide amazing services and materials that provide you with vital tools and feedback necessary to further develop your personal brand and career; whether it be within Cap One or outside of Capital One. Resume writing. Mock interviews. Classes. Online university that you can access at home. Capital One is the most diverse company I've ever worked for. Within their very own little professional social network, you can join groups that include LGBT chapters for your specific location; There are many groups promoting ethnic diversity; groups for women, the armed forces, etc. There is such a diverse mix of associates. Managers are awesome; but, there are some better than others of course. Not everyone can have the same leadership style. Benefits are amazing and Capital One is very accommodating if you need a medical accommodation. Capital One is always striving to develop new tools for associates to help solve customer's problems effectively and efficiently.
cons: Aetna still handles FMLA and disability benefits. I CAN'T STAND CVS CAREMARK, which is the proscription provider. They are awful IMO. Other than that, I love Capital One.

job_title: Commercial Credit Analyst in Houston, TX
pros:
1. Rich Fairbank is someone that has a vision for his company, a plan you can get behind, and a set of values that are actually present throughout the company. This attitude and passion flows (not trickles) down throughout management. I am the bottom of the totem pole, and everyone above me has "spit flying" passion about the company and their job. "Change banking for GOOD" is a real thing.

2. I have had my career nourished since day one. The   People here genuinely want you to be successful. The performance evaluations are not only fair, but insightful.

3. The resources -personal and professional- are vast and GROWING! 

4. The culture is genuine, inclusive, and is ever present throughout the company.

5. The pay and benefits are goooooood. And the company actually believes in work-life balance.

There are more but I felt like a top 5 would be enough.
cons: There are some growing pains as new technologies are being conceived and adapted. Some of the legacy systems are unintuitive, and take some time to learn. Once you do they are adequate, though sometimes feel inefficient.

review_title: Don't judge a book by its cover
pros: Benefits, some talented co-workers, workplace environment.
cons: no well balanced diversity,  product teams have no talented POs and have their heads in the clouds most of the time, party all time seems to be the motto,   women in tech is a joke - most women issues at work are ignored and if you raise it then you are ostracized. no work life balance unless you are on maternity or paternity, bad people managers and senior management.

job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Nottingham, England
pros:
Tech
- Top of the range tech and working environment.  mechanically operated desks that rise to allow you to stand, huge widescreen monitors, latest laptops & machines.
- Always striving to work on the latest tech.
- Video conferencing is an everyday occurrence and the tech to allow that is extremely good and available in abundance. 

Working Environment
- Relaxed and designed ergonomically to be pleasing with great breakout spaces. 

Great benefits
- Private healthcare options, life insurance, gym, canteen/cafe serving amazing food. Games room (table tennis, pool, table football), Music room with drums, guitars etc. 
- Strong emphasis on ensuring fun remains in the workplace - its one of the company values.
- Flexible working where necessary 

Progression
- Amazing progression with performance management practices designed to ensure you succeed. 

Strong emphasis on company values and imperatives that guide the company and are used as a backbone to which a majority of decisions are made. There is a feeling that you're always working with the best in the industry and to be frank, you pretty much are.
cons:
- Lack of parking
- Financial industry ensures that simple tasks are wrapped in process - be prepared for that!

review_title: Interesting place to work with talented people, but you'd better like working really close to them.
pros: Interesting project work.  Very smart, talented coworkers. Ability to do new things.  It doesn't get stale and you are always challenged.  Everybody gets a laptop and Blackberry, and the technology tools available are fairly good.  There is some flexibility to work remotely, but there are few, if any, professional positions that are advertised as being remote jobs.
cons: Very heavy on standard, procedures, and process.  It's a bank, after all, and heavily regulated.  The work environment is "mobile."  That means it's so crowded it's like working in an ant hill.  Every time they "restack" the work spaces, you end up with less room.  Agile work team spaces are like being in pre-school.  Everybody sits around a table elbow to elbow and I got two colds and two sinus infections in the first four months with my team.  They are leasing new buildings and creating more space, but oh boy is it crowded.

review_title: A growing and profitable company with room to improve
pros: Capital One is a large and growing financial company that casts itself as a technology company. If you work in IT which Capital One calls Shared Technology this is a very good thin as the company invests generously in the latest technology. Also, the level of engineering talent is very good, much better than some other companies I have worked for. The pay and benefits are also above average. The Plano campus where I work is beautiful and has a number of really nice amenities ( covered parking, bikes, gym, sports fields ).  The food served at the cafe's is really good.
cons: The annual review process is overly complex and burdensome.  I have worked at other companies where managers were given much more autonomy in the review process. Work/Life balance is non-existent in my group. My manager agrees but there is not much he can do as more work keeps coming. Recently, there was a realignment and people where laid off based on location.

review_title: A growing and profitable company with room to improve
pros: Capital One is a large and growing financial company that casts itself as a technology company. If you work in IT which Capital One calls Shared Technology this is a very good thin as the company invests generously in the latest technology. Also, the level of engineering talent is very good, much better than some other companies I have worked for. The pay and benefits are also above average. The Plano campus where I work is beautiful and has a number of really nice amenities ( covered parking, bikes, gym, sports fields ).  The food served at the cafe's is really good.
cons: The annual review process is overly complex and burdensome.  I have worked at other companies where managers were given much more autonomy in the review process. Work/Life balance is non-existent in my group. My manager agrees but there is not much he can do as more work keeps coming. Recently, there was a realignment and people where laid off based on location.

pros: Great benefits. Decent starting pay. Onsite Be Well clinic is free to employees and their immediate family members. Love Dr On Demand - Free video visits with a physician.
cons: Low pay raises. Forced Distribution / Stacked Ranking Performance Management method is outdated and drives a “dog eat dog” culture. It’s every man for himself with focus on stepping on who you have to .... to prevent from being forced in a lower ranking that is not truly reflective of your actual contributions to the business.  Greater of the Greats culture with the lesser of the greats being forced in a low rating up to Inconsistent to meet distribution in Exceptional / Strong / Inconsistent. Simply demotivating and a slap in the face when your efforts are not recognized or adequately compensated at the end of the year.  This is worst at non-frontline and management level roles. The CEO truly can’t be aware just how bad this method is...

pros:
Capital One has phenomenal work-life balance opportunities if you land on the right team; I'm not on such a team, but I still have a fairly positive experience. Strong benefits: 7.5% 401k matching, good healthcare, paternity leave, et cetera. Opportunities are available to learn new skills on the job, and your manager will probably not turn down your request to study for a new certificate on company time.

Great career move for the "put in my 40 and head home" crowd that still wants some challenges without the hoops of getting into the tech giants.
cons: Moves slowly, good ideas are rejected frequently, forced rankings can add either toxicity to the team or cost you your job, depending on the team. Talent acquisition is non-existent for some teams; our team has lost half our developers within the last year, yet management has no desire to get new engineers but continue honoring delivery speed of a team twice our size.

pros: Energetic and fun team environment, good benefits, great training.  Upper management is excellent in my experience-very dedicated.  It's a good opportunity for career auto industry people.  If you aren't 100% committed to auto finance or the auto industry in general, not only will this be a temporary gig for you but it will also have a limiting effect on future career opportunities (and good luck trying to get a Capital One recruiter to help you with an internal transfer: they are simply not interested in helping current employees).
cons: Work on the weekends, call center environment, open cubicle layout and it's business-casual despite the fact that you work over the phone all day.  Your success in the role is highly dependent on a lot of other people, i.e. teammates, customers, managers, underwriters, employers, etc., so a lot of things (including your success in this position) can be and are out of your control. Career opportunities rapidly diminish past the senior relationship manager role, so be prepared to relocate to Plano, TX for COAF advancement.  "Senior" Relationship Managers are mostly young with little to no prior management experience.

job_title: Bank Teller in New York, NY
pros:
- Benefits
-Co-workers
-401k Plan
-Health benefits
-Employee assistance Program
-Discounts with Perks
cons:
- Employee who get hired after me, as a teller, get more pay then the Older Employees in the   Branch.
- Manager Micromanaged us, for Customer Service Score and Sales.
- The amount of hard work we do, it hard to move up.

pros: I think most people would be surprised how hard Capital One works to be more than a stodgy, mammoth, financial company. Sure it struggles with bureaucracy, but they actively work to fight that and instead be a mission driven business. On top of that they take excellent care of their employees. The benefits are great and even in outplacement they bend over backwards to make sure associates are set up for future success. I think that how a company treats it's employees says loads about the company.
cons: Your experience may vary dramatically depending on which portion of the business you work for. While the overarching corporate leadership and mission may be strong, if you are in a more fringe part of the company (such as investing) you may find your direct Leadership very challenging to work for and that there is an atmosphere of cronyism or tribalism. The single biggest con for Capital One though is that they still use a traditional stack ranking form of performance management that kills collaboration and innovation in favor of being popular or associated with high profile projects.

pros:
9-5
Good health benefits
4 mos maternity leave, tho they prorate and keep yearly bonus if you take the leave
cons:
-All white male leadership bro club atmosphere. Gave feedback to female creative directors like "perhaps if you smiled more and were more friendly to the (male) leadership team, you could be considered for promotion." 
-Had very abusive and toxic GCD in place, with over 50 complaints in HR - leadership did nothing about it. Protected him because it "made them look bad if they report someone to HR that they had put up for promotion".
-Had very toxic Director in place, lots of HR complaints, did nothing about it
-Women creatives of all levels are hired in lower than their level of expertise and have to fight for years to get menial promotions, and fend off feedback like "perhaps if you spoke less in meetings and took notes/smiled more/got a (male) mentor". Meanwhile, men were hired in at top roles, top pay, and promoted faster and more often.
-Performance mgmt was a popularity contest, not meant to set people up to succeed or learn
-Creatives who spoke up about the toxic culture and lack of diversity in the creative depts, were re-orged and managed out of jobs.
-Creative dept ultimately hired an outside consultant to come in and help with morale and issues - after report was issued and very serious charges logged, no changes made, all-male leadership still in place.

pros: The Richmond campus provides a great physical and virtual work environment.  Capital One pioneered alternative work arrangements with its Future of Work program.  Salaries are in line with expectation and benefits are above average. Notably, maternity and paternity benefits are quite generous.  The external hiring decision process is rigorous and consistent, resulting in a generally high level of employee competence.
cons: Capital One's revenues and profits grew at a meteoric rate until about 2005, then leveled off.  The boom years produced a cadre of managers more skilled in rhetoric than in managing human talent.  As a result, the culture does not value, reward or develop people management skills.  Capital One's GE-style performance management system becomes an annual pain point, demoralizing many, rewarding too few with promotions and often presaging the next reorg exercise.

review_title: Review After Two Tours of Duty
pros: Capital One hires bright and motivated people. It's a dynamic environment in which you are always challenged to do great work. Pay is above scale in Richmond, VA and total compensation - salary, benefits and bonus - are generally good to very good. If you are a young engineer or developer you are currently primed for a good run at Capital One.
cons: Like any large corporation, decisions at the top of the house don't always play out well for the rank and file. After two tours of duty resulting in two layoffs Capital One became an increasingly tough place to work and move up. If you are a people manager or technology generalist, the deck is currently stacked against you. Be aware that Capital One regularly lays off and they are doing so now.

review_title: Engineers, Dont work for this company
pros: The campus and atmosphere is very nice, but management is non existent
cons:
I was hired on through contract for 3 months contract to hire, after being on the job for a couple weeks the manager above my manager was let go. (Although I didn't meet him, I gather that he was a manager with drive that wanted to accomplish something) After that point three new full time employees were hired on the team, and the four existing contractors were let go.

Capital One's management has no plan. They hire engineers, give them no products or requirements and assume they will innovate like a startup. Upon asking for requirements from management (whom aren't located in Plano) we were directed to a manager who didn't communicate with the team. (And were told not to waste his time by scheduling meetings with him)

There were 5 people at the company that had been there longer than a year. Everyone was new and had little to no idea how things worked. Being a bank they rely heavily on "friend of friend" hiring, other than the penetration testing contractors that worked near us, no one really did any real work from what I could see

pros: Very smart peers. Business folks are also very smart. Only reason I still work here is the quality of the work force. Good benefits and overall work environment. very good training resources. Good technology exposure throughout the stack.
cons:
very aggressive agenda and timelines  Work life balance non existent in many cases. Aggressive plan for employee involuntary attrition (10-12% every year).. regardless of intake of people. hoping to make up for it by hiring folks who are extremely difficult to find. 
Extremely competitive workplace even though its not made obvious employees are self focused and hesitant to share knowledge due to aggressive performance management agenda introduced by management. Very difficult to get information and co-operation even from peers.

review_title: fire people for wrong reasons without any prior warning, wrong reasons, and carry that "don't give a crap" attitude.
pros: vacation time (when you get to use it), benefits, working hours
cons: every month they are changing the name of a position, basically to a name that isn't as big and also lowering the level of pay for anyone trying to be promoted to that job. Also not refilling position of people who left that position previously and having the other manager or employee take over all job duties without a pay increase. Managment style is " I don't care what happend or why, just do it  or your fired"  You always have to watch what you say or do, managment takes a "your gonna get it now" attitude when they find out that you don't like something and try to just weed you out.  Watch our, they may fire you for the littlest of reasons just before they plan ssettlements. Watch out you may get fired for the smallest of things just before a layoff or branch closing due to not paying unemployment or severences.

pros:
Great place for work life balance. Flexible work schedules and ability to work from home allows employees to be able to have balance in their life. 
From day 1, employees are given responsibilities and ownership of their own work.
Strong teamwork environment. Employees are looking to support each other, very few people are cutthroat, though politics does still exist.
cons:
Many managers do not have the experience to be great people managers. This is due to a lack of experience in workplace in general (for some fast promotions).
Promotions seems to tie to groups that one works for. In addition, promotion criteria differs from group to group making it difficult for those who change groups internally to be promoted.
Feedback system could use some work. There should be more communication between managers and their employees.

review_title: Not as good as it looks from outside!
pros:
Reputable company
Flexible work environment, Work & Life Balance
Benefits, including increasing stock price 
Company is open if you are looking for a career move
cons:
Unfair performance reviews and rating system
Amateur management
High bureaucracy to get things done in a more efficient way
So many people who are good at talking, but bad at implementing
High level of unnecessary conversations in business meetings
Too much separation between business lines
Diversity disappears at the high levels of management

pros: Everything! They offer medical insurance that kicks in after about 30-60 days. They also offer a nice life insurance policy. There 401k is the best, the company will automatically contribute 3% on day one whether you contribute or not, then they will match you dollar for dollar up to another 3% and lastly 50 cents on the dollar for another 3%. You are 100 % vested from the day you start. 3 full weeks of paid vacation after 90 days of employment, which increases up to 6 weeks the more years you are with the company. Raise increases are a decent percentage of your pay. The hours are standard 9-5 or 9-4 depending on your region. They are extremely diverse in the employees they hire and not just entry level but all through the company.
cons:
With all the great things they offer, current employees are staying in there positions, so there is no opening to move into in some states. 
The company is only in about 9 US states. 
It could take a year or more to move into full time. 
Part time associates don't get paid for holidays off, or bereavement.

pros: Amazing work culture. Lots of good treatment. I got 4 friends in. 6 more are currently interviewing.  You get a promotion like every two years for the first 6-7 years. every promotion your sal increases by 25% Ofc you gotta put in the work...but if you do you'll be making uber level comp in no time. Heres the ladder. Associate swe. senior assoc. principal assoc. master. lead. distinguished. fellow. Usually getting to master takes like 8-10 years but I've met people who did it in 5. Again you get in how much you outwork. also, I feel c1 pays well for the work you do. its good work-life balance. as to how I got this info...I interned there over the summer and set up lunches at all levels across all lines of biz...assoc-distinguished for swe...assoc-svp for product. we got to meet the CEO too. his legit. liked his keynote. overall valid exp. Just doesn't have the recognition like FANG but you get the same FANG exp if not better because they are trying hard to impress. Oh, and there on a hiring frenzy rn...hope this helps. Apply early! Like august
cons: Small governance. But they listen to people across all levels.

pros:
They tend to pride themselves as having a high bar to get in but some of the Senior Management (Director +) are a joke and how they got to that level is a suprise to most people. 

Nice Gym
Like the idea of being able to have a high concentration within one campus
Close to lots of restaurants
cons:
There is so much politics it is ridiculous in order to move up. Promotions are not based on results but rather being best buddy with manager and there is so much instability with management if you happen to get momentum you will have a new manager that will not have any history on you. 

Compensation is far below the market in the same industry for similar job. A lot of focus on levels as a way to get things pushed. 

Claim to be about front line people engagement, however only a few areas actually live this and rest is lip service. 

Exodus of people close to happening like did before when people left to competition. Playing favorites is common here: a few select few (not actually any better) will get promoted every year to 2 years, the rest will never move up and those moving up will give foolish reasons why others shouldn't.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Benifits are ok. But it's pretty much the same in the banking industry. its a job. A touch over McDonald's with the whole supersize script. Remember this was a credit card. So good credit cards.
cons: Extreme racist environment. Worked ith this company 4 yr and have never seen such in your face racism. Have seen blacks and Indians targeted over the last few yrs in such a way that I'm surprised there is no law suits. Rich fair banks idea of changing banking for good is telling his employees how great is life is while making up these so called certifications to shrink the work force and not pay employees. Screwing over financial advisors and stealing from the everyday working stiff. Saw a DM get taken to HR for racial behavior by 2 different employees who didn't know each other and capt 1 swept it under the carpet. What's your worth with this corp. Don't wanna sound to disgusted but I am.

review_title: Not worth it - YOU CAN DO BETTER!
pros: great benefits and nothing else that I can actually think of right now
cons:
-ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE culture: backstabbing culture encouraged through feedback surveys; you get the feeling that it's like a bad cliche high school movie 
-their culture forces people to start acting like they are on survivor 
-existing long term employees are absolutely incompetent both in Canada and USA
-HR has no idea what they are doing: do not believe anything they say to you, it is almost always a lie
-so much red tape you cannot accomplish anything
-very poor compensation package compared to other companies of the same size
-old systems that do not function properly
-not open to new ideas from new experienced employees
-if you are an experienced manager, do not bother coming to this company
-be careful when signing your contract, they will try to screw you
-they have a great pitch to get you and when you arrive they will sell you on their values, but nobody is actually following through on what they claim
-absolutely no work/life balance
-if you absolutely need a job, come here but be careful in every aspect and continue looking for a better offer, under no circumstance come here if you are already employed
-the only reason why they are rated well in external surveys is because they force their employees to vote this way

pros: one upside of them trying to move fast is you will get to work on latest technologies but all of this comes at  huge cost to you personally. It's a good place for fresh college grads but everyone else not the place to be.
cons: Frequent reorgs and top level management changes all through the year. I have had 4 reorgs in less than 3 years of being there. Whenever someone at the top leaves, management takes it as an opportunity to reorg the deck across the division. One of the most regressive performance management process I have seen which they take great pride in, it's done 4 times a year with no time for associates to focus on learning and development - it's deliver or out all the time but when you couple that with the frequent reorgs it's hard to settle in a role and deliver. Very short term focused managers. Managers are not interested in your development, they just need results to go after their promotion. They run quarterly survey on employees but managers are busy trying to figure out who gave bad ratings than focusing on how to improve morale. There is a lot of corporate marketing speak which is says and means two different things. Be prepared to just preparing atleast 100 slides a week, that's all there is to their work.

review_title: Completely uninspired - and expecting to be replaced any day
pros: Benefits are good and some perks such as working remotely (if you work for the right manager) help maintain work life balance. You'll work with many smart people who you'll learn from; most everyone is amicable and interested in getting things accomplished.
cons: Tremendous lack of communication from management regarding direction of company. Very political - if you aren't good at promoting yourself and getting the right notice during meetings you will go nowhere. Doing your job well is not enough to get promoted nor is it rewarded. Understand in advance that your job is not secure. If you are promoted during the year, expect to get a poor review when you are first evaluated at that new level.

review_title: Mixed bag so far, but things are on the way up
job_title: Statistical Analysis Manager in McLean, VA
pros: The people are brilliant and hardworking. The volume and range of training available is amazing and we are actively encouraged to take it. Development is important to most managers and they generally want to help you grow. Their are ample opportunities to move up and into new areas. Especially in the past year or so, customer experience is an increasingly larger focus of most projects.
cons: We are a huge organization with high amounts of specialization, so I've noticed a recurring problem of different teams not communication with each other. I am in a support organization and have seen many of my completed projects de-prioritized before they are implemented. It has gotten pretty discouraging. Also, our recruiting and compensation teams within HR are awful. I can't count how much blatantly irrational behavior I've seen from these teams.

pros: Beautiful campus.  Great benefits.  Amenities are second to none.  Bright people.  Rewarded well if high performer.  Plenty of opportunities for engineers.  Pay better than most, if not all.  Enable associates to volunteer during work hours.  Work from home (within reason).  Great focus on professional development through Capital One University.
cons:
Work/life balance.  48-60 hrs/week seems to be the norm.  Stay away from Capital One if you are not or find it difficult to adapt to  change instantly.  Continuous reorganizations and head count cuts.  This company is not for you if job stability influences how you feel.  

Performance management system in combination with the above reality causes some people to be solely competitive rather than collaborative.  People who are promoted deserve it.  Some hard working dedicated associates could end up on the wrong side of the system.  It is unfortunate as they add value.  I feel it is an unintended consequence.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Richmond, VA
pros:
No commute 
Decent Pay
Benefits
They provide equipment
cons: Everyday things change with no warning and you are left to deal with angry customers on your own. The company has no idea what NPS really is when bigger companies such as Apple doesn't use that to coach agents they use CSAT (customer satisfaction).  The customers will give agents 100 across the board but not promote company because they outsource jobs or change made to rewards program but yet it's the agents job to fix them. A joke! Your family does not matter in order to get your schedule changed they give a set of criteria then change it during selection process to meet the needs of the favorites. No morale boosters oh and don't live two hours away if your internet goes down you are expected to come on site to work and won't be reimbursed for travel. The things you learn in training won't be used when you start production. Hours are not great for parents especially with small kids. Monday's Tuesday's Friday's and Saturday mornings are the busiest. Most time there is only a few seconds between each call.

pros: Compared to some other banks, the pay is good because some other banks don't pay you a monthly incentive for sales goals (i.e. Regions).  But Capital One is much quicker to fire it's employees over the simplest thing.
cons: Management is given too much power.  There aren't rules that apply across the board.  Managers are given a lot of discretion, so different branches do different things.  You can easily lose your job over one simple, honest mistake.  They only care about you harrassing and kissing up to the customers to meet your sales goals which ranges from a $35-$120 monthly incentive that is taxed.  All the stalking and butt kissing you have to do to reach the goals is not worth it.  They treat you like a number or product, not a person/employee.  Basically, go to work, do your job, and be sure to dot all i's and cross all t's.  And try not to NEVER be late or miss more than 4 days of work for being sick (a year) because they will fire you!!

pros: The company is moving in the right direction. For a while, I was worried about discussed culture change being just talk, but the investments in fully moving into modern technology and design have been profound. I expect the company to be a lead player in financial services technology in less than 3 years.
cons:
Still getting over some of its old bureaucratic ways. Really depends on the department you're in. The more traditional, legacy business units have a much longer way to go in terms of modern methods of work. I'm lucky enough to work in one of the newer organizations, where the status quo is constantly being challenged and we're pushing in the right direction.

Could run a little lighter. Seems like there are plenty of "lifers" that are content to push paper vs. really come in everyday and make change. The company could easily cut that workforce and notice little to no loss in productivity.

review_title: Great company and great people with poor management skills.
pros: Benefits are good as compared with similar ones. 401K contribution, vocation package and other benefits overall. Compensation is acceptable, but it's not in the top in region area. A lot trainings with lunch free, Xmas party, team party. Nice campus in West Creek and Buildings with nice office. Company have good profits so far.
cons:
Waste your time to work if you want career opportunities. Company is still using 'tech' as old as 10 years ago and try to keep it forever. A Bank company's goal to be 'Technology' ones, but it's not realistic. Senior managers are anxious of their 'performance' to get higher annual bonus, They do not care what is the new and DO CARE WHAT PEOPLE LIE AT STANDING UP MEETING. A lot meetings create 'good' communications with trashes. For example,
10-10, How to listen your boss's lies and flatter them.
Agile, How to lie your daily work.
Agile grooming, How to generate a lot trash tasks and nobody really cares later.
PS: Over 100 people fly from different regions to discuss one or two week tasks for less than 10 people. 
Richmond JAVA Community, Another trash meeting to benefit special purpose (individually).

review_title: Too many employees working overtime without overtime pay
pros: Reasonable compensation. Young and smart co-workers
cons:
1) Dirty office politics. Some co-workers will bad-mouth you behind your back or complain to your manager for tiny little things. Some favored employees are asked by management to keep an eye on you while pretending to be your "friend". Be aware!
2) Inefficient training for employees. 
3) Too many employees have such a heavy workload that they work late into the evenings (often more than 45 hours a week) without overtime pay whatsoever. 
4) If you're not a business analyst (BA), too bad for you! You may do a lot of the hard work and do get recognized from time to time. But most  roles feel like the auxiliary to BA's. If you're not a BA, the company culture will make you feel so Unimportant. Even if you get decent pay, what does it help if they constantly make you feel that you're so Unimportant to the company?

review_title: Good place to get your foot in the door, but that's it
pros: I started as a PT employee, they pay pretty well. They are willing to work with you if you put in effort. Managers are pretty laid back so long as you perform. They want to help you get to the next level but the opportunities to make that move to the position.
cons: If you plan on making more money, you won't get much thru internal promotions. Annual raises are typically cents on the dollar. Requesting a raise takes weeks to be submitted and months to get declined. People being hired from the outside into sales-focuses positions get paid tons more than those who have been promoted internally (ex i make 36k after 5 years, new hires for the same position are hired at 40k) They recently changed their sales incentinves/goals and are making it much harder for bankers and tellers to get their monthly minimums and to make decent commission

job_title: Fraud Intake Coordinator in Richmond, VA
pros: Excellent health and dentist benefits. Other benefits include matching 401k after 5 years you become fully vested. They provide 3 weeks paid vacation after your first year of employment and you can buy an extra week. After 5 years of employment they offer 4 weeks of vacation and you are able to buy an extra week of vacation.
cons: I have made less money every year at Capital One since I started!!! $29,000 a year to start. I made $30,000 salary and made $5000 in incentive bonus in 2015. Capital One has consistently dropped the top pay out incentive every year for the past 5 years.  Don't plan on getting a year end raise!! This is a joke! If you get an Exceptional rating you might get a raise between 4% and 5%. A Very Strong rating is between 3% and 4% yearly pay raise . A strong is around a 3% raise. The whole idea at Capital One is to get promoted. This is a joke!!! If you get promoted to a higher position, the most that they will offer is a 10% raise!!!

review_title: Overall Capital One is a good place to work.
job_title: PT Teller in New York, NY
pros:
Capital one has a wonderful incentive program for both relationship bankers and tellers.
Hours are flexible and Management usually will accommodate your needs.
Capital One encourages promotions from within.
Benefits are OK.
Your co-workers become like family due to the Team environment that Capital One encourages.
cons:
Capital One has unrealistic goals for the personal bankers.
The management team suffers undue stress due to the unrealistic goals.
They never seem to hire enough staff to accommodate the needs of the branch.
The secret shops are unfair to both the bankers and tellers.
The whole "GAIN" approach required to be used with clients inhibits the banker from properly relating to the client.
They like to put you on documented warnings when you don't follow the "GAIN" script.
When complaints are made against management they are often dismissed and then the employee that complained winds up being "managed out" by the manager!

review_title: Continues to evolve and keeps getting better!
job_title: User Experience Designer in London, England
pros:
•Finance is a very interesting industry to work in as a designer.
•Great salary and benefits.
•Lovely London office in Shoreditch, with a usability lab and a running track on the roof!
•Large, diverse and talented design team, including our own in-house research team (and Adaptive Path in the USA!).
•As design is still quite a new function within the UK business, there is opportunity to be involved in defining how we work.
•Plenty of opportunity for personal career growth with funded internal and external courses.
•Extensive library of design books.
•Design team offsite every 3 months.
•Half a day once per month to spend on a personal creative activity to refresh and inspire yourself.
•Company is continually taking on feedback to make it easier to get things done and be a better place to work.
cons:
•Often feels chaotic, disorganised and difficult to get things done, meaning there is less time to spend on designing which can impact on quality of output. This is mostly due to design being quite a new function within the UK business and this is actively being addressed.
•Can feel competitive rather than us all working as a team towards one goal, although this too is being addressed.
•A very meeting heavy culture.

pros: Depending on what position/role you are in, the work/life balance is pretty good. There are people in pockets of the company that are truly trying to make positive changes in the company.
cons: Performance Evaluations are biased against women, introverts and anyone not working on whatever new shiny object they've decided is the next great thing. My position works closely with the tech division. Their management is insane. My development team had a new director assigned and suddenly everyone on the team was on a performance improvement plan. They were yelled at on a daily basis, told not to work from home or take sick days, forced to work ridiculous hours at a table about 2 feet from the director (so he could see that they were there). Micromanagement doesn't begin to describe the situation. No one here understands Agile, they just like to use the word. Then, there's the issue of 20 people that try and do the exact same job. It's frustrating.

job_title: Senior Associate Software Engineer in Plano, TX
pros:
If you get lucky to get put on a high visibility project that has a big impact, you get a lot of recognition. 

Foosball tables, ping pong, and free snacks in Plano offices. 

A lot of the developers are really smart, and everyone that I know is happy to help explain things you might not understand. 

Work life balance depends largely on team. One of my team’s had high performing individuals that would come in at or before 9 and stay later than 5 on most days. My current team does 8am - 4pm.

Compensation (for college recruits at least) is very good
cons:
With the new “experience model” team system, Agile has turned into some type of pseudo mix of waterfall and agile. Business tries to dictate deadlines.

I know developers who work really hard (harder than me) and stay longer than me, but don’t get the proper recognition because either their managers aren’t good at giving it to them, or because the project they are on doesn’t get much visibility from higher ups. This impacts performance ratings/promotions. 

Teams that work on legacy tech/modernizing legacy tech don’t get much recognition.

review_title: Great for development, but not a long term gig
pros: There is a big focus on development in this role that allows you to constantly learn new skills and help you obtain your next role inside or outside of the company. Lots of focus on supporting local small businesses through resources and contracting them for catering and event services. You are also given a lot of freedom to connect with local non-profits by volunteering your time at work and offering financial literacy services. In addition to all of that it is still a customer facing role, so you get to meet a lot of people who live around the cafe and really hear what people need from the cafe. Capital One has the best benefits I've ever received from company from PTO to insurance.
cons: Not a lot of opportunities to move around the cafe organization unless you are willing to relocate. Merit increases are lower than any other position I've held at Capital One and there is no pay transparency. Leaders are great people, but are short sighted and don't take great care in anticipating how changes impact the front line and customers before they are implemented. Dissenting opinions are not received well by management.

review_title: It all depends on what department you're in
job_title: Principal Coordinator in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Management tends to be very flexible and allows for flexible work arrangements, either permanently or on a temporary basis.  This included either working a full day from home or a portion.  The gym at the main West Creek campus is great, never too crowded, knowledgeable trainers, a 5 minute or less walk from any building...and you can't beat the $15 per month fee.
cons: Some departments are either to advance in than others, and even then it depends on your manager.  I know of more than a few people who have been promoted 2+ times since they moved out of my department (within the past 2 years), but yet no one within my department has been promoted at all

job_title: Senior Process Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros: benefits are standard, health, 401k, paid days offs...  Unlimited sick days (even if your child is sick) for salaried employees.
cons:
Capital One didn't seem prepared to manage a staff virtually since the bulk of their staff is located in Virginia.  As part of the HSBC acquisition it was difficult to stay up to date with the fast pace environment.  Something as simple as phone etiquette during conference calls (one person speaking at a time) was a lost art; having a conference room in Virginia big enough to hold the required project team, with a phone (literally I was on calls that an iphone was being passed around to try and keep the conversation flowing. 

Tons of red tape for day to day operations, and the promotion process is unlike any organization I've ever worked for.  You have to have a champion submit your request for a promotion, then IF you are selected for the "stretch" opportunity you work the role for at least 12 months, at which point you will be told if you get the promotion or not and that is when you will see the increase in salary.

pros: Nice sites, nice work out facility, nice cafeterias.  For the most part, co-workers are all pretty decent too.  Rich Fairbanks seems like an honest,, decent person,  but he needs to have more sympathy for what people are going through with the Company he loves so much.
cons: The ever changing Managers you will have and shift bids.  You cannot have a normal work/life balance at this Company.  If you have kids, do not work here.  Also, very cliquey! This is due to the number of young Managers this Company promotes.  They must do this for monetary reasons.  Too many young kids running Capital One which makes it very High School-ish.  If you're not in a clique, you're not a "favorite."  Also the micro-managing is a joke and will drive you insane.

job_title: Operations Production Coordinator in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Compensation, Benefits, Work/Family Balance, PTO, culture of company, everything..... is amazing.
cons:
Once you are accept a position (ie. I am in the call center line of business in an hourly position) you will not be able to make more than 2 pay grade jumps (even if you are qualified fully for a salaried position in another line of business ie. IT). 

My advice: apply for what you plan on doing in the long run, this is an easy company to move around in (as long as you are in the same pay grade), but if you plan to get your foot in the door with an hourly position just to move to salaried because you are finishing your degree in a year, think again. You will have to leave and come back to Capital One to be taken seriously, just as I am in the process of doing. 

Some call center departments are being run to the ground, and floor managers don't always have best interest of their people at hand.

review_title: A bank trying to decide if it's a bank or a tech company
pros:
- Awesome place for new grads looking to start their careers with plenty of training in soft skills.
- Team members are usually super friendly and very bright, talented people.
- Great place to be cultured in data-driven decision making and dealing with a lot of data (but not to be confused with Big Data).
- Great work/life balance, but only if you choose to.
cons:
- Hit and miss for experienced hires due to a lack of career advancement opportunities.
- Performance review is a popularity contest as politics reign supreme.
- Most people managers lack leadership skills; some just bypass associate development altogether.
- Starting offer is competitive with market but low growth trajectory quickly erodes that position.

review_title: Capital One is a great place to work but it's not perfect.
pros:
*very collegial
*not your typical bank - culture is more like a consulting firm
*great place for a college hire to start their career in one of the many college development programs
cons:
*people management - some managers lack the training & tools to coach their teams effectively
*Need professional development programs for non-College hire associates
*Lack of Diversity 
*Selection process for a candidate is very rigorous and heavily focused on case interviewing for analyst candidates.  Does one's performance on a case dictate their success in the role? Is our process too rigorous where it could be screening out good candidates? Just because a person fails a case doesn't mean the person is not a great fit for Capital One.  They still maybe able to perform the core duties of the job.  They just need to sharpen their case interviewing skills and that only comes with practice and time.  That's not innate.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in McLean, VA
pros:
Benefits are good
Work life balance is possible
cons:
Misogynistic/Bro-culture and favoritism - despite there being a group centered around Women in Technology, the actual team dynamics are very different
Buzzwords are more important than good work
Quality work is not valued as much as who can peacock the best
Their recruiters will tell you what you want to hear to get you in the door instead of telling you what the job is really about
Very disorganized
A lot of bloated legacy systems manned by people who can't think outside their bubble
Not friendly or beneficial to engineers that aren't fresh out of college

pros: I never thought a big bank would feel like it cared about its employees, but Capital One does.  Great benefits, solid pay, flexible schedules, educational opportunities, great offices.  The leadership seems to have an eye on the future and doesn't get complacent for long, always looking on how to stay ahead.
cons: The year-end review process is a constant complaint at work.  Currently you're reviewing in "buckets" with people of a similar level, and on a curve, so some people are always going to be "exceptional" and some have to be "needs improvement."  They're working on fixing this, but for now it's the standard.  Also in some roles it's hard to find ways to move up the ladder, so you'll need to keep your ears open for opportunities if your department doesn't offer them.

pros: Its nice to know that you will never be stuck at work past 6 30 you get a lot of holidays off (paid if your full time) and some of the incentives you get are pretty nice.  Most full timers do not work weekends and they give you a decent amount of sick and vacation days.
cons: Corporate has no idea what lower level workers do and keep issuing more work for everyone without seeing if its possible for the people to do it.  Banking should be a fast quick process not filled with questions and looking up different things on multiple different systems to see if the customer needs another account.  If it was all on one system it would not be that complicated.  Managers also do not check what work each person does and one or two people will usually have to cover the work of four because two people wont do anything all day.

review_title: Smart people, nimble org but limited growth for non-superstars (80% of people)
job_title: Senior Business Manager in Richmond, VA
pros:
Very smart high calibre people to work with, at all levels in the company. CEO is a true visionary. 

Excellent work/office amenities and location flexibility. 

Nimble and high paced vs. traditional big banks, so quicker decision making and relatively less red tape. 

Logic and data driven thinking, resulting in rigorous strategies and decisions. This DNA runs across all levels (at least in credit card division). 

Focus on people development and training. Good internal training curriculums.
cons:
Career advancement dependent heavily on your manager and his manager. Perceptions matter much much more than your actual results. If you don't have a god father backing you at xcals you can't get promoted or get best ratings. 

Management shows much bias to develop and promote superstars (identified as top 10 pc), they will get all meaty projects even when other qualified people exist. It's a vicious cycle. Unless you are superstar you will stagnate at mgr/sr.mgr levels and get frustrated. 

Pay is below par at most levels below sr.director+, so you will see more attrition at junior levels and almost no voluntary attrition at vp+ levels.

review_title: Long hours; only got 30 min lunch break, and the lead teller was a bully
job_title: Bank Teller in Carle Place, NY
pros: Free bank account that's about it I can't say anything else otherwise I would be lying maybe it was just the branch I worked for but capital one has given me a bad taste in my mouth.
cons: As a teller you can't sit down; the customers were some of the rudest people I have ever met. Especially the drivers at the drive up window they would throw their check at you and expect you to know what kind of transaction they wanted like if your'e some kind of psychic. We would always run of out 100$ bills and we had to keep our cash drawers no more than 3K. So if a customer wanted a big withdrawal we would have to wait a while until the slow lead teller decided she wanted to get you more money. The cash advance machine was ALWAYS broken,As well as the ATM machine that was on the outside of the building. But some how getting a new coffee machine was not a problem. The manager was almost never there. So the lead teller would take it upon herself to "try to run the bank" she had a nasty attitude and talked down to everyone.

pros: A flexible work routine that helps achieve a healthy work life balance. Good pension and training opportunities, with generous access to external courses too. London Office location is great.
cons: Bombarded by internal events and staff change emails. Get at least one a month announcing department reorgs. I’ve never been in a business of so much change. It’s a who you know place. Working really hard isnt enough, you have to be constantly talking your successes up to the right people which can get tiring and uncomfortable. Despite an amazing location, the London Office has very little energy, it feels like we are a satellite office for Nottingham, where all the decisions are made and majority of leadership are based. Travelling up every week is the only way to stay connected and have a presence. A very slow pace of innovation and lots of complexity, which wears some people out and they leave.

pros: Benefits are okay. Take advantage of tuition reimbursement there. Most of the intelligent people there do. Other standard benefits.
cons:
It was all roses to start, but I quickly learned plenty of obstacles had to be hurdled daily to get my job done. Had to seek out information, seek out the right people with said information, get approvals within and outside my department, even outside the state, for small things. Those in mid and upper management seem to be clueless and out of touch. As long as the company is making progress, damn the stock prices. My stock there was originally $80/share, but fell to $40 over five years. 
They often seek barely warm bodies with a few active brain cells for management positions and these people are ill equipped. Many of the managers could use communication skills and human communication 101 lessons.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tampa, FL
pros:
Seems like a wonderful company to work for.  Everyone I met at the open house that they had for us new employees had nothing but praise for Capital One.  I will work from home, they even supply a computer and all necessary equipment and the job will start at 13.03 per hour.  They put 3% into your 401k.  All medical, dental, vision are available after 6 months.  WOW!  I can't wait to start work for them!  I am really excited about this job.  Working Monday thru 
Friday (weekends off).  They have various shifts available.  I picked 12pm to 7pm with an hour off for lunch!  Woopie!  My favorite shift.  I have ams available and evening available.
cons: There is absolutely nothing negative to say about this wonderful employer.  I'm in love with my job already.  I always remember that if your love what you are doing, you never have to work a day in your life!

pros: Tuition benefits, vacation days, retirement benefits are great for employees. Company also has great competitive products.
cons: There is no balance between work and personal life. It was always a hassle to request day offs. Employees works 6 days a week, at least in retail branches,. Company or at least my district terminated people left and right. I saw 7 people let go with in one year that I worked for the company. There is no sense of job security here. I felt as if managers are not interested in developing their employees or may be they are just not competent enough to know how to develop associate and employee retention is just not their concern. There was no Exit interview when I left.

pros:
Standard Benefits (Not flexible credits like other companies)
3 weeks vacations to start
Free parking
cons:
You can find something better
Very low pay, way below average.
For a bank you would think they would be organized but NOT AT ALL! Nobody knows anything, very little training and they expect you to know everything once you get on the phone. 
Higher managements pretend to be friendly to your face but talks bad about everyone.
Team managers are disorganized, not tech savvy at all some of them are still writing things down instead of organizing themselves digitally. 
Some managers will talk bad about people on their own team and they think we don't hear them. They even gossip about each other and put each other down in front of people.
Bilingualism doesn't exist over there, people that are supposed to be bilingual are not, one of them was promoted to management and is doing a horrible job and is the one that gossip the most.
There is no HR on site, when they come they have the biggest attitude.
Many people have been fired for the most ridiculous things including personal stuff that is nobody's business.
They have no ethics and people that run this place have no experience.

review_title: Good benefits and people but bad company policies and managment
job_title: Fraud Investigator in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Great teamwork between coworkers in completing work and everyone on team always willing to help and was very nice so created great inner working environment.  Benefits were very good compared to other companies that I have worked for with good health premiums and stock purchase perks.
cons: Hours very long and not consistent from day to day.  Offered flex schedule but did not really matter how early you came in, if the rest of your team came in later you would still be there late.  Workload very unreasonable for such a small group and company made little effort to help struggling departments shift work load.  Very little work/life balance and pay was well below what could be paid for similiar job at other companies.  Education assistance also not very good with only a yearly payout of $5000/yr which does not reallly pay for much with rising tuition costs.

job_title: Capital One Front Line Manager Call Center in Irving, TX
pros:
-Great Benefits (medical, dental, stock purchase, 401k, vision)
-Good Training (both instructor led and online
cons: Capital One Bank is a good place to work until it is not. Leadership has no problem spending money, celebrating, and going out of their way to entice their non-exempt staff to work excessive overtime. Capital One Bank has a new org chart every 4-6 months, so you will spend a lot of time feeling like you are spinning your wheels. As I mentioned before they don't mind spending money, they will spend it to keep you and spend it to get rid of you. Lots of lay-offs. Mid level management gets things done by turning entry level managers against each other. Very cut throat.

review_title: Capital One Retention and Customer Service  Departments
pros: It was a paycheck with good benefits while it lasted
cons:
Full disclosure - I last worked at Capital One in Tampa, FL in 2004. 2012 is the last year in the drop down box. I am biased, not because of Tampa location closing, but more because of how they went about it.
My cons of working at Capital One, while I was there was there was no communication between management and employee. We also had mandatory overtime every week (still not sure if that was legal). I don't mind working overtime and usually did even before it was mandatory, but many people pushed back against it. People fell in line when jobs were threatened and a few were let go (officially for other things, not for refusing to work overtime). We never had time to breath between phone calls, usually 300 or more calls in queue. We were "encouraged" to work through our breaks and lunches. The last 12 to 14 months before the location closed became very oppressive.

job_title: Customer Experience Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: Cap one has excellent benefits, PTO, monthly incentives, etc. Also tuition reimbursement and a nice corporate office; paid days to have fun for team building
cons: To advance in that company is such a struggle. They truly embody the idea of kissing butts to get ahead. Superiors are afraid of your greatness and like to keep you down if they believe you have a lot of potential to grow. A lot of overworking and underpaying. Be prepared to wear a lot of hats which can be beneficial however delegating work because you have too much work due to a chaotic business model is crazy! They are almost militant. They try blinding you with a culture like you matter when they truly have the same goal of any firm, to maximize profit. They will lead you on to believe you are doing great work but then pass you over for someone less qualified because they may be easy to manipulate. Worse thing than a boss who doesn't care is a boss who acts like they care just because they feel like it's their job. Most employees are dissatisfied and feel pressured in a lot of ways.

review_title: Good place to work, but no job is secure
pros: Capital One has great people that are smart and fun to work with.  There are good opportunities for young ,smart and talented employees that want to learn and have a meaningful impact on results.  Compensation is great -- better at most levels than a comparable company.  While most work hard, the environment is flexible - which makes it easy to have a good work life balance.
cons: The company has a Very Unfair process for recognizing individuals for promotions and performance reviews.  Managers jointly decide on all staff  --- creating a highly political environment where strong managers get their  staff good ratings and promotions and weak ones don't.  It is always hard to understand why some get promoted and others loose their job. The announcements are always a suprise.  Also, executive management views employees  at all levels as completely disposable.  No job is secure, regardless of performance.  Politics rules the day.

review_title: Can be a GREAT place to work!
pros: Opportunities to network across financial services divisions, positive environment for collaboration, focus is on hiring top talent, and a wide array of special events to spotlight the employee.
cons:
Focus is on too many projects. Each division has their goals to achieve, which requires cross functional teams. The result is managers are mired in too many meetings and the time it takes to complete is lengthy. Most projects take 8 to 12 months to complete because of all the levels to approve and committees that need to review. The focus is on top talent, but there are some employees that have come on board from acquisitions and have their heels dug in on how processes should be even though they are outdated compared to the marketplace. The recognition program is focused mainly on front line staff, leaving out the mid level managers 
who feel sandwiched between some employees who feel entitled to be recognized and their manager who continue to push down on mid level managers for recognizing staff without giving them recognition.

review_title: IT Senior Manager - Good Company - but no loyalty
pros: Good benefits and decent yearly bonuses, lots of time off.  Good work/life balance.  Decent Training Opportunities.  Lost of smart people who seem to want to do the right thing.  great work facilities.  Lots of focus on families and personal interests.
cons: Stacked ranking stinks!  Basically everyone falls into 4 buckets, Exceptional, Very Strong, Strong and Inconsistent/Need Action.  The problem is that their are required percentages in all 4 buckets including the inconsistent so even you have a high performing team, someone is going to be forced into the bottom bucket!  Also, there is no loyalty!  Been there for more than 10 years and was laid off with at least 100 others in IT without good reason!

review_title: 6 months in and still doesn't feel like I work for a bank
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
Capital One's Technology department is young, diverse and very tech-forward. Feels as current with the tech scene as any startup I've worked in—from the open office culture to the product development methodologies to the actual tech stacks we use.

I also very much appreciate their hiring process, which focuses as much on your character and chemistry with your potential teammates as your technical chops. I enjoy the people I work with now even more than close friends whose companies I've worked for in the past.
cons:
Capital One's non-tech departments have a little ideological catching up to do. Not a lot, but some.

There's definitely a gap in understanding between the agile/lean methodology of the tech department and the more numerical timeline-/goal-oriented mentality of the company at large.

Luckily, it's not a conflict or a war—just difference in backgrounds. One that I believe can (and will) be overcome with more communication between the two.

review_title: At first ot was awesome now its just BLAH..
pros:
Benefits are awesome..
People are great..
Environment is great..
Pay is great..
cons:
Management is horrible..
VERY unorganized..
Stuff changes every hour..
More focused on what other companies do and not focused on the real problems in our own back yard.. 
Trying to compete with other places but really do not have our stuff together..
Home loans dept IS A JOKE.. 
The managers ect do not know what they are doing but exepects the csr to know.. 
The managers go to all of these meetings for nothing..
They dont care about your well being..
Its work now we dont care about what you have going on attitudes..
They turn over rate is extremely high here.. So if you have a family or relying on a place to work for a long time. Do not apply for this place. The only way you will make it here is if you're friends with someone ect.. I dont like to walk on egg shells at my job due to fearing my badge will not swipe. I am currently looking for another job..

pros: Capital One is a flexible work environment.  There is freedom in how you spend your day and there are opportunities to expand your knowledge in different areas and work towards various professional certifications.
cons: Capital One seems to have had its heyday in the late 90s and early 2000s.  Those who were hired recently (within the last three years) see little opportunity for growth/advancement on a macro level within the company or in creativity on an individual role level.  Currently, the company is more interested in maintaining the status quo rather than building creative or exciting products.  Also, due to the compensation structure and performance management cycle, promotion and salary are based almost completely on an employee's direct manager (who may or may not have been involved in that employee actual performance) instead of how they actually performed.  Therefore, doing an excellent job or going above an beyond does not equal promotion or high ratings.

pros: The compensation and benefits are competitive to above average. You get plenty of vacation days, there is interesting work to be done if your department lets you. It's not a place where you have to sit around to log extra hours in the office for appearance.
cons: The main problem with Capital One is the professionalism of management. You really have to be on the lookout to see if colleagues are undermining you. I was floored by some of the discussions that I was privy to regarding both business and HR policies. There are absolutely no boundaries to what action someone will take. This issue is part of the culture at Capital One in general. They have put some additional controls in place since the early to mid 00s but it's still kind of a wild west type of place. If you get the right department and manager, it's great. However, there are just so many weak managers in general that at some point you're going to get a bad one.

pros: Some managers appreciates employees and recognizes good work. Nice campus and benefits.
cons: Some areas are political and advancement is difficult.  Some managers are non aggressive, and sometimes fail to execute on projects & some managers are too demanding.  Lots of executive layering and often layoff at that level are frequent. Lots of long hours and as a salaried person it doesn't balance out.  Some areas are in need of stronger more knowledgeable management.  Lots of meetings and little time to complete work task.  Not all areas have a lot of on the job formal training. Most training is sitting side by side with other associates and this is not the best most efficient way of learning new material.

pros: Nice working environment and some good technical guys there. some interesting projects.
cons: there is most certainly a core clique of people who create a campaign of propaganda and most certainly do not like honest opinions. If you speak your mind regards project deliverables, strategy or staff members who are clearly playing a game then prepare to have your card marked and be rounded on by the stasi "This is the cap One way" police. Long time serving staff at Cap One have been slowly brainwashed by the Capital one ethics. The one upmanship approach is encouraged, staff are passive aggressively managed out of the business if the face or opinion does not fit. Many very talented people joining from external organisations rarely stick around as they see and experience the wrath of this unhealthy culture. On the outside it looks like fun and enjoyable but underneath there is a very protective and somewhat nieve group of people who only care about how good you can make them look. Very divisive and intrinsic.

pros: With the current focus, if you have a love for both finance and tech, then this is the place for you.  The old school Wall Street personality doesn't fit in here.  You will be rewarded if you are able to develop change in the company.  If you are more of an entrepreneur and have foresight to see how to transform ideas into reality, and can visualize and communicate steps along the way, then you will be successful here. The majority of associates  here are very open to sharing their expertise to help you along the way.
