If you're not open to teaching or learning from others, regardless of your years of experience, then this is not the place for you.
cons:
You really need to self promote here and be a 
Self starter.  If you want something done, you have to do the majority of the work yourself until you can gain momentum. It is a very risk averse company, so you will need to jump through a lot of hoops and beurcracy to make your ideas a reality.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros:
The new HQ in Tysons looks amazing (like an actual tech office) and certain locations like Richmond have actual campuses. 

• Decent 401k match, health/dental/vision
• Lots of empowerment when it comes to leading the work
• Impactful work – everyone genuinely come in quite motivated

If you land yourself with a good team, you can find Capital One to be quite amazing.
cons:
After making it onto the list of top companies to work for, we saw our budget, snacks, and office perks pretty much cut overnight. 

NY office saw one snack each day disappear and never restocked again. We went from fully stocked draws to pretty much nothing but Reeses cups. Some of the Virginia offices saw snacks completely disappear. 

What kind of company advertise themselves as a 'tech company' without free food?

Meeting rooms have become non existent as senior leadership began making their own personal offices. 

Management have become less and less visible, and the new hires have become more and more like those of traditional / irrelevant companies. The once young and fresh vibe is disappearing, and the company is now filled with people who came from failed startups and places like Barnes and Nobles. 

Capital One just can't compete with new tech talent, and they simply cannot offer high enough compensation. 

Educational benefits are lost, and promotions feels incredibly biased. 

Individual contributor work is not recognized. There is lots of talk about doing things but nothing ever gets done. Bureaucracy is endless and only getting worst as we bring in the more older and traditional way of management. 

Work culture can be a hit or miss. You can work late or you can have nothing to do at all. Two years ago, Capital One had an amazing work life balance. Today, not so much. Vacations are tracked like hawks and you cannot take a vacation without somebody calling your personal phone. 

The moral is extremely low. People are dropping like flies, and there haven't been a single day without another 'Goodbye' email.

review_title: Great place to learn, tough place to grow
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in McLean, VA
pros: People at Capital One at all levels are intelligent, innovative, and hard-working.  Information is open and easily shared across departments.  I rarely encountered people who were an impediment to my work.  Also, employees are given an immense level of responsibility, even in the early stages of their career.  It's a great place to learn and develop as a productive employee and easy to deliver positive contributions. They also encourage job rotations across departments, which I found an excellent way to learn about the company.
cons: They pay is low, especially for the D.C. area.  It is also difficult to be promoted from Analyst to Manager, even after 5+ years of experience and an MBA.  Part of that is due to a preference of hiring managers from the outside, and part of that is limiting promotions to only 10% of the analyst group each year.

review_title: Diversified and open-minded company, but workload is overwhelming
Good place to start your career
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in McLean, VA
pros:
ADP is great way to meet new people, gain skills, and learn about the business
Employees are the most important part of the company
Work life balance is fantastic
People are very bright, very credentialed (MBA’s, consulting exp, elite universities etc…)
Other employers understand the level of talent of ex-Capital One associates
cons:
The company isn’t growing anymore, but there is massive pressure from Wall St to grow profits
There are fewer dollars for investment in business ideas or personal growth
Perpetual reorganizations; expect to get moved every 6-12 months (esp in Bank)
Projects take FOREVER to get done – get ready to sit in meetings to discuss planning a pre-planning meeting 
Annual review process is somewhere between ‘alright’ and ‘a mess’ 

Ultimately, your experience will be highly dependent on the specific team you are on. Some teams are growing quickly and have the support and visibility of senior leadership, others are not. Guess which type of team is more fun to be on.

pros: Hands down, it's the people. Capital One does a great job with diversity and inclusion. You work with all kinds of different people from all over the world and it's very rewarding.
cons: Overworked and underpaid is an Understatement. Call center managers are piled on and piled on and expected to balance entirely too much. The "free thinking" culture that is promoted is only a dream in the call centers. We are walking on egg shells each day as to not make a mistake and be "marked" by upper management. If your opinion doesn't match upper management, you get "redeployed". You are scheduled for mandatory meetings, some of which are all day long and then they send a survey out asking if you are visible to your team. It's an extremely stressful situation to work in.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great benefits, company activities, relief from boredom.
cons: Constant scrutiny, weekly report cards that can jeopardize your employment. You will be held accountable for things that are out of your control. If a customer is having s bad day and doesn't do backflips from the service you provide, it's your fault and you will be written up! If a customer is upset with the previous rep they talked to and they do a survey about being upset after they talked to you, you get the bad review on your record and can be written up! Three right ups for something stupid and you're fired! Be prepared to deal with pettiness and butt kissing! High turnover. On the flip side, if you work your butt off and customers refuse to complete surveys, you will go unnoticed. If you care enough not to rush a customer off of the phone, be prepared to get ding'd for long phone calls! You can't win!! If you can deal with constantly being judged and told how to do your job, this is the place for you!

review_title: An OK company that has cool buildings
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Tysons Corner, VA
pros: The buildings in Tysons look beautiful on the inside. Definitely does not have a corporate vibe. Feels like an IT company in silicon valley. There's all sorts of unique and creative decorations, layouts, etc. They provide some free snacks and drinks.
cons: It all depends on your group since it's such a large company. From my experience, they have way too many software engineers, way too many cogs in a giant machine, and everything is too decentralized. Amazed that anything actually works, quite frankly. There was no vision, just myopic two week sprints, that were incredibly fast-paced. Hated the open layout concept. There are also too many H1B people working there, and they sometimes tended to group together and speak their own language. There was no strong sense of camaraderie among the team. Young people have some pros, but they also have some cons.

pros: Capital One has a strong culture of "Excellence and Do the right thing", providing a great work environment to develop and hone critical competencies, numerous development opportunities (large and small projects), while also understanding and promoting the balance between personal life and work.  It has been a great place to work for many years while I've progressed in many ways; I highly recommend working for Capital One.
cons: While working here for many years, our benefits and compensation felt like they were exceptional early on, but with the purchase of other banks they have been decreased in order to provide standard benefits across the board.  This, I'm sure, has occurred in many other corporations, but it would have been nice for the 'Maverick' of the financial industry to buck the trend and keep the high level of benefits and just extend them to new banks and employees.

review_title: Competitive salary and benefits, but sometimes too competitive to be productive
job_title: Senior Applications Developer/Manager in Plano, TX
pros:
Decent place to work with good salary and benefits like $1000 match on FSA, 7.5% 401K match, Stock purchase program etc. 
Great benefits in case of layoffs.
Good work/life balance. 
Convenient location and conveniences like gym and nurse practitioner on site.
cons:
They try to hire really good people based on aptitude, but not enough focus on technical skills. 
A very competitive culture that fosters distrust and people always doing this for visibility and getting good points for year end appraisal. 
Forced rankings in the year end performance process. 
In IT, too many people who talk a lot and come up with list of bullet points, but very few people who understand technology and can help when there are problems. 
In IT, too many managers who seem more interested in climbing the corporate ladder, but lack any strong technical background.

review_title: Don't count on getting that $1100 monthly bonus
pros: Cardholders are nice compared to other companies I have worked for.  Few irate callers.
cons: HIGH HIGH TURNOVER. I asked one of the reps there why there is so few people and I was told "people leave". They present it as a simple job in training, but there are potentially thousands of complex details and you don't know them going in and are marked off on them. Management evaluates 5 calls per month and you don't find out until the last day of training that you have to score an 84 consistently to keep your job. They say there is no script but you are shown a basic one in training.  What they want is much more than that, and if you don't do things in a specific sequence they mark you off, and of course it is subjective according to who is grading you. I think it is so they don't have to pay you the $1100 per month bonus that they dangle for those who score 100%.

pros: They have great benefits. The incentives are great. Order food, mostly pizza, but I love pizza so that's fine with me lol
cons: Shows a lot of favoritism!!! They put the wrong people in training or nesting positions. If you don't kiss *** then u will not get picked for anything no matter how much you know or how long you been there. QA is too over the top with grading, they nitpick over everything on one call, grading is entirely too strict. They update policies and procedures almost everyday ( who does that)On almost every call you have to check policies and procedures to make sure nothing has changed which takes too much extra time. The nerve of them putting a limit on our talk time with all this extra unecessary things they want us to do while the customer is on the line. Capital One really needs to get it together, that's more than likely why they have a high turnover rate, no one I began training with is there anymore.

review_title: Great face lift to site overall, compensation for working hard. Not so good.
job_title: Customer Coordinator II in Las Vegas, NV
pros: On site gym and cafeteria
cons: When capital one acquired HSBC in May 2012, everything changed for the better, especially with the $10 Million face lift the call center got, however the company failed to budget for annual pay raises! From May 2012- Sept 2014 (under Capital One's management), I received a total of $.35 raise. This was after 3 years of service! Then when inquiring why we weren't brought up to Capital One pay scale for same position withing the company elsewhere, we were advised it was to keep benefit cost down!  When your working full time and paying $600 per month for on-site daycare and $500 for a family of 5 to have medical benefits, this smaller hourly wage just wouldn't allow ends to meet financial, which ultimately forced me to quit my job.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tampa, FL
pros:
Some good things about working at a Capital One call center were:

- Somewhat flexible hours
- Decent pay
- Excellent benefits
cons:
The environment is very stressful and most managers were very keen on making you listen to your worst calls. They put the customer first in service which is a good practice and there was a lot of corporate mission statement buzzwords being thrown around and there was a lot of talk about how great it was to work for them; however, under the syrupy film of good nature that the management applied, they were not interested in the employees well being outside of throwing snack at them. 

I think a lot of the cons in working for them is that they are a company that is trying to change how they operate by building on top of old practices. These practices don't align with the new warm and fuzzy feels they are trying to portray.

review_title: New Executive; The Pluses of A Large Bank With The Agility & Talent of A Growth/Tech Co.
pros: Extremely robust talent sourcing, management and development process; acute focus on developing existing and future leaders within the company and in the communities where we have a presence; top-notch benefits; respectful and diverse culture; numerous opportunities to promote and pivot one’s career in different directions to stay energized and keep learning vs being in a dead-end job; inspiring, influential and energetic leaders; and flexibility to work in different geographies.
cons: Too early to have witnessed any but the methodical interview process can certainly weed out those who are impatient and be taxing while one is in an existing role at a different company. Applicants need to really appreciate that the lengthy process with numerous rounds of interviews is deliberate to ensure proper fit and consistency of talent while also offering the candidate exposure to a number of the company’s employees in different departments.

pros: Oh sure it's great at first... Don't be fooled by the recreational activities they furnish, trust me, there's a catch
cons: I am having my job threatened because I went home today very, VERY sick... With the flu. I brought my thermometer in and took my temp (which has been in the 101_102 range all day ) right in front of them. I feel that i need to be hospitalized... I've been very ill for last 3 days. I was told before leaving work that this will result in a written warning, and my attendence better be perfect for the next 2 months... And i am an employee (contractor) who  comes in an hour early almost everyday and has shown a lot of initiative. One of the occurences i received was for leaving work (when my trainer told me to) for 2 hours to go to an urgent care for a kidney infection, which i came back to work and worked through and i had a dr. Note. . I am so sick i should be hospitalized right now, and instead of taking care of myself, I'm laying here seriously ill worried about losing my job if i don't go to work tomorrow, and my temp is still 101.3 and i feel aweful. It's abusive and inhumane.

pros:
Brilliant, ethical leadership; emphasis on doing the right thing; work/life balance commitment is strong; forward-looking innovation; uses fact-based decision-making; fail forward philosophy - okay to make mistakes, but must own resolutions.
Great benefits; they value continuous learning; open to internal job changes after you have a history of performance of course.
Great colleagues; positive atmosphere; generally no backstabbing
Flexibility on hours and locations (on-site workstation, flexible seating around campus, work from home if needed);
cons:
When business strategies changes there can be job realignments, redeployments, and/or separations.  Know it and be aware. Not particularly often but can be suddenly rolled out.  They are open with information about the strategy changes.
They still use a form of the old GE performance review process. It's part of the culture, but behind the times. Don't expect it to change easily.

review_title: Don't work here if you have career goals
job_title: Business Analysis Manager in Plano, TX
pros:
Above average salary and benefits; cool campuses; flexible work schedule/PTO (all pros apply to salaried full-time associates; no comment otherwise) 

Great place if you want to put forth a mediocre effort for a consistent paycheck with no personal or professional growth. Otherwise the worst place I could ever imagine.
cons:
Everything else. Leadership is terrible. They don't listen to their people. Performance management is super backwards. Nothing ever gets done. When something does get done, it's extremely slowly, and it's almost always a zero risk, tiny reward initiative. Risk tolerance is 0. All about making each other feel good and giving participation trophies - coaching is non existent as a result. You only find out what you can do better at twice a year. Good ideas are turned down because they're "too hard" or "too much effort."

Overall - insanely toxic environment that will kill the winner inside you. Also the lack of actual innovation and speed is going to get the company taken down by an new competitor in the next 10 years unless acquisition saves it.

review_title: Company can be too smart for their own good.
job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Plano, TX
pros:
-Decent Pay/Benefits
-Flexible work arrangements
-High Quality Co-Workers
-Nice Facilities
-Spends money to keep up moral
cons:
-People tend to over analyze projects and people can make analysis match the desired outcome
-Horrible IT (It's a wonder this company is still in business considering how much they rely on IT)
-Promotions are very political (If you have a manager who won't fight for you then forget about getting promoted. Also, young analyst are promoted based on seniority. Once you have 18 months, you get promoted no matter how much you suck)
-Good analysts do not necessarily make good managers. People managers should have people skills!
-Company seems like they do not learn from previous mistakes. They seem to be willing to go down the same path that previously got them in trouble. Especially if their has been a change in management.

pros: I have worked with Capital One for many years now, started out as a associate on the phones and worked my way up to management. They really do have a great culture, management tries to make it fun and the benefits are great. 12 weeks PAID maternity leave, there is paternity leave that can be split up as you want, insurance is good, 3 weeks vacation starting out and you earn more the longer you stay.
cons:
As with every job you have politics, it is all about who you know.  If you work for this company make sure you network and DO NOT burn bridges. The Home Loans side has org changes often and have had reduced headcount and increased headcount countless times. The Auto side is a much more stable side of the business. 

Pay for the tenured associates is on the low end, so for anyone coming in new they typically make more starting out than someone who has been in the role for example 2-3 years.

review_title: Nice place to work, but watch your back .
pros: Very diverse , friendly atmosphere , & nice pay . The benefits are great & the pto offered is nice .
cons: They provide you with paid training , but once you get on the floor the information obtained during training isn't always valid . They tell you to do your own research . So, it doesn't matter what you learned or advice given by managers . If you receive the wrong information, and you Do what you're told, you're ultimately at fault . So that raises the question what's the purpose of the training and managers ? It's unfair to get fired , without previous warnings, for something you were taught . It's not a bad place to work, you just have to watch your own back bc clearly you can't depend on anyone else to guide you .

review_title: Talknology and definitely not  a Technology company
pros: Base Pay & Benefits, Resources at your disposal, like Mac, AWS and exposure every enterprise software you can imagine as a techie.
cons:
I've worked in technology companies all my life before joining C1 and trust me, there's not a single trait in this company to qualify remotely as tech company.

 * So called, distinguished engineers who hardly codes
* Too much politics with way too many CBS walking around thriving on Here-say technique.  Lies and un-ethical behavior during appraisal/calibrations
* Awesome vision from top management but missed opportunity because of too many C grade players in middle management who believes in cronies culture

review_title: Constant org changes, good work-life balance
pros: Good overall work-life balance, good benefits. Job became nebulous and difficult to perform in the wake of so many organizational and mission changes.
cons:
Extremely difficult to get a promotion. The process expects that you work at the next level (in a "stretch role") for at least six months, sometimes a year, without any increase in pay. Additionally, the process states that there must be a need for someone at the next level in order for a position to be open. But since you're already doing the job while you're at the lower level, there's never a need to promote you or pay you more. Massively unfair catch-22. 

Nearly constant org changes. Very little value put on consistency of management presence -- it wasn't unusual for people to have 5 or more managers in a single year. The Virginia sites seem unable or unwilling to work with other sites across the nation. The culture on the Capital One campus in VA is strong, but they did not know how to make that culture work outside of VA.

job_title: Client Service Associate in New Orleans, LA
pros: The pros that I saw when I started with the company have gone away.  With the unnecessary changes to management leadership has driven the good managers and employees out and created a negative experience.
cons:
Racist and sexist managers who target you, so much for bringing in diversity champions as managers.
Only concerned about metrics and not actual production or employees.
Overly political in performance management, current system is a joke and only benefits those that management likes.  Your peers can rate you highly but if your manager doesn't like you then you're screwed.
The company only cares about you if you are located in certain areas of the country, those locations with the greatest perks shows you who they care about and want to be.
Upper management tends to think down on the rank and file employee and seems to only say things to quite the masses but not deliver on those promises.

review_title: Live in DC metro, Get paid like you live in Birmingham, AL
pros: Company has some very smart people and has upgraded finance talent over the last few years.
cons: If you work in capital markets / risk you will not be compensated appropriately.  You would be better off looking for jobs in the South or Midwest - the pay is the same.  The company's high turnover in these roles is driven by poor / inexperienced management (in some cases), poor compensation, and poor work / life balance (in many cases driven by lack of or undeveloped processes).

pros: Treasury at Capital One is filled with amazing potential.  The excitement is so thick you can feel it from everyone.   The innovative approach pioneered by the card group flows throughout the organization.  Almost everyone is supportive and encourages using the consultative approach and adapting new practices for the improvement of the bank.
cons: Management is too 'old school' bank focused.  There is a glacial pace around innovation that is extremely contrasted with the card side of the bank.  Management is quick to use buzzwords and speak the language of design thinking, agile methods, but when a decision point is reached the team reverts back to traditional, waterfall style management.  This lack of real innovation is coupled with a horrible political management style that is promotes through who you know more than what you produce.  It is a shame because there is so much potential waiting to explode out of the commercial bank the tension is exhausting.  The better team is small business.

pros: Treasury at Capital One is filled with amazing potential.  The excitement is so thick you can feel it from everyone.   The innovative approach pioneered by the card group flows throughout the organization.  Almost everyone is supportive and encourages using the consultative approach and adapting new practices for the improvement of the bank.
cons: Management is too 'old school' bank focused.  There is a glacial pace around innovation that is extremely contrasted with the card side of the bank.  Management is quick to use buzzwords and speak the language of design thinking, agile methods, but when a decision point is reached the team reverts back to traditional, waterfall style management.  This lack of real innovation is coupled with a horrible political management style that is promotes through who you know more than what you produce.  It is a shame because there is so much potential waiting to explode out of the commercial bank the tension is exhausting.  The better team is small business.

job_title: Senior Operations Coordinator in Wilmington, DE
pros: I started with Capital One when they purchased ING Direct - I was there during transitional times, which were followed by prosperous years and culminated with my lay-off in 2018 and reorganization of the investing department - I have nothing but love and it still remains the best workplace I have ever been a part of, so much so that after I took severance I had to wait at least a year to reapply back to Capital One and you can bet I did! Managers on down to Customer Service all seem to have a calm coolness - the banking world can be so smug and it was refreshing to come to work each day. The work/life balance is one of my favorite parts - they believe a happy, healthy (mentally, physically & financially) are recipes for success & a sustainable business model.
cons: It was sometimes tough to get ahead in some departments - the beauty of Capital One is the ability for most associates to migrate inter-department & pickup valuable skills along the way, so there were always opportunities.

job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros:
I worked for Capital One as an analyst for several years, coming in straight from college.  The Analyst Development Program was a great way to make a transition to the "real world," get a lot of training and support, and meet many people throughout the company.  I felt like my managers cared about my development and provided great opportunities to succeed.
On a broader level, Capital One has a very collaborative culture.  Work/life balance was prized and easily obtained.  Pay and benefits were very good, especially for the Richmond area.  It is easy to switch teams if your current position is a bad fit, and that flexibility is supported by management.
cons:
Bureaucracy is a necessary evil, but that doesn't make it any less annoying.
People are smart, but this can also result in overly complex systems and processes.
There always seemed to be constant re-orgs that seemed disruptive and may or may not have actually achieved business objectives.

review_title: Cut pay for employees as profits skyrocket
job_title: Relationship Banker in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Very easy job. Have sales goals but they are generally easy to reach. 4 weeks vacation and great benefits.
cons: What's the point of having so much vacation if you can't afford to go anywhere? Incentives have been cut every year in half or more each time. The 2016 incentive cut makes it working here not a viable option for work for anyone that needs 35- 40k or higher. Upper management pretends to care and sends shoutouts for the highest achievers via email, but little else. The future of capital one is to go digital which means employment cuts. Automated teller machines and one to two employee branches are what you have to look forward to. Encouraged to train customers to be self sufficient so we are no longer needed. Bank profits were 4.4billion last year while capital one cut incentives for bankers by 10k a year.

pros: not any. it's so bad.
cons:
The issue with this business, is that associates are either managing too much, managing something they are not good at, or processes and setup at the business make it really hard to deliver results fast. AT THE SAME TIME, managers do not acknowledge this fact, continue to place harsh, unrealistic, and sometimes unsensible expectations on associates, and blame the associates for not working hard enough. These insufficiencies are well obvious in the day-to-day operation of the business. How can leaders blatantly neglect these fundamental challenges the business is going through? This is what pissed us off and why morale is low. What's so difficult about dividing the work a little more fairly? What's so difficult about putting the right person at the right role? What's so difficult about letting go some of your unreasonable expectations? And what's so difficult about reshuffling certain personnel (especially certain leaders) off their current role?

Leaders who are trying to make a change, I really hope you take a look at this. No one dares to say this cuz if they did, chances are they will get the blame for being not good enough and risk getting fired. We don't even trust the anonymous surveys to be anonymous.

review_title: Great company, but take note of recent changes in 2017 & 2018
pros: Atmosphere is great for millenials, healthy living focus (cafes and initiatives), fantastic health benefits, visually pleasing campuses, relaxed dress, lots of groups and events, many genuinely great coworkers, as much learning and development as you could possibly want, etc.
cons: Recent layoffs and cost cutting measures across Financial Services (includes Small Business, Auto, Mortgage, Consumer and Lending). Capital One is also a hard place to get things done. Lots of disarray and many employees, especially at higher levels, are very overworked. The performance management cycle is the absolute worst thing about this company, hands down.

review_title: Great tech company in downtown SF
job_title: Principal Data Scientist in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I've worked at Capital One in San Francisco for almost 2 years now, and my time here has been incredibly good. 

The office space in SF is really impressive: 4 floors, multiple kitchens, user testing lab, ping pong, and game room, happy hour bar, and a very long etcetera. 

Colleagues are great too, having worked at other places, I can say Capital One is full of nice people willing to help out, and unlike other places, personal egos are not running the business. 

Unmatched flexibility, amazing work-life balance, really good opportunities to move sideways or up the ladder, managers trust on your craft and trips to other offices namely in NYC and Washington DC finalize an amazing package to join this great company.
cons: As with any organization this size, expect a little bit of politics here and there. Nothing too bad, actually maybe better than some much smaller startups.

review_title: Not as great a place to work as you are encouraged to believe
pros:
benefits are good and on par with marketplace
physical workplace environment is very good 
salary compensation if coming from outside is comparable or above market
however, once you are inside the compensation process is extremely slow and does not keep pace 
coworkers are among some of the best people
cons:
performance management process leaves much to be desired  
little chance for promotion unless have management support
favors youthful go getters willing to work long hours (60-100 plus hrs per week)
can "try"  next level role without pay or title change 6-18 months and still not get promotion if  management does not agree or they eliminate role/department
work life balance doesn't truly exist below management level 
open culture only works if you agree; woe to those who question you'll find yourself moved out

review_title: Great company; tough culture in some divisions
pros: 5 stars for the company itself as far as level of technology and the services available to employees which is quite impressive for a company of this size.  You will have your hands in all sorts of technologies right from the start.  Benefits are great...pay is ok
cons: Reviews are brutal in that they pit employees of like title against each other with only your manager to fight for you.  It is tough to get very far if you are in shared technology services unless you have been there a long time or are Indian.  Not enough time to learn technologies properly....more interested in being first to launch.

job_title: Segment Lead, Marketing Operations in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Capital One was a great working experience. The people are collaborative, the West Creek campus is beautiful (tree house and all), they truly "get" the mobile work environment and promote it, and processes are mostly clearly defined (at least more so than you would expect from such a giant organization), communication is open and honest, and they take the time to train mangers how to lead mindfully.
cons: As with many large corporations, there is a LOT of process to learn to get even the smallest item into market, and this takes a whole lot of time and meetings to accomplish. So it can be a bit frustrating moving at a snails pace. The organization was trying to become more Agile in it's digital development, but still had a bit of a hike to get there (and they might be there by now). Also, because of some development programs and the large number of contractors, your team changes constantly, sometimes mid project - so this can slow progress some as well.

review_title: One of the best companies for software engineers in Nottingham.
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Nottingham, England
pros:
The benefits offered are among the best available for the area.

You get 10% time to learn or work on something that interests you.

You have access to many online courses and books plus a wide community of developers.

Great facilities really good canteen with multiple meal options every day.

As a software engineer you get the latest MacPro, wide monitor, standing desk, unlimited coffee and a really comfy chair.

A good work life balance flexible to accommodate most child care commitments.

Management encourage associates to get involved in corporate responsibility events.
cons:
Getting used to all the acronyms will take you a few months (but there is always someone willing to help!)

No parking available on site for most associates. On the other hand, support for travel to work is good e.g. NCT, Tram, cycle.

review_title: The best second-choice place to start a career
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in McLean, VA
pros:
Experience in Capital One's Information Based Strategy (using lots of data and number crunching to optimize business decisions) teaches skill sets that are easily transferable to a variety of industries and are in demand by other employers.

Very good benefits: 401k match, 3 weeks vacation (but no one keeps track of how much vacation time you use), modern facilities.

Above-average work-life balance, however it can vary from team to team.  You can expect 3 to 4 60+ hour weeks each year, but the late hours are often justified and the extra effort is usually rewarded.

People have a human side which makes the office an entertaining place to be.
cons:
People are high caliber (top 20%) but aren't truly elite.  A previous commenter said that Capital One tends to attract people who didn't receive offers or washed out of top tier banks and consulting firms, and I have to agree with him/her.

The company is big, hierarchical and slow to adapt (still uses Windows XP, MS Office 2003 in 2011).  Assignments tend to be boring, formulaic, and get bogged down in bureaucracy.   Middle management obsesses over meaningless analytic details.

Limited space, don't expect a cubicle or desk.  You will have a corner of a table in a small meeting room that may or may not have a window.

There's the potential to come up with a big idea and drive it into market, but you'll spend most of your time jumping through analytic and procedural hoops that have little tangible benefit.

The procedures and infrastructure act as a crutch and don't offer the same learning opportunities that may exist in less structured organizations.

Promotions are frequent (30% annual promotion rate, above-average workers are promoted every 2 years) however they tend to be promotions in name only, as people continue to do the same type of work that they were doing before.

Job roles have become so specialized that few people have the opportunity to see how the full value chain is integrated.

Company's culture is dominated with empty buzzwords like "value chain"

Can be clique-y and some people tend to hold a grudge, although this is true everywhere.

review_title: Takes a Specific Kind of Person
job_title: IT Applications Manager in Richmond, VA
pros:
Working at Capital One was great, at the start.  My team was friendly, the people were good to work with; but the on-boarding was horrible.

The pay, benefits and ancillary perks were amazing there, as was the cafeterias that were available to eat at.
cons:
There is a complete disconnect between upper management and everyone else regarding job expectations and performance; leading to a ton of confusion as to just how you're supposed to perform so that you get a good rating and bonus at the end of the year.  It seems entirely subjective, from the outside looking in.

They treat their full time people like temporary hires, including moving you from one location in the country to another, and then eliminating your job.  The morale seems to go down further every 6-10 months, as they announce more layoffs, excuse me, "redeployments", and as they reorganize constantly.

review_title: Good until I got laid off
pros: Great benefits and decent pay with year end bonuses and annual cost of living increase. Loved working here when I did. They encourage you to volunteer and take classes on campus to better yourself.
cons: Got re-deployed (laid off) and was told they would do anything to help you get re-hired. Applied for at least 15 jobs and only got one interview. All of the rest, I never even got a phone call. I had to check the website to see it said candidate declined. Numerous calls to HR to find out status of applications went unanswered. Horrible HR communication. Or lack there of. Upper management is not much better. They say they'll help but then never do.

pros: Large company with good benefits, remote work depending on department and manager, encourages employee training, nice facilities.
cons: Constant re-orgs result in constant layoffs then hiring in different departments or locations, hence a reputation as a revolving door. Very difficult to get promoted. Cross calibrations are phony because it all depends on how your manager presents you in the meetings so you could be screwed if your manager doesn't like you or if they don't know enough about what you actually do. There is overt ageism as evidenced in the majority of the people who get laid off. Depending on department or management, you could work yourself to death with very little work/life balance.

pros: Good coworkers, not much else
cons: Horribly low pay for amount of work. If someone is required to wear a suit each day to work then you need to be paying more than minimum wage. unrealistic sales goals... I mean come on it's 2017 and you can open up a bank account, apply for a loan, get a credit card, invest online. Took away bonuses for sales goals since it's now a liability and used them for marketing instead but still expects employees to sell. Bad compensation = low sales.

review_title: The manager makes a difference, so hopefully you get a good one.
pros:
• Great people (the ones who aren't looking to simply climb the ladder)
• Great perks
• Great technology
• Ability for remote work
• Travel
cons:
• The wrong manager will ruin your experience
• Prefers who you know and well you are liked over talent and hard work
• Favoritism
• Did I mention management?
• Teammates from different locations favor their location teammates
• Still an internal battle between locations
• Senior management looks to create a barrier between teams

review_title: Terrible Leaders - Good Pay - Good balance
job_title: Senior Enhanced Due Diligence Analyst in New Orleans, LA
pros: The particular department in which I worked had a somewhat lax atmosphere. The company is progressive and I believe compensates employees fairly.
cons: The management within my department was horrible. Out of the three upper-level managers that I had two didn't care at all about their reports. There is no recognition for doing good work and very little opportunity for advancement. Managers frequently completed all of the interesting projects by themselves leaving only the most mundane mindless work for the team to complete. After bringing this up to our senior leader for 2 years, nothing was ever done. Very selfish management. If you are smart and want to be successful, do not work here. Your intelligence will not be used and will be overlooked.

review_title: Mainly good folks, but lots of posers with power in Richmond
pros: Some of the best and smartest people I've worked with in terms of sheer analytic skills and ability.  The West Creek complex has lots to make the working area fresh and enjoyable - albeit a bit short of space.
cons: Make no mistake - the place is politics to the nth degree, and not in a favorable way.  If you're looking for candor and transparency in leadership this in not the place to look.  I'm not saying that all are vile, but I would say that there is an 'old guard' in mid-upper management that has lost its way.  And the self-interest of these folks severely limits the ability of the company to be the best.  People are pawns, and contractors... well they're something less, but at least provide cover.

job_title: Senior Reporting Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Telecommuting.  They also took me to Austin.  That's it.
cons: Disorganization, frequent layoffs, pretentious attitude, culture of complacency makes it difficult to incentivize people to improve, tolerance and acceptance of mediocrity and intolerance toward those who want to bring about positive change.

job_title: Senior Reporting Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Telecommuting.  They also took me to Austin.  That's it.
cons: Disorganization, frequent layoffs, pretentious attitude, culture of complacency makes it difficult to incentivize people to improve, tolerance and acceptance of mediocrity and intolerance toward those who want to bring about positive change.

review_title: A year and a half in and the honeymoon continues!
pros: My colleagues have been a pleasure to work with. I feel the company rewards good performers well. Exciting work that makes me eager and motivated to be in the office with my colleagues every day. Executive leadership in my department is approachable and challenges all levels to bring ideas to the table. Truly feels like a tech culture in financial services. Work life balance is great.
cons: The meetings. Oh lord, the meetings. You will be pulled into so many meetings you will barely have time for productive work hours on some days. It's one thing if you're a value add at the table, but sometimes you're called upon to just be present for no other reason than to be present. I feel like the company needs to do a better job of addressing "the meeting problem," because it's a consistent complaint across Glass Door.

review_title: Fantastic, large company - just be flexible
job_title: Senior Process Manager in Tigard, OR
pros: In short, I perceived Capital One to be a bit of an odd duck amongst big financial institutions. It's very progressive, both in business and in its social stances and efforts. It's large, but its structure feels relative flat, and they value independent input and questions. They don't squash down constructive dissent, they welcome it. They don't brace against change, they embrace it.
cons: They embrace change, and so you can expect a lot of it. That makes day-to-day work challenging at times (but also exciting), and it may mean that you get changed right out of the picture, which is what is happening to me as part of a site closure. That said, they've been more supportive about that change and transition than you can imagine, so even that isn't very much of a con.

pros: Capital One is committed to offering the best possible services to its customers and strives every day to achieve that.   However, their commitment to excellence is also reflected in the treatment of their employees.  They have incredible benefits packages, and their implementation of it shows how much Capital One truly cares about its employees' well-being.
cons: They do not promote well from within, unless you live in the Richmond or Plano area.  They also impose goals on their retail staff that are bordering on unreasonable, especially in today's technologically digital age.  Several times, they require tasks from their employees without adequate training.

job_title: Principal Research Associate in McLean, VA
pros: Good perks: gym, cafeteria. Strong work life balance. Beautiful offices.
cons:
Under the guise of "calibration against your peers," individuals can be pushed out without being given a chance to prove themselves, as was my case after just 4 months at the company. The same experience happened to two members of my team who were African American and had been at the company for less than a year. As a gay man of color, I have to wonder if "poor job fit" was simply an excuse to get rid of someone who was physically different from the rest of the department. 

Company is large and hard to navigate. You have to continuously re-do your work because you need to incorporate feedback from 3 layers of bureaucracy. 

Trips down to the Richmond office are exhausting.

Inconsistencies with policies about remote work and whether vacation time is actively tracked or not (varies manager to manager). 

This is place fixated on doing things "The Capital One way," with no room for interpretation, even if someone comes in from a different industry. Managers are fastidious about PowerPoint decks fitting a rigid format in everything from style to content.

pros:
Great benefits, decent pay for young adults just starting out, great place for career opportunities.
I enjoy working at Capital One Bank working and interacting with customers. Teaches you a lot of structure in professionalism. Co-workers and managers are very supportive, everyone works as a team which makes the environment feel equal. Also I love the fact they have a "open-door" policy which they strongly encourage employees to take advantage of.
cons: The contact center is a Business Critical Operation center where when the whole city is closed down due to inclement weather you still have to report to work. I would prefer to work in a branch where the hours are less stressful and more manageable. The company should expand as far as contact center and branches to better assist customers.

review_title: Good place to start, but don't throw your talent away here!
job_title: Senior Business Systems Analyst in Richmond, VA
pros: The company offers great starting salary for anyone with a Master's degree. You are given tons of training up front (in fact take advantage of an entire library of web based training). Its a good company to get your bearings of Corporate America. Their benefits are good with generous vacation and work from home policy.
cons: You are stereotyped by the role and projects you have participated in. Senior management is mostly male and are isolated from day to day activities. Expectations are high but the worst part is the tendency to focus on weaknesses and to induce anxiety over trivial details. Your talent and skills will atrophy if you stay in this company for long.

job_title: Fraud Account Supervisor in Richmond, VA
pros: Great Benefits from your hire date
cons: At the beginning they tell you that you not going to be monitored when taking calls or watch how many calls you are taking and how long you’re off the phone.  But I tell you this that is so not right.  They do every one of these things.  Don’t ever tell and be honest and tell them something that you did wrong and that you were sorry for because after 2 days goes by they decide to fire you!  How wrong is that!  No slap on the hand, no write up, just fire you!  Just be careful!

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in McLean, VA
pros: Great company culture. In my 3 years working here I have yet to meet someone I disliked or couldn't work with. Everyone is very professional, smart and dedicated. The pay is ok (could be better) and the company is willing to try new things
cons:
Too much change. While there is a vision of where we want to be and an understanding of where we are, there isn't a clear direction of how to get from A to Z. It feels like every year the company is changing direction and what you've been working on for the past year is no longer worth anything. 

Plus there is a pressure in the IT department for everyone to be able to do everything - which will only lead to everyone to being the jack of all trades but the master of none. 

Also, for a company that want to be the google of banking, they need to do more to remove barriers to innovation.

job_title: Direct Loan Officer in Plano, TX
pros: Benefits are good. 401k has a good match. Medical is good. But, a lot of back stabbing and management has much to be desired.
cons: Very poor upper management starting at the top home loans. Very poor upper management starting at the top of home loans. Distributed Chanel is a revolving door for LO"s looking for a guarantee. Top producers are shunned if they speak up. A lot of attrition in direr t also. DE site had 2 LO's leave within 3 weeks of hire date. Questionable manager settling false expectations in DE. Not a merit driven department. Only those that play the political game can advance. Employee turnover and engagement is comical. It seems in this department upper management is fixated on self preservation opposed to growing the business. Employees are an after thought. For gods sake gmail now views our promotional emails as spam.
